text:
Series 2 fell off a cliff I loved the first series of this, it was genuinely funny, compelling and well-written. I binged the hell out of it.

So what happened to series 2?? It was all over the place. Having established Sly by the end of S1 they needed to throw new adversaries at him but they went mad, throwing three different groups into the mix and then deciding late on which of them was the real bad guy.

It wasted too much time on his family relationships and while you do need your characters to be grounded to generate empathy for them, there was too much of this and it really slowed the episodes down.

I agree with the reviewers who say the whole concept is ridiculous - that he just waltzes in, punches someone and everyone accepts him taking over, that the police barely feature during all this crime, that the portrayal of NY seems silly. But I don;t mind all that - it's entertainment and it's not trying to be a Scorsese movie. But the story was a mess and that hurt series 2 badly.

We have all known for ages that Taylor Sheridan has been spreading himself far too thinly - the Yellowstone prequels were boring and the final series of that is looking pretty shaky for being forced not to include Costner.

Maybe this was just a great one-series show but like so many, they make more of it without having anything else to say. If it does get a S3 I really hope they don't mess that up too.

text:
The Newgrounds Animators Have Finally Made It Following the production of the "Hellbenders" pilot and the brief history of Sleepy Cabin, its great to finally see some of the best internet funny bois get their vision on TV. It fully retains the spontaneity of Zach and Michael's unique internet animation styles and wastes no time at all with the jokes. The structure of the 12-min short is split into 2 plots which are equally fascinating and bizarre but not in the way a lot of "edgy" or subversive adult animated shows tend to be. The looseness of the drawing style helps the craziness never seem like its on rails, it truly feels like you're in the mind of 2 nutbag internet artists and I love it.

Mike Stoklasa's performance will be one for the history books.

text: This is really, really good. First off, I don't think it's a spoiler to say that I can smell Gary Oldman's stink through the screen. So much so that I even googled how much time he spends in make-up to achieve how downright nasty his character appears on the screen. But alas!!! I found nothing. But trust me, if he was "Character Acting" we would know. The co-stars would say something. Claire Danes played a similarly disgusting person on Homeland, but Gary is far, far more obvious in his portrayal. That said, this is basically a story of a bunch of Millennials and Boomers forced together in a spy vs. Spy sort of story. There is a lot of humor (American English= American spelling) a little bit of violence and a whole lot of sticking it to the man and behind the back betrayal. But on the whole, it's about two very distinct (I can only come up with personalities) ways of saving the people within the country's borders of Great Britain from terrorism. One side being the all great MI5 and the other being their miscreant, screwup, castoffs. This show is fun. I think that this is only the third show/movie since I joined IMDB more than 20 years ago that I rated above an 8. However, I still can't rate MASH or Cheers. I don't know why, because I am a Boomer after all, let's just say that my rating this a 9 is high praise indeed.

text:
Materialists, Pretty but Shallow I walked into Materialists hoping for something sharp, unsettling, and soul rattling, something in the vein of Past Lives, a film that crawled under my skin and refused to leave. What I got was... just fine. Stylish, clever, occasionally moving but shallow compared to what it could have been. Materialists isn't bad, Dakota Johnson owns every frame with a presence that makes everything else fade. The visuals shine, and both Pascal and Evans are fine.

But for me, it never went deep enough. It toyed with love vs money, dating & marriage but only skimmed the surface. Anyways It's smart, it's pretty, and it has moments of brilliance. But for someone who craves films that leaves impact, Materialists felt like a missed opportunity. I wanted more, More emotion, more depth.

I know it is all the rave to complain about the unequal treatment by police officers but I watched the last two episodes yesterday and Detective Bernard complained about it in both episodes almost the same way. Move on from that, get back to good stories and let the audience draw their own conclusions about disequity. We're not stupid and we certainly don't need to be beat over the head with it.

As for Hugh Dancy - Wow, what a nothing of an ADA. No passion, no empathy for the victims, just an automoton.

Finally, the story writing is lazy with huge plot holes so they can stitch up the story quick and get in more commercials. The writers should be fired and get a new crew.

text:
The show that changed TV forever There have been a lot of great TV since its conception. The fact remained though that it was overall beneath movies in quality.

Enter the first of many similar HBO masterpieces. This show presents itself as the story about a family man tackling the every-day problems of life, only one difference: he is in the mafia. This show dared to go where no TV and not many movies had gone before. It actually portrayed the players in the criminal life as complex human beings and made them relatable.

The Godfather and Scroreses works are all fantastic, but Sopranos truly broke new ground in not romantisicing the inner playings of the mafia in any way.

The actors are all fantastic, especially the late James Gandolfini, and do a great job of conveying this unique and never-before seen story.

Whilst being great in its own right, it paved the way for pretty much all great TV shows since and HBO shows such as Game of Thrones, The Wire, Treme, Rome, The Outsider and so on.

It is definitely a recommendation any day of the week if you haven't (for unlikely reasons) watched it yet!
label: literal

text:
Boring - Unrealistic Ted Danson and the makers of "The Good Place" enticed me to this show. Episode after episode , was hoping something interesting to happen but just cliche after cliche. The whole premise is of a retirement community where some stuff has got stolen and Ted Danson goes in to investigate as an insider.

The community is picture perfect to ridiculous levels where every employee is a passionate and perfect employee. The retirement centre feels like a five star resort. How on earth can these old people afford it and how can you sympathise with any of them , considering the struggles actual old people face in reality with poor finances,health and basic care.

Even the guy who has cancer is never shown even in pain once and looks hale and hearty. If this was what you faced as an old person, you will retire and move in there right away.

Unbelievable that this is the same group which made a masterpiece like "The Good Place".

text:
Go and watch the 1994 masterpiece instead Even if the film is visually beautiful, it feels like a superficial version of the 1994 movie. If by chance you haven't seen Mary Shelley's Frankenstein (1994), go watch it instead and you'll see what I'm talking about. I can't believe so many people are writing euphoric reviews.

Every strong punchline from the 1994 film is reduced to a mere shadow here. Every opportunity to convey the creature's sorrow is missed. Instead of expressing it cinematically, del Toro chose to deliver it through direct narration from Frankenstein's monster, which I found rather dull.

Additionally, the makeup of Frankenstein's monster feels more aesthetic than eerie or realistic, which was a letdown for me.

This movie deserves a 1 or a 10, anything in the middle in not fair. It's either the worst sickly idiotic spiritualist romantic schlock; or genuine art. No. the latter is too ridiculous an indefensible with this nonsense which causes dangerous convulsions with its clichÃ©s.

Sirk deserved better and he was a true intellectual, but its impossible to defend this banal drivel.

text: A good actioner Having just finished reading Stephen King's 'The Running Man', and having just seen this movie, I say that while the former astounded me, the latter served purposes of mere entertainment.  The novel 'The Running Man', written in '82 is 100 times more potent in it's horrifying Orwellian vision of our future.  With the mind-numbing, scapegoating shows on Reality TV, it is very easy to see that in the 2025 this sort of organized madness is plausible. 'The Running Man' movie has lost almost all the social commentary of its source material, but manages to retain the sense of raw suspense the book carried throughout.  As a film, this is no Terminator 2, or even a Total Recall, but its still a decent actioner, certainly better than the tripe Schwarzenegger turns out today (Although I have fingers crossed for T3)

text:
Leans More Towards History Lesson Than Drama, But Still Solid There are two ways to make a historical film such as Nuremberg. The first is to take some liberties (if more in time than in actual facts/events) in pursuit of drama. The second is the "just the facts, ma'am" strategy. Director/writer James Vanderbilt takes the latter approach here, which crimps the movie's ceiling but also raises its floor.

For a very basic overview, this film looks at the Nuremberg Trials largely from the perspective of Douglas Kelley (Rami Malek), a psychiatrist brought in to evaluate the German prisoners, most notably Hermann Goring (Russell Crowe). Simultaneously, Justice Robert H. Jackson (Michael Shannon) struggles to put together a war crimes trial unlike anything any justice system has ever seen.

I'll start with the ceiling-limitation on Nuremberg, which is that it's far from Spielberg-ian drama. This is a simply-made film that does not lean into dramatic flourishes. This approach renders it more "history lesson" than "fully engrossing drama". As such, it's tough to give Nuremberg the highest of marks.

On the positive side of things, Nuremberg covers a compelling story which was truly a watershed moment in the history of war and its crimes. Crowe is chilling in embodying the pompous Goring, while Malek portrays a wonderfully sympathetic adversary. The final 20-30 minutes are the highlight here, when the psychological battling and the actual trial converge.

All told, Nuremberg is a movie that deftly portrays all the themes it sets out to cover. The underlying message, that fascism isn't contained to the Nazi regime, is an important one (if frustratingly difficult to convey with high drama and still be as historically accurate as Vanderbilt shoots for here). This results in somewhat of a "take your medicine and learn your history" feel to the overall experience (eschewing manufactured drama), but the end result is still a solid flick from which at least some entertainment and many lessons can be derived.
label: literal

text:
Nope. Frankenstein's monster is not a superhero. He doesn't growl like a bear or a dinosaur. He can't be shot twenty times and keep coming. Further, I don't care about Victor Frankenstein's boyhood. I don't enjoy watching the gilded rich in their massive gowns while listening to future Victor's verbose narration. Give me the story of a man who created another man out of body parts. The horror of that is enough. Give me the perspective of such a creature. The sadness of that is sufficient.

Here instead we have another overcooked grasping for what the algorithms demand, the further dumbing down of cinema for the distracted smartphone generation. Yeah yeah, it's Guillermo Del Toro. I'm familiar. I've had dinner with him. And his last good film was Pan's Labyrinth.

See you on down the road.

6/10.

text:
A brilliant performance by Billy Bob Thornton Billy Bob Thornton delivers a standout performance as Tommy Norris, a seasoned landman navigating the treacherous terrain of the oil industry. His portrayal adds depth to the series, anchoring its complex narrative.

The show skillfully intertwines family dynamics with the high-stakes oil business. While some characters, like Jacob Lattland's Cooper Norris and Paulina Chavez's Ariana, may feel slightly contrived, they effectively contribute to the overarching storyline.

Set against the backdrop of Texas's rugged landscape, "Landman" offers a raw and authentic portrayal of the oil industry's impact on individuals and communities. Sheridan's direction ensures a compelling viewing experience, making it a must-watch for fans of intense drama.

text:
A Poignant Picture Of Betrayal, Desire And Reconciliation Regretting You is a poignant picture of betrayal, desire and reconciliation. While it leans on stereotypical characters and trite storylines, director Josh Boone's willingness to embrace these clichÃ©s is ultimately what brings the film its heart and timelessness.

Set against the idyllic backdrop of the American South, Regretting You follows a seemingly-perfect family struck not only by an unimaginable tragedy, but by revelations of truths that threaten to destroy the fragile balance its survivors have found. When Morgan (Allison Williams) attempts to restore a sense of normalcy to her teenage daughter's (McKenna Grace) life, both find themselves on parallel paths of healing and self-discovery.

Regretting You tackles heartbreaking themes such as grief and deception, but projects them through a heavily romanticized lens. The creative team chooses to emphasize the optimism and togetherness that usually follow acceptance, only briefly acknowledging the emotional aftermath of a loss. Love is equally idealized, painted as an all-withstanding entity that exists in the form of letters and watermelon Jolly Ranchers, in tearful confessions in the rain, golden sunsets and starry skies. Conflict and suffering are given inadequate weight; despite its dramatic premise - Regretting You is a vision of perfection, not realism. However, this rejection of authenticity creates a fleeting atmosphere of hope and comfort. The film is an invitation to safety, taking viewers directly to the picturesque, imagined worlds we retreat to when reality's light becomes too harsh. The creators don't glorify pain; they simply opt for a portrayal shallow enough that it allowed me to immerse myself in the story for the time that it lasted, then walk away without its emotional weight - a meaningful but ephemeral escape from reality. The majority of Regretting You is a sentimental portrait, composed of overused cliches and excessively sentimental exchanges, but this allows the film's few gems of both comedy and true drama to stand out. For example, Allison Williams delivers an especially captivating performance upon discovering that a loved one has been unfaithful. The classical characters carry a feeling of nostalgia, while the film's predictability creates a sense of tragic irony that makes it impossible not to get lost in.

Regretting You is a reminder that when life hands you lemons, make lemonade. Beautiful things are born from the worst of circumstances; losing something cherished can be the beginning of something else. Your loved ones can help you build a new life, start over, and, with time, learn to heal.

I give Regretting You 3.5 out of 5 stars and recommend it for ages 12 to 18, plus adults. The film releases in theaters on October 24, 2025.

By Ruhi K., KIDS FIRST!
label: figurative

text:
Too many difficult to like characters and some very unfunny comedy sink this one. "Is This Thing On?" is a new film directed by Bradley Cooper and Cooper also plays a relatively minor role in the story. I saw it at the Philadelphia Film Festival yesterday.

Alex and Tess (Will Arnett and Laura Dern) are married but they are separating. Neither seems to have that much reason to separate other than, perhaps, boredom. However, Alex copes with this in a strange way. Instead of seeking therapy, he decides on a lark to do standup comedy! As for the wife, she copes by returning to her first love, volleyball.

So why did I give this one a paltry five? Well, two main reasons. First, Arnett is supposed to be doing standup and people like his act...but the act has barely a laugh in it at any time! They really needed to get a comedian to punch up Arnett's act and it just doesn't make sense why anyone would want to see it. In contrast, the very first episode of "The Marvelous Miss Maisel", the main character was freaking hilarious the first time she did standup! Second, the characters are all people I either strongly disliked (Alex, Tess, their extended family and friends) or was completely ambivalent towards (the gay couple and the kids). It;s a real shame, as the message that EVENTUALLY comes out in the film is an important one...that folks in a marriage might just need to focus on a hobby or avocation which gives them satisfaction, not just expecting their spouse to provide this. Overall, it sure seems like a film which could used a bit of a re-write and I can't see going to the trouble of seeing this in theaters...more a film to watch on Netflix or some other streaming service...if at all.
label: figurative

text:
January Embers Stephen King adaptations can be a mixed bag. For every masterpiece, A Shawshank Redemption and The Shining there are other productions that sit opposite, CELL, Bag of Bones and the deplorable Mist TV series to name a few. King has a huge body of work and some times it takes a film director to make or break his writing for a cinematic audience.

Andy Muschietti and screenwriter Cary Fukunaga announced a cinema version of IT in 2014. Muschietti had directed MAMA and Fukunaga had gone into bat for Woody Harrelson and Matt Mcconaughey for the first season of True Detective. It was an interesting peering and then the production went quiet. until the first trailer.

Based on the the Novel by King and the television version which featured Tim Curry as the clown antagonist obsessed with killing children the question was; would the trailer that broke the internet match up to everything read and seen before? and if so would it be better?After two full versions Andy Muschietti had a lot of work to do.

Bill, Ben , Beverley, Richie, Mike, Eddie and Stanley live in the fictional town Derry Maine. They are all very early teenagers and find comfort among each other and are very close. Early on Bill loses his brother and it soon becomes obvious that Derry houses a demon so evil that adults cannot see it leaving it to the teens to do something about it. This is a very Stephen King story.

After a relentless death that will go down in the halls of Horror as a great film murder. This becomes a very adult version of the story compared to the mini series but not so the novel which is even more adult. Stephen King WTF !!. The Clown PENNYWISE is pivotal early and Bill Skisgard is owning it in the first few seconds which is important not just for the story but also the cinematography sound and general tension.

Muschietti has done an amazing job. Stephen King has mentioned he did not expect this to be as good as it is and he is right. This is a fantastic horror film but in saying it pays homage to the classic 80's and also addresses the issues of teens growing up ( Well almost ) and creates an on screen entity that future films other that the sequel will struggle to compete with.

PENNYWISE is not nice, Hannibal Lecter not nice.

A film that has had the highest opening of any horror film ever and it deserves this, We deserve it , This is the mini series on steroids and fills the gap between the three. Smart acting directing and writing for a simple horror film which has fallen into very caring hands.

Bring on Chapter 2...It's going to get very nasty.

text:
Bob Merrick reminds one of Ethan Couch In 2013, reports arose of a teenage boy in Texas named Ethan Couch who had been drinking and driving with some friends and accidentally killed some people in the process. His lawyer made the argument that his privileged upbringing gave him no sense of right and wrong, resulting in a slap on the wrist for the boy. This scenario has become known as affluenza.

The spoiled protagonist in Lloyd Douglas's "Magnificent Obsession" is kind of like that, in that his irresponsibility resulted in someone else's death. I watched the 1935 and 1954 versions back-to-back. The original is obviously the more serious one, while Douglas Sirk's remake has more of a glossy quality. I understand that Sirk's movies are now seen as a critique of the supposed idealism of the US lifestyle, and that their look inspired Todd Haynes's "Far from Heaven". I can see that.

As for the content, the cast puts in good enough performances. Every time that Agnes Moorehead's character was on screen, I though "Stop encouraging Tabitha to use witchcraft!". Anyway, respectable movie.

text:
It's a movie that's easy to enjoy while sitting down and watching with free action. Four years after the surprise hit Nobody introduced the world to the suburban dad with a dark past, Hutch Mansell (Bob Odenkirk) returns in a sequel that doubles down on the first film's winning formula. Directed by Timo Tjahjanto and written by returning scribe Derek Kolstad, Nobody 2 is a gleefully violent, fast-paced, and darkly humorous romp that, while lacking some of the original's novelty, proves to be a more than worthy follow-up.

The film picks up with Hutch still living a double life. To pay off the massive debt he incurred by wiping out a Russian mob syndicate, he's now working as an assassin for the shadowy organization known only as "The Barber." This work, however, is taking a toll on his family life. Hutch's wife, Becca (Connie Nielsen), and children are becoming distant, so in an effort to reconnect, he plans a family vacation to a waterpark in the small tourist town of Plummerville-a place he remembers from his own childhood. Of course, this is a Nobody movie, so the peaceful getaway is short-lived. A minor altercation at an arcade escalates into a full-blown confrontation with the town's criminal element, led by a corrupt theme park owner (John Ortiz) and his menacing sheriff (Colin Hanks). This small-town syndicate, in turn, is merely a front for a ruthless, unhinged crime boss named Lendina, played with scenery-chewing delight by Sharon Stone.

The true star of the show remains Bob Odenkirk. He seamlessly slips back into the role of Hutch Mansell, a man who just wants to live a quiet life but is constantly pulled back into a world of brutal violence. Odenkirk's performance perfectly balances the character's exhausted resignation with the explosive, almost-unhinged glee he gets from dispatching his foes. The film wisely understands that its core appeal lies in watching this seemingly ordinary man become an engine of chaotic destruction.

While the plot is admittedly formulaic and serves primarily as a vehicle for a new round of meticulously choreographed mayhem, the action is top-notch. Director Timo Tjahjanto brings his signature brand of bone-crunching, over-the-top violence to the franchise. The set pieces are inventive, taking full advantage of the amusement park setting. We see Hutch using everything from water slides to ball pits to a funhouse as his personal battlefield, each sequence more outlandish and fun than the last. The movie doesn't take itself too seriously, embracing its own absurdity and delivering a high-octane spectacle that will satisfy any action fan.

The supporting cast, including Christopher Lloyd as Hutch's dad and RZA as his brother, Harry, also return, adding to the film's unique charm. The film smartly weaves them into the action, turning the final confrontation into a bizarre, family-bonding bloodbath. Sharon Stone is a standout as the film's primary antagonist, delivering a performance that is both terrifying and wildly entertaining.

In conclusion, Nobody 2 is a fantastic example of a sequel that understands its audience. It delivers exactly what fans of the original loved: more of Bob Odenkirk's brilliant performance, more visceral and creative fight scenes, and a relentless pace that never lets up. While it may not surprise you in terms of story, it is a hugely entertaining and satisfying slice of brutal action cinema that proves the Nobody franchise has plenty of gas left in the tank. It's a perfect popcorn flick for a night out, a relentless and fun ride from start to finish.
label: literal

text:
Season 2: 5/10 & Season 1: 10/10 Season 2 is pulled in too many directions with boring and seemingly pointless plot lines. The writing is sloppy, and the storyline is flailing all over the place. I had a hard time sitting in place to finish the first 4 episodes, mainly because of the following:

(1) Bruno: His plot line with Enid gets way too much screen time, and Bruno is a boring flat character. After their first couple scenes, I'm quite sure the audience got enough - we don't need to be banged in the head with it over and over when there's literally nothing new to learn.

(2) Slurp: How I hate this plot line so much. Why does Slurp get so much screen time? What's the point of the zombie? Slurp had better be integral to the mystery plot line. Even if Slurp is integral, they still devoted too much screen time to this. I literally walked away to do laundry during these scenes and sometimes forgot to come back.

(3) Agnes DeMille - The actress is fantastic, but the plot lines are ridiculous. What was up with the stunt that almost kill Enid? If the "prank" was not so brutal, then sure. But the prank was deadly, and this firmly puts Agnes into "psycho crazy" territory vs potential friend territory. Wednesday's blase reaction to Agnes' prank doesn't align with her character, especially given how Wednesday seemingly is protective over Enid like Pugsley, and with Pugsley, she nearly killed the entire swim team with piranhas for having done less. She would have reported or taken revenge on Agnes.

(4) Tyler Galpin: Arguably the most complex character on the show outside of Wednesday, and yet they sideline his character - what a loss for the show and for the audience. Like if what the writers have revealed to us is true (ie Thornhill controlled the Hyde), aren't the actions of the Hyde due to Thornhill and not Tyler? I'm so confused with Wednesday's total write off of Tyler and this doesn't align with her liking for darkness and internally sympathetic nature. Outside of this misalignment, I think they should have threaded this continuing storyline more into this season to maintain continuity. Because as-is this show is flailing all over the place.
label: figurative

text:
There's a lot to unpack It's been years since I wrote a review on IMDb. For that matter, I wiped my youthful, naive review slate clean a few years ago. But I felt compelled to write one for this for a number of reasons.

I just watched these first two episodes today. Mainly cuz I do respect Mike White, but mostly because I adore a properly done dark comedy maybe more than anything... and if Steve Zahn is in it, I'll probably watch it.

So first off, I can actually understand people's confusion to this. I saw a few other reviews that said "this isn't funny", "these characters are awful", "was Lani's water breaking supposed to be funny?".

I get this reaction if you go in expecting a standard "dark comedy". But much like HBO's masterpiece "Barry", it's intensely dark in all of the strangest places. (Is "Barry" more laugh out loud funny than "The White Lotus"? YES. Is something like "Barry" just slightly more of a crowd-pleaser in terms of its flawless execution? YES. Do I consider "Barry" one of the greatest shows ever made? YES. Is "The White Lotus" in the same league? NO, not necessarily. But it certainly deserves respect). However, I've found myself more intrigued by the dark drama of these characters (and the inherent ugliness... or social disconnect, rather) and surprised by the strangely layered comedy that has come through.

Strangely layered. I have a hunch that this series would be funnier on a second viewing because it's certainly a confounding yet intriguing little mystery.

There aren't punchlines. No. That's not where the comedy comes from. It seems, at least after the first 2 episodes, that a lot of the comedy is coming from pain or anger or hesitation or fear or simply being uncomfortable.

I laughed at very strange things during this... and I felt for the characters as well, despite (as many others have pointed out) that they're mostly unlikable. But I like this. It forces you to reflect and think about who these people are. Why do we need to like or root for our main characters? As long as they're interesting... that's all I care about. (Look at the woefully underrated "The Founder" starring Michael Keaton about McDonald's. At the end of the day, there's not much likable about his portrayal of Ray Kroc... but it was an excellent movie with an excellent performance).

I, personally, find the flawed/unlikable characters more interesting. And I'm always surprised when I can get emotionally behind someone I either don''t understand or puts me off.

To answer those questions above... was Lani's water breaking supposed to be funny? In my opinion, no... not at all. In fact, if it was a cheaper comedy, they would'v'e had Armond slip and fall in the fluid. But that's not what happened. Because it's not that kind of comedy.

This is a drama under the thin guise of a dark comedy. But it's working for me. And, again, I understand where it may not for many. These characters are awful in many ways. But I feel there are complexities unfolding that might turn out great. I'm immensely enjoying the mystery of who is the body being put on the place in Scene 1 of episode 1.

To be in paradise and still be in a personal Hell is something I find to be an incredibly juxtaposed position to be in. The idea that there is so much confusion and so little happiness while having the luxury to even be at a resort like that in the first place is a fascinating concept.

Not to feel sorry for the wealthy, upper "elite". But to prove, in many ways, that money doesn't buy happiness.

I'm excited to see where this goes. Will it let me down mid-way like most shows do? Maybe. But for now, as the 3rd episode airs tonight...

...Color me intrigued.
label: figurative

text: For the love of Sirk The first of the run of lush Cinemascope dramas Sirk did for Universal is this re-make of the 1935 Stahl film, with Rock Hudson and Jane Wyman this time in the leading roles. Hudson is the selfish, rich layabout who discovers a "new way of living" only after he indirectly causes both the death of Wymna's husband and her blindness. And they proceed to fall in love! Only in Hollywood, I guess, but this crazy plot is miraculously made touching and real by Sirk, who films it in glorious colour compositions. The constant Sirk theme of the dissatisfied, idle rich is portrayed well by Hudson, whose movie-star hunk image is the perfect facade for Sirk to tear down in showing the initial emptiness of Bob Merrick's life. He and Wyman would do better work in "All That Heaven Allows" a year later, but this may be the better test of whether or not you "get" Sirk. If you can look past the outlandish plot, no, actually look inside it and find depth, you'll know you like Sirk.
label: figurative

text:
It's not bad The biggest problem that Hazbin Hotel has is the limited time given to each episode. The plot is being rushed through at the speed of sound which doesn't allow for meaningful moments or action sequences to be convincing. The premise is a bit confusing since it brands itself as a kind of redemption show but that is not what the majority of the conflict is about. It presents you with all of these heavy topics relating to abuse of power and forgets about its redemption themes until a character makes a side remark. Going forward with a season 2, I hope they give the show and its characters more time to be properly fleshed out.

Aside from the general pacing issues, the animation is solid and feels very fluid. I can understand some criticisms about lack of differing body-types but that is what the style is. However, it may not be to everyone's taste.

The sound design and music is very good. I am a big fan of Broadway musicals and this show hit that sweet sound for me. The one issue I had about the sound design is the voice acting particularly in the first few episodes. One characters voice, Vaggie, sounded a little bit too monotone and sharp compared to the rest of cast. This didn't seem intentional either. This is just a small nitpick.

Overall, this show is very fun to watch despite its pacing flaws.
label: literal

text:
Ari Aster's New Divisive Movie Unlike many horror fans, I have never seen an Ari Aster movie, but I have heard great things about him. I had to check out "Eddington" due to all the discourse around it. This is a very polarizing movie, so some will love it while others hate it. The movie stars Joaquin Phoenix, Pedro Pascal, Emma Stone, and Deirdre O'Connell. Taking place during the beginning of Covid and the BLM movement, a standoff between the sheriff and current mayor causes things to get out of hand in Eddington, New Mexico.

I love the buzz around this movie because it means people are talking about it. It definitely is a thought-provoking movie because so much happens. At the same time, not all the discourse is peaceful. It was a very weird experience watching this, and there is a lot to unpack. Joaquin Phoenix and Pedro Pascal give great performances in this movie. I thought Joaquin was slightly better, but we also followed him the whole movie. Ari Aster shows his talent by creating a great technical movie. There were many scenes filled with anxiety and uncomfortable moments with the use of sound and camera movement. The little carnage in this movie looked great as well. Also, the writing created many surprisingly funny dark moments.

With a 2 hour 30 minute runtime, there has to be a lot to fill the time. The story didn't fail to fill the time, but I didn't feel like it wrapped up neatly by the end. I thought the movie would have been slightly better if they had cut out the final 10 minutes or so. This would have helped wrap things up as well as cut down on the length. Emma Stone and Austin Butler seemed wasted. They have very little screen time, and the movie wouldn't change if they were removed. I am unsure of the message being told. The events of the pandemic are extreme versions within this film. Both main characters aren't great people, so there is no one to root for. However, this may be the point.

"Eddington" certainly needs a rewatch before the end of the year, but it's not a movie I particularly want to rewatch. My favorite part of the movie was the mayoral campaign and even the Covid setting was neat. It's a hard movie to recommend due to the varying opinions people have. However, Ari Aster fans should check this out still.
label: literal

text:
To be taken once a year, with a pinch of salt The Running Man is one of those films that if overwatched, would become boring and depressing even.

My advice is to watch it maybe once or twice a year with a couple of mates and a few drinks.

In todays climate of TV Media domination and the capitalist mode in society it really does work as a revisionist social commentary, post 1980s-boom. Forget that though!  There are other brilliant and better reasons to watch this film.

Schwarzenegger is on top form as Ben "The Butcher of Bakersfield" Richards, and the inclusion of Bond-belting one liners was completely inspired-thety are truly leg-end-dary (with his rant to Killian over a camera the main highlight).

The design of the stalkers is authentically American, and mirrors the characterizations seen in the PC 'Gladiators' TV show, and the WWE as well. Buzz-saw's grisly end will chill any viewer to the core (as a foot note, why does his death stand out as particularly disturbing in what is ostensibly an upbeat actioner with a bitter sense of humour?)

Jesse Venturer and Sven Ole Thorssen are great as backing muscle (and are Arnies buds in real life), and its even got Mick Fleetwood in it too! What more could you ask for?

I highly recommend the Running Man if you're looking for a great piece of entertaining action, with a glossty finish and some great characters. Just don't expect an education from it (at least on surface value).

Quality, I bloody love it actually.  You will too unless you're a thesp. 7/10

text:
Now you don't see the magic This movie commits a cardinal sin.

It makes the original cast incompetent, such that the new crew can appear better.

It is to a point where it downgrades and makes fun of the original. Showing them unable to get out of cuffs, figure out extremely simple puzzles or heck even perform most magic.

The reason for this is simple: There is a new set of 3 main chars. They want them to appear competent, so they are the ones performing the magic, the ones solving puzzles e.g. Leaving the old gang to be and feel pointless. You could remove them from the movie, and the plot would still work - except with less gags poking fun at the "old magicians".

We have a little bit of magic in one scene where they "show" of to each other. Reminiscent somewhat of the first movie meetup. But thinking more about it and much of that scene makes no sense.

In general though, this movie prefers set dressing and hinting at magic, rather than showing much magic. There is significantly more brutal beating of various cops and heck even Interpol - who all are apparently utterly untrained and coordinated.

So yea, real fire to buildings, beating cops, causing car accidents and potentially risking the life of others, that is the "magic" here.

Of course there is a trick and twist. It makes very little sense and trying to think about the plot for more than 10 seconds almost makes your brain hurt from how extremely dumb it must assume the watcher to be.

The plot holes are big enough to escape through, so I guess there is some magic there.

While tempting to go into each one, I won't bother. Watch it when it goes to streaming and judge those yourself.

I didn't expect much of a third movie.. but something more the lines of the 2'end. But this - this might be one of the worst movies I've watched in recent years. Primarily for how it neglects the previous movies and degrade the abilities of the originals.

The should have made this movie about the new 3 chars from the start. Set in the same universe, same plot idea - maybe hints to the old crew - but not involve them. It would have been a better movie that way.

Oh yea - I also do love when a movie sequel bait hard at the end.

It currently still has surprisingly high rates - I can only assume that some people forgot the previous movies in the years that passed.

But I am not expecting a sequel, of if they do - just stick the new cast and stop ruining the old.
label: literal

text: Not quite a fantastic snore, but nothing we haven't seen be-four. I must admit that 'The Fantastic Four: First Steps (2025)' left me a little underwhelmed. Despite taking place in a retro-futuristic pocket universe separate to the rest of the MCU, the theoretically bright and colourful picture just lacks a genuine sense of wonder and is oddly dull considering how delightfully odd some parts of its world are. It doesn't really have any pep, any zip or zeal. It's a very paint-by-numbers effort that may be the first truly insular Marvel movie since 'Iron Man (2008)', but is still undeniably a generic superhero blockbuster. It feels very small and insignificant in some ways, despite its literally world-ending stakes and a powerful potential personal loss hovering over the eponymous four, and a lot of it just feels like highly produced fan fiction to me. Much of that feeling comes from the fact that, despite individually being confident and charismatic actors, the cast never quite gel together, their chemistry constantly seeming performative rather than natural. Pedro Pascal isn't quite what I think of when I think of Reed Richards, for example, and he's strangely flat here given how magnetically charming he is in real life. Vanessa Kirby gives her character more depth and dignity than we're used to (it's ironic that The Invisible Woman is arguably the most visible female character in any of Marvel's ensembles, although Yelena is also strong and complex lead), but she doesn't get anything meaty to chew on despite there being quite an emotionally draining central conflict she's directly involved in. Joseph Quinn isn't quite as quippy and delightfully jerk-ish as I'd expect, and Ebon Moss-Bachrach isn't afforded any opportunity of an arc thanks to the story's post-accident setting. Really, two of the four eponymous teammates feel like they're just there for decoration, and the two that get more focus mostly come across as lifeless and uninteresting. That's perhaps not entirely fair, but I can't deny that the flick fails to move me in any real way and that its underlying themes are so subtle they barley register. It isn't really about anything, nor do its characters go on any meaningful arcs, and it doesn't live up to the campy potential of its setting or source material. We could really do with something that isn't so self-serious from Marvel, something with a notably different tone and comedy that isn't based around meek quips you can see coming a mile away. This isn't that, though. For all its promises of being its own thing, it's devastatingly homogeneous. The thing is, though, that the movie isn't as bad as I've made it seem. It doesn't really get going until an exciting sequence set in space shakes the dust off and acts as the highlight of the entire affair, showcasing the formidable prowess of Julia Garner's Shalla-Bal (who makes Ralph Ineson's sedentary Galactus seem even less interesting than he already does) and easily putting you on the edge of your seat. The finale is also entertaining in its own generic way, essentially staying just one step ahead of the customary 'giant beam in the sky' ending by having said beam be a big bloke with a booming voice. It presents a compelling use of its characters' powers, combining them in enjoyable ways and really seeming to push their relatively restrained abilities to the limit. Most of the fantastic four's crime fighting is restricted to an opening montage that features snippets of showdowns far more interesting, albeit less 'important', than the one they're involved with for the duration of the plot, but the midsection of the movie is fairly fun in its depiction of its alternative-world science bringing every nation on the planet together. So, like I said, this isn't a bad film. It's just much a more middle-of-the-road experience than I'd like it to be, and that saps all the excitement out of both it and the thought that this team is going to be a major player in the MCU going forwards. It certainly isn't fantastic, let's put it like that. It's fun enough for what it is, though, and I'd probably say it's better than 'Captain America: Brave New World (2025)' now that I've had a bit of time to reflect on that film (it's nowhere near as strong an effort as 'Thunderbolts* (2025)', however). At this point, I don't quite know if "good enough" is good enough, especially considering that Marvel have been sort of floundering post 'Avengers: Endgame (2019)' and need to get back on track in time for their next big crossover event (which is unlikely now). For example, this pales in comparison to the sheer fun and emotional resonance of 'Superman (2025)', which is perhaps the first time in over ten years that DC have genuinely bested Marvel. As its own thing, it's a perfectly fine and often fairly fun superhero movie that conforms to its genre but is comfortable because of it. As Marvel's Hail Mary to get people back on board in time for 'Avengers: Doomsday (2026)', it doesn't cut the mustard.
label: literal

text:
An entertaining romp It would be a bit strong to call Materialists a 'modern Pride and Prejudice' - but there's a deeply inhaled whiff of that old contest between marrying for love or marrying for money. The film doesn't solve it (the ending can be guessed early on and is what the audience will want rather than any objective analysis). What it does do though is entertain thoroughly for a couple of hours and provide a clever enough dialogue for most of that to raise it above the standard rom-com.

Dakota Johnson plays Lucy Mason, a dating exec, matchmaking for New York's finest (a.k.a. Rich and good-looking). Two men, Chris Evans and Pedro Pascal, both want to date her, and both exuding best intentions and deep sincerity. Personally I don't think Lucy should take either of them if this were the real world, but it's not, it's a beautiful, magical Manhattan merry-go-round of lovers-for-life and wannabes. Throw in some dancing and it could almost be a fine romance for Fred and Ginger.

I'm pleased it didn't have any dancing: it manages to keep its feet on the ground long enough to relate to - if only for those at a distance of earning less than a couple of million a year - which also means that for anyone without half of Wall Street in the bank the small element of fantasy can be considered entirely justifiable!

Celine Song has made a second hit (after the beautifully crafted Past Lives) with just enough candour to make us question ourselves without intruding with a virtue-signalling message. We can ask ourselves what does love consist of, and does love conquer all, or we can just go with the flow.

Materialists is not a "classic" in the sense of Audrey Hepburn in Breakfast at Tiffany's or Julia Roberts in Pretty Woman: but the cast do the script proud and make it a thoroughly enjoyable. Don't go and see it if you are desperate for love, have just joined a dating app, are uncomfortable with your own attractiveness or inclined to take romcoms too seriously: but as a night out with a partner that you love it's worth the price of admission, or even just with a friend who likes dissecting the issues over coffee afterwards. I hope that is a reasonably helpful balance of 'materialism'!
label: figurative

text:
Plot holes galore The story is interesting. A very rich family employs a male nanny. He is seemingly wonderful with the kids and with everyone, but he's secret mission is to reek havoc on their lives.

The scenery is beautiful and the acting is generally OK, but there are exceptions, and major weaknesses in the story.

Then actor playing the 'hot villain' is neither masculine enough to be considered 'hot', nor does he come off very likeable. More like a 'know-it-all smug creep' that practically no one would want around their kids.

Then there's the issue with the family's best friends - when the husband in that family goes missing naturally everybody is worried about him, but it seems they very soon lose interest in that and stop asking about him. Hardly believeable! And we don't know if anyone finds out what had happened to him.

Then there's a point where the wife and kids are in greece and the husband can't reach them because the wife doesn't have her cellphone. Again - this makes no sense - the daughter is well into her teens and the family is wealthy - so she hasn't got a cellphone? And there's no phone in the house? And he could easily call the local maid...so this drama as if he can't reach them until he gets there from London is just nonsense.
label: literal

text:
ONE OF THE BEST ACTION FILM FROM CHINA The Shadow's Edge is a thrilling action-packed movie that showcases the enduring talents of Jackie Chan and Tony Leung Ka-fai. Even in their 70s, these legends deliver powerful performances reminiscent of Sylvester Stallone and his crew in The Expendables.

While Jackie Chan is a familiar icon to many, Tony Leung shines as a cold-blooded villain who thrives on challenges. The film's main highlight is the intense fight scene between Tony and Jackie-a stellar, heart-pounding moment that captivates from start to finish.

Kudos to the new generation of actors and actresses, particularly Ci Sha, whose compelling monologue and gripping action sequence with Tony Leung elevate the movie's tension to new heights. The fight scenes featuring Jackie against Lionel and Qiu Nan are also a treat, incorporating some of his signature moves from past films.

Overall, this stands out as a solid action film from Chinese directors, boasting strong writing and a coherent story. They would do well to prioritize quality over quantity, as too many movies suffer from weak narratives or poor scripting.
label: figurative

text: Too much plot armor Lets face the facts, the ideia behind this movie was great and had everything to be a 10/10. To begging with, the characters had no development, they are dropped out of nothing. We had no idea who those people were, their life story and the reason they commited to the mission. In another topic, there was way too much plot armour, most of the characters would die if the movie was realistic. The violent nature of the dinosaurs was wasted, as only 4 of the 11 characters were killed. The death of more characters would have enhanced this nature and made the film more interesting. One last thing to point is the lack of violence. The violence that one would expect from homicidal dinosaurs is not present. The characters' constant escape makes the dinosaurs seem slow and stupid. The deaths of the less trained characters would be expected, such as Isabella, Xavier, Nina, Reuban and Martin. The deaths would also have to be more violent and brutal. On the brigth side, the plot itself was great and the visuals were stunning.

text:
Lowdown: Authentic, Relevant, and Rooted in Tulsa Lowdown is one of the most relevant shows to come out in a long time. It is not a direct retelling of Tulsa history, but it draws loosely on stories connected to the Brady family and their ties to the Ku Klux Klan and the Tulsa Race Massacre. The series uses that backdrop as inspiration rather than strict history, and so far it has managed to capture a lot of subtle details that feel true to Tulsa.

What makes it stand out is the authenticity. From the look and feel of the city to the number of local extras involved, it shows a real care for getting Tulsa right. This is a refreshing change compared to shows like Tulsa King, where Taylor Sheridan not only got many things wrong about Tulsa but also chose not to film here at all.

Some critics have written it off as simply political, but that misses the point. This is not about pushing an agenda. It is a story that pulls from Tulsa's past while creating something new, and it is all the more powerful for it.

Even with only two episodes released, it is already clear that Lowdown has the potential to be essential viewing.
label: literal

text:
It won't replace the cartoon, but it's worth seeing! I wasn't expecting much from this movie. Although I admit I like Jim Carrey and the Grinch cartoon, I figured putting them together would be a disaster.

It wasn't. The movie is different enough from the cartoon that it's interesting to watch, and I wasn't constantly comparing the two. Anthony Hopkins is no Boris Karloff, but with the extended plot the movie doesn't rely on the narrator NEARLY as much as the cartoon did. (Not that Hopkins was really bad, it's just that Karloff was that much better.)

text:
Lighthearted mystery dramedy Going on the introduction: the good place (which I watched) this is less of a comedy and more of a soapy show with some comedic situations, wrapped in a mystery set-up.

A necklace was stolen and Ted Dansons's character is hired by a private eye to infiltrate a senios residence.

While touching on dementia, we barely got to see any of it. What really is behind the doors of 'memory care'?

I work with people who suffer from different types of dementia and I don't feel this series was about dementia at all.

Yes, the late wife of our main protagonist died of Alzheimer's, and there was the woman who started to suffer from a form of dementia, but there was little from there.

It looked more like an all-in hotel for seniors.

The premise is fun. The series was fun. But in my opinion it's not comparable to The good place.

It's going to the finale to finally have Danson bond with his daughter and his handler to appreciate him and also the friend he made to get over the spying.

I had fun watching it, I don't mind if there wouldn't be a new season. Netflix has many other shows deserving of continuation.

text:
Addictive but also anowing The show is addictive and great for binge watching. I would give it an eight if not for the annoying parts. Some small but important differences I believe could have added a lot more quality to the show. Stana Katic delivers a stunning performance and she is driver of the show.

This being said, I will necessarily have to go to the spoilers, so stop reading if you want to be spared.

The husband is an asshole even though he is not portrayed that way. His wife whom he clearly loved goes missing and after six years he has a new wife that clearly has been there for quite some years, because she treats her stepson like her son and the kid clearly sees her as her mom and even dismisses his dead mom (also weird because any child would still hang to the victim mom whom everyone assumes is dead - even dough body was never found). The husband reacts in a positive way and saves her once he learns she is alive. After that, I mean, he reencounters the wife he loved so much and whose grave he would visit with feelings attached. He is married to another (too soon in my opinion but that can happen), still has feelings for after all not dead wife, but leaves her to bear with the trauma by herself. Yes he struggles with the feeling, but keeps on going home to his new wife and, again, leaves his also wife (no divorce happened) who clearly needed his help the most to deal with all that happened to her by herself, feeling abandoned by his husband. He does help with the investigation, but man that is so not enough! And he is a crap detective. Should he have left his more current wife? Well, I believe he should have, if only to have space to figure out whom he loves the most at the moment, make his choice and also to make himself available to his first (and also current) wife who went through hell.

Oh, but she came out differently. Is that a shock?? Of course she has! And she is constantly being judged by that, left alone to deal with her demons (minus the FBI's psychologist), abandoned by her husband and her child whom is really rude to her (because his mum was tortured for 6 years?? This would never happen in real life).

In mids of all, she hangs on, is able to create a bond with her son. While the current 2nd wife becomes (understandably i must add on her behalf) more and more obnoxious.

And the idiot husband of both feels betrayed by 1st wife because she is unfairly being charged by the system whom has already failed her so much and can't face the fact of being again incarcerated because she has been for 6 years while under tortured. The husband only feels betrayed and goes on to becoming against his 1st and still current wife, to the point of physically abusing her when both are fighting to save their son.

And after all this? She is the one who apologises and says he is better off with current new wife. That is it for him. Get away free card. He doesn't even apologise for having been utterly stupid and unfair most of the time.

And they all become friends. What an idiot ending. And has a women, it makes me angry how easily the man gets off the hook.

text: Is the relationship between parents and three teens realistic? Where Ted Danson is involved in dialogue with others at the facility or with his investigation boss, or even with a very truthful scene with his daughter, I enjoyed the show immensely. However, I was shocked at the relationship between his daughter, her husband and the kids. It's unrealistic (paying for learning about a kid's day???) the kids are rude, the parents eat dinner alone, and every time I watch these scenes, I feel uncomfortable and think, "Come on. Surely you can do better than this?" Perhaps in Season two, the relationship between parents and three teen boys will come to a head and eventually (or suddenly) improve, In an otherwise completely enjoyable show, with good humour, poignancy and truth, I was disappointed. I hope I'm not disappointed next season, with a teen/parent turnaround.

text:
Melodramatic Pap Magnificent Obsession is an overly melodramatic soap opera blessed with some good actors who cannot rise above the script. If you listen to this movie without watching the picture, it is easy to hear the horrible music, the overly dramatic phrasing, and the silly dialogue. Everything is just too earnest.

What really makes this film as loser though is the premise upon which the story is constructed--that everyone has a destiny. And that you cannot fulfill that destiny unless you help others without acknowledgement.

Helping others without extracting credit for it is a noble aim. Everyone should aspire to it. But by saying that you will get what you want via your destiny if you follow this noble path, it undercuts the message, by rewarding the giver. Also, the concept of destiny, as expressed in Christian terms in the film, is nothing more than mumbo jumbo. Too bad they didn't advocate giving for the sake of doing something nice for someone. Or solely because it is the right thing to do.

For those who think of Rock Hudson only in terms of his partnerships with Doris Day, a film like Magnificent Obsession might be an eye opener. But he played plenty of meatier roles with better scripts, e.g. Giant.
label: literal

text:
The perfect blend of comedy and horror Having not seen the original movie and only tidbits of the trailer, I didn't really know what to expect when walking into the cinema this evening. Someone described the movie as 'The Goonies' meets 'A Nightmare on Elm Street' - this turned out to be an extremely accurate description!

The opening scene seems to suggest that the movie will be very dark, yet these expectations are quickly dispersed as the horror is undercut by comedy. This happens repeatedly throughout the film: and it works. My friends and I (as well as the entire packed cinema) found ourselves gasping at scenes of sheer terror, then only moments later laughing hysterically at the banter between the main characters.

I would say that this is not a film for the faint of heart, yet I think even those individuals would find themselves enjoying 'It'. If not for the horror, then certainly for the comedy and camaraderie. It's as if this is a movie within a movie: a mix of a high-school-problems/coming-of-age movie and a horror. A brilliant two-for-one if you ask me!

Great acting from all of the cast as well as excellent writing make this movie a must watch!
label: literal

text:
Like A B-Movie Well, just got done watching this one last night, and I must say that I was greatly disappointed. Foreign films, like any other, are hit and miss Â– and this one was definitely a miss. The only truly redeeming quality was the cinematography and visuals, which were good, but nothing spectacular.

Ironically, the most disappointed aspect of Brotherhood of the Wolf ("BotW") were the action scenes, which seem to be garnering praise from just about everyone on these review sites. Without question, the most important part of an action scene is the choreography, whether it be hand-to-hand combat or a car chase. The fights in BotW can be categorized as follows: (1) hand-to-hand conflicts between humans; and (2) weapon battles between humans and the beast.

With regards to the former type of action, this film is abhorrent. The action choreography is so lazy and unoriginal that I am truly perplexed why anyone would enjoy it to any significant degree. Turn on any B-flick or made-for-TV action movie and you'll see a comparable quality of action. Quite frankly, I could have pulled off most of the moves in this one: block a punch, kick the guy; block a punch, punch a guy; etc. Post-production need only add some slow-mo and sound effects, and I'd be the next French superstar. Anyone who considers the hand-to-hand choreography in BotW to be great should seriously consider upgrading their movie standards to include some of the films from East Asia (notably Fist of Legend, Tom Yum Goong, Sha Po Lang, So Close, and Azumi). Basically, BotW doesn't hold a candle to any of those films in terms of hand-to-hand combat choreography. In fact, BotW is barely average. The frequent references to the "great action" in this film is probably due to nothing more than the characters looking cool and stylish, and is not an accurate description of the action itself.

With regards to the latter type of action (between humans and the beast), the choreography is just okay. At one point, the characters had the beast trapped, but acted too slowly to kill it. Also, the beast itself did nothing noteworthy. You'd figure that such a killing machine would have some awesome attacks Â– but you would be very, very wrong.

With regards to acting, the lead character comes off as a pompous pretty boy who is so full of himself that he's almost impossible to like. The Indian was better, but lacked any character development whatsoever. The townspeople are really stupid in this one. Like morons, they keep killing dozens of regular wolves when there is no way in hell a wolf could be behind the murders. The dialogue is uninteresting and pointless to the main storyline.

Finally, the true villain of the film exposes the storyline as nothing more than an excessively long and mediocre propaganda piece for philosophical naturalism that lacks any notable entertainment value.
label: figurative

text: Used to be 10 stars but has gone WAY down hill after season 13 This show used to be in my top 5 must not miss shows every week until season 14. I honestly don't know what they were thinking when they forced Bishop & Kasie on us. Those 2 have ruined the show for me. I can tolerate the other 2 newbies, Torres & Sloane, to a point, but they too aren't the best fit either. It was great to bring back Ziva this season as an attempt to keep us interested, but it's a little too late because the damage has already been done the last few seasons. I can no longer watch without cringing every time Bishop & Kasie are on the screen because they just don't belong on this show. So many other loyal fans have said the same things & it amazes me they haven't replaced these horrible characters yet, but maybe the plan is to end the show, so they figure why bother writing in better characters. Anyway, I just want to say how much I truly enjoyed every season up to 13. I put up with most of season 14 only because I love Jennifer Esposito & wanted to see where that was going, but the minute they forced that out of nowhere relationship Bishop had onto us & then had her go all crazy & murder that guy it made me sick to my stomach to watch after that. I actually forced myself to keep watching just because I kept thinking things would change & that maybe Bishop would get fired for what she did or get demoted, since that's what it seemed was going to happen, except nothing happened. I guess the writers just gave up trying after that. I finally stopped watching it weekly after Kasie joined the team, though because she's the absolute worst fit of any character that's ever been on the show & I just couldn't stomach watching it after that. Last month I went back to try & catch up before this new season started by trying to skip through the parts when she came on & parts where it was just Bishop, too, but it's just not worth the trouble, so I am officially done watching for good now. It's such a shame how they made it so many seasons picking good characters that fit well with each other & with Gibbs, but then they just stopped trying after season 13. Thanks for 13 great seasons at least.
label: literal

text:
I hoped that it would be better I came into this movie expecting the type of entertaining lowish budget actions movies that have come out in the last decade. Visceral and hard-hitting...and came away disappointed.

There's tons of action, and the cinematography and acting is competent...but far too many of the action scenes are just too unrealistic. The guy blocks a heavy machine gun's bullets with a mining pan that he holds in his hands like it's Captain America's shield...I actually went back thinking that he picked up a tank hatch or something...but no a thin piece of steel is stopping bullets. Far too many of the action scenes rely on these outlandish premises. It's not that Sisu is a skilled and determined soldier seeking bloody revenge...he's a freakin' super hero.

It does feel like those sequences were done to look impressive, without actual thought to making them believable. Which undermines the entire film, and the premise that he's just gutting it through. This movie would have been so much better if they grounded it a lot more. Why not have him come up for a breath instead of literally sucking the air out of gaping neck wound? Why not have him dive for cover instead of tanking HMG rounds? There's just so many baffling decisions that take away from the movie that the good scenes (and there are several) really made me wonder why there couldn't have been more of those type of sequences instead.

Most action movies are not realistic...but the best avoid disrupting the suspension of disbelief. In this case the movie more-or-less jumps the shark from the first major action sequence, and never really gets back in the groove.

An interesting, yet wasted premise...I don't regret watching it, it was fairly entertaining, but I'll probably never watch it again.
label: literal

text:
Spellbinding, Unique Show which deserves to be watched in it's own right!!!! I admit to being confused as to why SOOOO many folk are talking about Peaky Blinders this is The House of Guiness, it is not Peaky Blinders, just because it is a period drama. Why are you not saying it is not like Rogue Heroes, did you all compare Rogue Heroes to Peaky Blinders. There is an essence running through the shows of Steven Knight that is recognisable, the history, the amazing image, the rythm of the show where the incredible use of music makes you ride through it as if you are riding a wave. But that is it, this is a completely different story, time, place and characters to his other shows and if it was a repeat of Peaky Blinders you would all be shouting how boring and lazy Knight is for repeating his hit show within a different story and setting.

Now lets get away from his previous work and look at this FANTASTIC show in it's own right because it absolutely deserves it. I loved it, my Mam loved it and we are desperately waiting for Season2. We watched it over 2 nights and we were wired with energy each night after watching it made settling to go to sleep rather difficult and had to watch TV/read to calm down our brains from the excietment. Everything in this show is top notch, from the whole look of it, costumes, script (which had some incredibly funny lines in it) and the acting. James Norton had a stance and command to him that you could so easily spot him in a crowd just by the way he was standing. This alone gave us so much information about him and his character without much dialogue in the first few minutes of episode1 and lets agree that this episode started with a bang! The funeral scenes were so impactful and gave so much information in a short space of time about this family. This show moved, there was no 'gazing out the window' moments as my Mam calls them, when people seem to slow EVERYTHING down SOOO much to try to give impact or mood, no whispering or boring moments. The show went on waves and the music represented the rythm& energy of the scene and it made you go on a fantastic ride along with the characters. Here I will compare, but to Rogue Heroes not Peaky Blinders, they too have the music take you along with them and demonstrate the energy of the story, something I have never seen anybody else other than Knight use in this way. I know some don't like modern music in a period drama but they are getting a feeling that modern us can relate to, rap, hip hop, contemporary music and comparing it to how these folk were feeling back in the day, showing how we are not so different to them and they were not quite so stuck up and stiff as most of us imagine the rich to have been. I liked the debauchery and the swearing and the real people with their father looming over and remaining in control even year and more after his death. I didn't always like the characters but just as I was starting to get irritated by their entitlement a more human side of them appears and I start to like them again. I could go on more, a lot more about the love of this show but I will spare you all that. I do want to beg those of you who have not watched it yet to FORGET what Knight has done in the past, he is not remaking past shows but coming up with new excieting and original NEW shows to keep us engaged and excieted. If you enjoyed Peaky Blinders so much that you want to see it again then go and rewatch the show again from the beginning and let The House of Guinness stand alone as an incredible piece of work in it's own right!!!
label: literal

text:
I'm from Mentor Ohio and it's about time! I'm from Mentir Ohio, the home of Garfield. His house a museum and many roads are named after him. A city park is named for him as well as schools. I heard my whole life about him yet never has there been any real story written about him.

It's about time.

The cast is frigging outstanding! The acting superb! They instill a bit of humor in things nicely. The writing and directing superb as well.

At minimum it's worth watching for its historical value.. at best it's a great saga and recollection of a story told too late for everyone. This was long overdue! An assassinated president barely gets a blurb of notice.

I'm glad I came from a place who did honor him as president and mourned his death. Many have never given him a thought!
label: literal

text: Unforgettable Ride! In the shadow of America's opulent excess, Death by Lightning strikes like a bolt from the blue, transforming the forgotten tragedy of James Garfield's assassination into a pulse-pounding saga of ambition, betrayal, and fleeting glory. David Franzoni's script crackles with authenticity, blending meticulous historical detail with taut, modern suspense-think The Assassination of Jesse James meets Succession's cutthroat boardrooms, but set against the gaslit grandeur of 1881 Washington. Matthew Macfadyen is magnetic as the scheming Charles Guiteau, his oily charm masking a descent into delusion that's equal parts chilling and heartbreaking. Opposite him, Michael Shannon's Garfield simmers with quiet fire, a reformer whose idealism clashes against the era's corrupt undercurrents in scenes that linger like thunder. The ensemble shines too-Gillian Jacobs brings fierce wit to Lucretia Garfield, while the production design (those lavish costumes! Those shadowy saloons!) immerses you utterly. At just eight episodes, it never drags, building to a finale that's as devastating as it is inevitable. If you crave smart, stylish history that hits harder than a headline, this is your must-watch. Lightning indeed-fast, fierce, unforgettable.
label: figurative

text: For Dimwits Only Excellent film for those completely ignorant in U. S. military readiness and response. Given Kathryn's previous work on "The Hurt Locker", this is unsurprising. The unrealistic emotionalism of the primary (military) characters approaches haminess to a degree not seen since Shatner fought an alien in 1966. Soldiers and Airmen in these roles, and in their leadership chain, would remain on task with little to no emotion through the entire process. ADDITIONALLY, the U. S. has a multi-tiered ABM response in place on both water and on land, where multiple "kill" vehicles would be launched in response to such a threat. Purporting a singular ABM launch as the only response is preposterous. 4/10.

text:
a 9.2....eh...come again? I had never heard of this show until a couple of weeks ago when someone started raving about it at a party. Soon others joined him in the glorification of the, what soon got to be called, 'show of the century'. I must say, I was intrigued.

I was even more intrigued by the big fat 9.2 this show gets here on IMDb. I mean, that was a first for me.

I found the complete first season on Usenet and started to watch anxiously as soon as the first episodes hit my harddrive.

I watched....and watched some more. Suddenly I woke up from the incredible loud hiss of my headphones which tend to make this sound after being inactive for too long to warn its owner its batteries are being sucked dry. I had fallen asleep like a baby. Talk about firsts.

I must have been tired I thought to myself so the next day I watched another episode and another one the day after that, etc etc. I got to about 5 of them.

Is it just me? (yes, apparently) or is there really nothing happening in this series which is even slightly compelling? It must be just me, all I see is just another episode of As the World Turns only this time using every goddamn mafia-clichÃ© in the book.

The characters are SÃ³ clichÃ© that it's simply impossible to find any of them likable (or even slightly interesting) and because of the whole mob-setting, I'm expecting a suspenseful watch only to be disappointed by a soap-with-the-f-word which to my surprise is dragged out over 7 seasons???!!

For a completely depleted theme, which to me the mafia had become after regretfully seeing 'Analyse This', to resurrect in a series where humor is lacking, originality is exiled and suspense has been replaced by Golden Girls caliber drama to be voted a 9.2 is truly beyond me.

Was the voting only open to teenagers who never saw the classics?

text:
Run for your life, criminal! Vintage 80's, Arnie doing what he does best; undoubtedly now a cult classic, "The Running Man" hits you with nostalgia and awe..., somewhat lame and crude compared to today's standards, particularly with the visuals and special effects, it is a film very much etched in the 80's and a product of its time.

Full of wall to wall action, fights and crude violence, the film doesn't give you a moment to breathe, it picks up the pace immediately and doesn't stop until the credits roll, and that is exactly how an action film should be!

"The Running Man" doesn't tell an intellectual and thought provoking story, not at all, this is an action flick designed for adrenaline junkies from a certain age, and it truly delivers what it promises.

A cool film that hasn't particularly aged well, but in my opinion the fact that it hasn't aged too well simply adds to its charm and appeal.

text:
So much talent wasted One of the things you can depend on in the world of television is that, if a particular show succeeds, there will be multiple attempts to copy it in the hope that it's the formula that makes it a success. Unfortunately, formulas don't work by themselves, they need good writing. The mockumentary formula that made The Office, Parks & Recreation, and Abbott Elementary succeed falls flat on its face here thanks to abysmal writing.

When I first saw the cast list, I was looking forward to this show being released. But then I watched a trailer and was left shaking my head.

I love many of the actors in St. Denis Medical, but I can't believe they signed up for this after seeing any of the scripts. Or maybe they didn't read any and it was blind trust on their part. At any rate, they have no chance of saving this mess thanks to the clunky writing and ham-fisted directing. The fact that some viewers like this disaster is actually scary.

text:
Giggling With Jim Carrey's 'Grinch'. Howard's 'How the Grinch Stole Christmas' is a delightful family flick that both adults and children can enjoy (mostly with each other). It is basically an adaptation of the famous children's books and what the audience gets is a pleasant Christmas treat. Price's screenplay is brilliant as he cleverly manages to include some adult humour.

The world of Whoville is beautifully constructed and created, full of colour, life, energy and spirit. The vivacious characters are full of positive energy and while it is over the top, it is all done within the context and none of it appears out of place. The CGI team and makeup crew deserve full credit for making the characters and settings so lifelike, bringing out a lot of detail and appearing authentic. The set designs are stunning and the cinematography is just as energetic as the characters.

Child actress Taylor Momsen is absolutely. The cute dog also turns in a fine performance. Jeffrey Tambor, a very sexy Christine Baranski, Bill Irwin and Molly Shannon are first rate. However, what would 'How the Grinch Stole Christmas' be without Jim Carrey? Carrey is simply fantastic as he immerses himself entirely into the character. It's a role that has Jim Carrey written all over it. The actor has immortalized the Grinch on screen.

The movie itself is not an exact 100% adaptation of the book as there are a few changes. The romance between the Grinch and Martha May could have been better developed. Other than the actors mentioned above, the rest of the cast hardly have anything to do than make fleeting appearances. Yet, 'How the Grinch Stole Christmas' is a charming little Christmas family film that is dazzling to look at and hugely enjoyable with the whole family.

text: Not John Hughes' best, but not bad, in fact it is quite entertaining I do not think Weird Science is John Hughes' best film, but it is a decent enough film that did entertain me. It is too short however, and the humour occasionally is rather crass. However, I loved the concept, it was original and I think it worked rather well. The film looks good too, the scenery and cinematography are typical Hughes which is a good thing in itself, while the soundtrack is cool. While the humour is crass, there are some funny moments and some inspired wit in the script, while the pacing and direction are fine. The acting is good enough as well. Anthony Michael Hall Ilan Mitchell-Smith are likable leads, while Bill Paxton gives the best performance and Kelly LeBrock is smouldering. Also look out for Robert Downey Jnr in this. Overall, not bad, not amazing but it entertains. 7/10 Bethany Cox
