text:
The story is far fetched, but the movie is magnificent indeed. In the '50s the films of Douglas Sirk were highly appreciated by women and not held in very high esteem by critics (they regarded his films as weepies).

Today it is the other way around. Today critics see the subtle criticism on the hypocrisy of the 50's consumer society through the surface of the amazing technicolor images. This is especially evident in a film like "All that heaven allows" (1955).

"Magnificent obsession" was made one year earlier, with the same lead actors (Rock Hudson and Jane Wyman). More important is that this film is not so much on the level of society as a whole but much more on the individual level. A conceited millionaire who becomes righteous through his love for a blind woman.

This film has relations with "The game" (1997, David Fincher, spoiled millionaire) and "City lights" (1931, Charlie Chaplin, blind girl). From the book (1929, Lloyd C. Douglas) it also has an unmistakable christian undertone. Its theme is derived from the gospel of St Matthew 6:1-4. Good deeds have te be performed in silence.

text:
One of the best! The Office is definitely one of the best sitcoms out there. How many times have I watched it! And yet I still always laugh and find new jokes I missed before. I still get upset when it is over and already wonder when will I start again.

The humor is wonderful. The characters are a great creation. All of them! They all bring something special to the show. Of course Michael Scott is a special one. And when it comes to Dwight Shrute I think he is one of the best in sitcom history. We also get some romance with Pam and Jim or Dwight and Angela.

The actors are great at their performing and on time humor. When we start the characters don't seem to have so much depth. But with time we start seeing how sweet Michael and Dwight are. All the little moments when we see Michael be in pain make us love him more and more. He is a guy who wants not only to be loved but to love. This is how he treats his office as his best friends or children.

And the great thing is that the show is on high level until it's very end. Even after Michael Scott leaves. Many say that it went down after, but even if it did it wasn't that far down. It still brought us a lot and I am glad they made those seasons. I liked all characters, except for Nellie and that was only for the short period of time when she was a manager. Now that was a disaster idea but they luckily saved it within a few episodes. And the end... The last episodes of the show are so emotional! They really made a great and successful effort to give the amazing show the ending it deserves. And I wish it was still going on...

text:
Masterpiece "Better Call Saul is one of the most outstanding TV series of recent years. This prequel to "Breaking Bad" follows the adventures of neighbourhood lawyer Jimmy McGill (played amazingly by Bob Odenkirk) as he transforms into the famous character of Saul Goodman.

What makes Better Call Saul so exceptional is its ability to tell a complex and exciting story without relying on constant drama or gratuitous shock. Instead, the series focuses on creating complex characters and the evolution of their relationships, and each episode is a little narrative gem.

In addition, the production of the series is impressive, with stunning set designs and photography, as well as an impeccably selected soundtrack. Each episode is a visual and technical masterpiece in its own right.

Overall, Better Call Saul is a series not to be missed. It's smart, funny and exciting, and it's full of interesting characters and plots.
label: figurative

text:
Wig and the casting were perfection Palm Royale captures the essence of the late 60s, with every element from cinematography to the soundtrack hitting just the right notes. The plot is engaging, offering a fun twist on dark comedy without diving too deep into heavy or intense plot twists/ so an easy to watch series if you don't want too much intensity. .

Kristen Wiig's playing Maxine is definitely the highlight. She embodies her character with a blend of vulnerability, gullible, hopeless romantic who everyone wants to tear to shreds. The character has this admirable bulletproof resilience that's captivating to watch. It's like Maxine is in a constant boxing match, taking hit after hit.

Ricky Martin delivers a surprisingly charming performance. His character has this smooth, effortless way of gliding through scenes that makes him a delight to watch.

The ensemble cast brings their characters to life with distinct, memorable qualities. Their on-screen chemistry adds a layer of authenticity and enjoyment to the series.

The one exception in casting/capability is, Mitsy, played by Kiera gerber (Cindy Crawford daughter). She justdidn't quite hit the mark for me. Her performance felt a bit wooden, and she struggled to match the depth and nuance of Wiig's experience, appearing slightly out of her element in this role. I get it / first big break. But I don't think this was the right fit for her.

Allison Janney, as Evelyn, is outstanding. She brings strength and presence to her role, earning every bit of applause for her performance.

"Palm Royale is a truly fun to watch, mixing great acting with a story that's entertaining and randomly inspiring.

Maxine's unyielding spirit, in particular, is a powerful draw, making the series a standout. It's almost a thing of the past,,, big risk, big reward.

It's a perfect mix of 60s flair and timeless themes, definitely worth your rime.
label: figurative

text:
Quite an Engrossing Series It's off to a roaring season 1. You wanted it not to end but it did in an explosive way. This is the way that movies in this genre should be made.

It was such an enjoyable movie experience, so life-like because what's in the movie could happen in real life. What made it more interesting is it's told in the context of events that we're familiar with in recent years such as Brexit, the festering war in Ukraine, the assassination of bin Laden.

The cast is splendid. But, like any other political drama worth its salt, there are actors and there are actors. Keri Russell, who's also executive producer, is amazing here. There's never a dull moment with her. She portrays an intelligent, feisty and pragmatic diplomat. Her screen presence is scintillating. The fact that she's now older with lines on her once pretty face makes her so much more credible in her role.

The other actor that strikes me is Ali Ahn. She's great here, too. I like how she handles her scenes with Ato Essandoh.

Perhaps, like many others like me, I can't wait for season 2 to roll. As Rufus Sewell's character intones: diplomacy doesn't work until it does. Right on.

So far, with two episodes released, it is a great time to write a review filled with expectations and hopes.. and no spoilers!

The topic of "CC" (Collective Consciousness) is a favorite of mine.. so, it is my hope that this VERY high-concept show has decided to leave the interesting exploration of such ideas out of the introductory episodes. While intriguing and inviting with a great foundation for worldbuilding, it hasn't had time to offer anything else.

It is my hope that it does not just go into a "romantic" or individual-centric direction.. but expands and surprise with unexplored ideas and unexpected developments, and hopefully, weighty consequences. The last thing I want for it, would be for it to be forgettable.. and to not be able to recommend it once it is done.

The cast was obviously amazing. I loved all 5 of horsemans altogether - definitely refreshing. Amazing to see so many women and I just adored the little feminist comment.

He gave an acceptable performance in "MO", but it certainly wasn't one of his best. With some shame, I have to admit that if it had not been for the mere fact that Rock Hudson WAS in this film, I wouldn't have stopped and watched the whole thing. I, as you don't know am a female, and there's something about Rock with no shirt on that attracts me. (laughs) Jane Wyman was, well, lets say believable- at times. Sure she stopped after bumping into things and felt her way around rooms with her fingertips, but when Merrick, (Rock Hudson) spoke to her she would often look right at him, also her eyes were straight ahead and she'd move them around often in the same direction as she was going. It would have been better if she worked on this a little more.  Certainly though, being only 16, but an AVID classic fan, I don't know everything, but I try to notice the little things.  So my advice to people out there- if your a Rock Hudson fan as I am, rent it, when he's scrubbing up for "her operation" near the end, and-oops! has no shirt on..well thats theatre gold!! thanks for the memory. erin

text:
Good visuals and tension let down by its script What's up people? Stop reviewing those found-footage tapes you've magically stumbled across and check out my review of Shelby Oaks.

I was excited for this one as it's the directorial debut of Chris Stuckmann, it's a film I backed through crowdfunding and my name is on the special edition poster alongside 15,000 other backers but was it money well spent?

Shelby Oaks is a found-footage spiritual horror. When a group of kids goes missing, all of their bodies except Riley's are found. Riley's sister Mia obtains tapes from the incident, becomes convinced Riley is still alive and takes matters into her own hands.

First off, Shelby Oaks looks like a legit Hollywood film. So, money well spent in that department. What worked for me was the tension built through camera angles, set locations and good direction. What didn't work quite as well was the script. There were too many conveniences and character decisions that didn't add up. The ending also felt anticlimactic, leaning heavily on the spiritual horror angle seemingly for the sake of it.

Overall, Shelby Oaks is an okay horror movie with decent visuals and tension but lacking in a solid story. Ultimately, I'm happy to have contributed towards this project and I'm excited that Chris Stuckmann is officially on his Hollywood directing journey. I'm look forward to what's next!

text:
Very solid show! This spin-off of "Law & Order" is extremely solid and every episode is always a pleasure to watch.

The show is about a new elite squad of NYPD detectives who investigate sexually oriented crimes. So you would kind of expect that ever episode would be the same; someone gets raped and the SVU is send out to solve it. This however is not the case, every episode is extremely original. Kudos to that! OK so maybe the stories are pretty far fetched at times but that doesn't take away any of the quality of the show.

Only real complaint I have about the series is that it misses a good solid main character. "Law & Order" had Lennie Briscoe (Jerry Orbach) and "Law & Order: Criminal Intent" has Robert Goren (Vincent D'Onofrio) but "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" doesn't have a good solid leading character. Neither Elliot Stabler (Christopher Meloni) or Olivia Benson (Mariska Hargitay) are interesting enough. Best characters are the ones that always play the smaller roles such as; Capt. Donald Cragen (Dann Florek), John Munch (Richard Belzer, that guy has got style! Hard to believe he is well over 60 years old already.) and Odafin "Fin" Tutuola (Ice-T). At first I didn't really liked Ice-T in this, I don't know for some reason he seemed nervous about acting in this to me but he now often gives away a very solid performance. The B.D. Wong character Dr. George Huang is a bit of a weird one to me, he is an all knowing character that truly knows everything and always has an answer and an opinion ready. He feels like a kind of unrealistic character to me, even though I really always have liked B.D. Wong as an actor. I'm also glad Alexandra Cabot (Stephanie March) got replaced by ADA Casey Novak (Diane Neal), she is a way better character!

The show is very likable to watch. The guest appearances are like in all "Law & Order" series, always top-class and the fact that the show lacks a good main character doesn't take away any of the quality of the show.

8/10

http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

text:
Entertaining fluff I had doubts at first about Palm Royale, which follows an ethically challenged beauty queen desperate to break into high society. At first, she just seemed awful, as did most of the other people, and her dream seemed so petty and dumb. The movie was more appealing for its set design and campy acting than anything else.

But the series surprised me, giving increasing depth to the protagonist and offering just a little bit of complexity to it all.

The series also gets crazier and crazier with the twists and turns as it goes along, reaching a level of over-the-top goofiness by the end that's just lots of fun.

I did feel the cliffhanger at the end was too dark for the series, and I hope they quickly clear away the rubble they created with that when season two begins. But overall, this is terrific fun and well worth watching.
label: literal

text:
Kim Wexler: the Perfect Woman and the Antithesis of Skylar White Not only is Rhea Seehorn, who plays Kim, extremely pretty, but the character is rich and deep in ways every person should aspire to be. In short, Kim Wexler is the polar opposite and the very antithesis of Skylar White.

Kim, alone, is enough to not only watch Better Call Saul, but to rate it a 10.

The thing is, that BEYOND the 'perfect woman' that is Kim, it isn't only she who makes up the wonderful tapestry of interwoven majesty that is this series. As if her character were not enough to convince you of this series' greatness, on top of it, you have a myriad of characters almost as fabulous and just as engaging. To not list them all would be an insult; and yet to list them all would be an exercise in futility. Not only is every major character written and directed as only the geniuses who brought us Breaking Bad could write and direct them, but they are portrayed fabulously by everyone onscreen. EVEN the extras and lesser-used characters are standouts.

Now, Better call Saul moves at a pace that is not for everyone. The story progresses somewhat more slowly than other series/shows. The plus side is that it gives you time to enjoy each moment of this subtle (not slap-you-in-the-face, willy-nilly), but delightfully presented jewel of a look into the time before the monumentally amazing story of Breaking Bad took place.

I can't say it enough: watch it. If you watched some and thought it was not for you, watch it again. You'll thank me.
label: literal

text:
What a load of miserable gits inhabit these reviews! I appreciate people have very different tastes - we like different things. But some of these comments (as is often the case online) cross the line from expressing a point of view to being downright aggressive and cruel (a bit like the title of this review)! People are on the receiving end of your reviews, so be kind!

As for this show, I thought it was excellent entertainment. And that's what it is meant to be: entertainment. It's not history. It's not a drama doc. It's not a statement of Britain's position in international information gathering.

To appreciate this show, I think you need to understand irony, which runs deep in this comedic spy caper. It's Brits laughing at ourselves. It's Brits poking fun at the establishment. It's Brits enjoying seeing the "underdog" triumph over the smug, privileged and powerful. It's all that and more.

So, sit back, enjoy excellent acting, a tight script with so many jokes coming so fast that you might miss them, and something that offers a typically British counterpoint to the glossy "24", "The Americans" et al spy genre that tends to originate in the USA (not that I'm against them, they have their place too).

For me, it lost 2 stars because I felt the final episode was rather predictable and more improbable than the show deserved.

text: Christmas Vacation If there ever was someone who understood the effects of Murphy's Law it's the always-maligned Clark Griswold who just wanted the perfect family Christmas and instead is leveled with one disaster after another. If Clark isn't battle scarred from putting up Christmas lights, he's contending with problems with the tree. Bickering relatives, long-awaited bonus(which doesn't turn out to be what Clark was hoping for so he could pay for a new pool), Cousin Eddie, getting locked in the attic while the family is gone(not to mention getting smacked in the face with the attic latter and falling out altogether while watching old family reels on the projector), an overcooked turkey, Cousin Eddie, a sled ride that goes terribly wrong..did I mention Cousin Eddie? With plenty of Chevy Chase zingers(his demand at the end that no one leaves when all is not well, what he'd like to tell his (insert insults here) boss who screwed him over regarding the late "bonus", and especially his comments about Eddie), slapstick, and one hell of a supporting cast, "National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation" stands the test of time as a real comedy Christmas classic worth revisiting every single year. The mayhem brought on by one nightmarish scenario after another(the tree going up in flames thanks to Uncle Lewis' cigar, the cat getting "lit up" when Clark plugs in the lights, Eddie filling the Griswold sewer with "toxic s#it", a runaway squirrel causing the family to panic, etc.)provides plenty of chuckles. Before this film John Hughes was mainly putting out teenage fare, but afterward you'd have other Christmas slapstick comedies like HOME ALONE where destruction in a cartoony fashion would erupt on the unlucky. Probably the last great comedy Chase would be a part of; the next decade wasn't as kind as the 80s.

A comfort show that will leave you feeling warm and fuzzy It only took 3 episodes to have me hooked. This series definitely gives off a cozy, nostalgic, autumn feel that leaves you craving a pumpkin spice latte in all the best ways.

The show and it's characters are written in such an effortless, true-to-life and relatable way. I read a comment somewhere that said "this is a show about conversations" and I agree, but it's not in a boring sense whatsoever.

Gilmore Girls delves into every aspect of the human experience, and I now understand why people refer to this as a "comfort" show.

It's not afraid of showing and delving into its characters and their flaws, even that of the protagonist (which is a rarity to be found in many shows and movies made today).

Overall, this show will leave you feeling warm, fuzzy and oddly understood.

text:
Worst Jurassic Park/World by FAAAR Worst Jurassic Park by far. Absolutely terrible movie. Small very predictable spoilers included.

First off they give us no reason to like the characters at all. They are poorly written and you spend the first half of the movie wondering if they are the good guys or bad guys. This absolutely ruins the suspense or any scare factor because were not sure if were even supposed to like them. They introduce a character that is supposed to be a lazy know-nothing and then 10 minutes later they have this completely un-earned character development scene where suddenly we're supposed to respect him? It happens way too early in the movie and the one good thing he does hardly outlays all of his awful behavior prior to that. Scarlet Johansens character is only in it for money the whole time and is supposed to be this mercenary soldier person but when it comes down to it she can't hit the broad side of a barn with any weapon they give, or she's screaming for help.

The CGI is abundant and terribly done. There is a small cargo plane pulling 6g turns for no reason, it looks like a cartoon. It seems like they had no plan when shooting the scenes with the real actors. Often times they are acting in the wrong direction or not reacting to things happening on screen. I swear the CGI team has never even seen a boat before. All the of the boat scenes dont make sense. From the "crew" just running around randomly to the guy that understands english but only speaks french the whole movie, to the listing of the boat being completely inconsistent. The boat gets hit by a dinosaur at one point and none of the actors even move. It gets bumped on the hull and for some unexplained reason it then starts pluming thick black smoke from somewhere else unexplained. What was even damaged? Then with litteraly an entire ocean to escape in they decide to drive right into the sharp rocks?

There are weird things that happen seemingly for no reason, like needing to fire a rifle from the very exposed extended bow of the boat while being roped into it when they could have just fired from the safety of the deck. A guy in a facility where everyone is wearing tyvex suits and masks and eye protection chowing a snickers and dropping the wrapper on the ground, then it gets sucked into an intake vent on a door? Why the F is there an intake vent on door? And why is it on the ground?? Then that snickers wrapper causes the door to fail which then causes the entire security and computer system to fail, releasing all the dinosaurs. I mean come on. That is even lazier writing that "somehow Palpetine returned". Its like they think we're stupid.

There are literally only 8 types of dinosaurs in this movie. 8. And for some reason they all give up on eating everyone after like 2 minutes of trying.

This movie has more plot holes that ive ever seen in one movie. At one point a T-rex picks up and inflatable raft and crushes it, only to put it back down and it doesn't have any marks. Like not even a scratch, AND it's still perfectly inflated. Then they use the raft to PADDLE away slowly from it. AND IT JUST GIVES UP! What happened to T-Rex's being intelligent hunters like in the original trilogy?

There is ZERO continuity in this film. One character badly hurts his leg and needs a cane to walk then suddenly can carry a child and run? His limp completely disappears half way through the movie. Keep in mind this movie takes place over 2 days.

There is a scene where one character has a gun and runs out of ammo, then proceeds to act as if it is still loaded, then in the next scene the gun is gone!

There is a guy with his hand handcuffed to a brief case and suddenly the handcuff disappears when the other characters need to grab it. Like not even a broken chain or broken handcuff. Its just not there anymore.

Spoilers after this part: The main big bad dinosaur is basically a rip off of the rancor in Star Wars Return of the Jedi. And it also gives up after 2 minutes and seeing a flare. One of the characters sacrifices himself by leading the dino away with a flare, and get this, SWIMMING. He gets away SWIMMING... WITH A FLARE IN HIS HAND. HOW DOES HE NOT GET EATEN??? Then somehow he gets away and shoots another flare so he can be rescued, but the dino now suddenly doesnt care about flares?

In conclusion, it is a terrible movie. I want my 2 and a half hours back.
label: literal

text:
I mean, the next thing you know, you'll be wearing a bra on your head!... "Weird Science" is definitely one of the memorable movies from the 1980's, and it is without a doubt also one of the movies that instantly comes to mind when you think movies from the 1980's. Furthermore, it is a classic in its own right, and it is a movie that you can watch over and over again.

The story is about Gary (played by Anthony Michael Hall) and Wyatt (played by Ilan Mitchell-Smith), two high school students without any luck with the women and often at the end of the bullies shenanigans. After seeing a "Frankenstein" movie on late night TV, they decide to create their own ideal woman (played by Kelly LeBrock) on the computer. But when their creation takes physical form and becomes a real woman, the two teenagers find that their luck has changed and popularity is just around the bend.

When you watch "Weird Science" these days you are just amused with the graphics that were used in the movie back in the day. Sure, it was grand and impressive back then. And seeing that is a nostalgic trip back to the glorious 1980's.

It is a combination of the storyline, the characters and the cast ensemble that makes the movie stand out so nicely and work so well.

The cast list includes Kelly LeBrock which is very much the epitome of the 1980's for many men whom were young adults or adults during the 1980's. But it also has some other impressive appearances, for example Bill Paxton in the hilarious role of Chet, but also Robert Downey Jr. and Robert Rusler as the two high school bullies. Furthermore, there is also some nice appearances by Vernon Wells and Michael Berryman as two bad guys.

If you were watching movies during the 1980's, then chances are slim to none that you are not already familiar with this lovable movie. And on the off-chance that you aren't already familiar with "Weird Science", then do take the opportunity to sit down and watch it should you get the chance. This is a very enjoyable movie in every way.
label: literal

text: Sinners draws me back to the 'Sin'ema! I really enjoyed Sinners! Not a perfect movie but definitely a good one. It's giving "cult classic" vibes for me. We don't get a lot of original content nowadays that isn't already tied to a franchise or existing IP so thank you Ryan Coogler for creating something artful with a story of its own. Admittedly, the protagonist "Preacher Boy" sparked immediate comparisons for me to urban legend blues man archetypes like Robert Johnson but stands out in how this character's story is told. It feels personal. It feels inspired and I was along for the ride. For me, Sinners is the live action version of an Ernie Barnes painting, particularly "The Sugar Shack", and I am so here for bringing back such depictions of Black life and art. There is a powerfully moving juke joint scene that motivates the darker themes of the film while simultaneously shining in pushing both narrative and nostalgia. It weaves ancestry and anarchy masterfully. And it proves why we need more black creators in the supernatural horror genre! Michael B. Jordan is getting the well deserved attention for his performances but I would argue to say that this is an ensemble effort where everyone sunk their teeth into their respective roles. Final thought: If From Dusk Till Dawn, Idlewild, & Eve's Bayou had a one night stand they would conceive Twins called Smoke & Stacks.

text: Edgar for hire. 'The Running Man (2025)' is the first film directed by Edgar Wright that feels as though it would have not only been made, but been more or less the same without his involvement. It's basically what 'Ant-Man (2015)' would've been like if he didn't decide to leave over creative differences. That's not to say that the movie could've been directed by anyone, just that it could've been directed with anyone good. There's very little of the specific flair he's known for, even if it does pop up here and there, and there isn't the crystal clear clarity of vision that's arguably the most important asset he brings to a production. Still, none of this is to suggest that the film isn't a fairly fun blockbuster actioner. It's a very different flavour to the more overtly campy original, but it's still heightened and absurd and playing around with satirical elements that are as humorous as they are on-the-nose. It feels as though it would be the perfect framework to hang some extremely tight, fast-paced and satisfying set-pieces on, but the action is never anything more - or less - than simply sturdy. It's exciting enough, but it doesn't exactly blow you away with its freneticism, inventiveness or charm. That's a good way to describe the overall affair, actually. It's always just above perfectly serviceable, but rarely anything more. Its third act really struggles to tie everything together, feeling as though it tries to do too much and not enough all at once, and its quirky elements are too subdued to make a genuine lasting impression. It all feels fairly forgettable, despite its committed performances (including from Glen Powell, who plays every single moment as if he's seconds away from exploding due to the pure rage running through his veins, and Josh Brolin, who chews on a set of fake teeth that are permanently fashioned into a smarmy grin) and its confidently crafted and suitably grungy dystopian setting that serves as an apt environment for its propulsive carnage and ham-fisted theming. Its genuinely pretty entertaining for what it is, but it's also vaguely underwhelming. Its better than it could have been, sure, but it's also not quite as good as I'd hoped it would be when I first learned who was involved with it. It's a rock-solid version of a movie we've all seen before, but it's honestly nothing especially noteworthy. Although it has some really fun sequences, it eventually finds itself running out of steam.

text:
we need a reunion - badly! I just finished watching all seven seasons on Netflix, and at the end, it was like saying goodbye to an old friend.

This is just a wonderful series about a single mom Lorelai (Lauren Graham) and her daughter Rory (Alexis Biedel), as Rory goes through high school and Yale, and Lorelai has several romances and a couple of engagements, most notably with Luke (Scott-Gordon Patterson). I became very involved with Lorelai, Rory, Luke, Lane, Sookie, and everyone in Stars Hollow. And then there is Lorelai's on again/off again relationship with her mother (Kelly Bishop) and father (Edward Herrmann). I wanted to live in Stars Hollow, too.

My only problem with the show (and it's minor) is that as witty and sparkling and fast as the dialogue is, sometimes Lorelai's repartee is just too much. Also, although Rory and Lorelai had a wonderful relationship, sometimes I felt like they were too close -- Lorelai is going to have some real issues with Rory out in the world.

That's one reason why I want a reunion -- to see how everything panned out with Rory, Lorelai, and Luke.

I can hope.

We got also the investigations of The Garcia murder who happened a little bit late and feel like the real talks and problem was before this because after this its only gunshots and murders .

The ending dont let us to really know more just how everyone are and it end like this and Joe will never confront the public of his murders and it could give a nice moments but anyway..... we got also that story of isolation with that pandemia but thats all and launch the confrontation between Joe and Tedd.

text:
The best historical drama I've ever seen Writing, acting, directing, just top notch across the board. I won't single anyone out, they could all be nominated for major awards. I have no criticisms at all.

In fact, as a history major, I appreciate the fact that even when dramatic license is taken, it is true to the spirit and truth of reality. That's a tricky thing and they navigate it so well that I don't mind minor exaggerations or embellishments.

This is my favorite genre. It is incredibly rare, if not unheard of, to have a historical drama that can't really be picked apart and called out for gross inaccuracies.

All this while creating a fascinating, compelling, engaing story with witty, intelligent writing, flawless delivery, perfect pacing and a clearly understood plot. It leaves you extremely satisfied, despite the inevitable ending.

Exceptionally well done.
label: literal

text:
Sunday Sizzler with its Roots in the Dramas of the Seventies and Eighties What can one say about Debbie Horsfield's rendering of Winston Graham's evergreen series of classics that has not been said before? Being old enough to remember the 1975 version when Robin Ellis strode through the West Country with his scanty undershirt revealing a hairy chest and equally distinguished sideburns, I was impressed with Aidan Turner's recreation of the same role. Turner has a wonderful gift for smoldering; his features do not change much, but his eyes flash and his lips purse in a way that brooks no resistance from anyone. George Warleggan (Jack Farthing) is an eminently hissable villain, his pasty face and arrogant mien contrasting with Robin Poldark's humanity. The facial and bodily contrasts between the two resembles that of any great melodrama. We know George will get his comeuppance in the end, but we marvel at the extent to which he is prepared to manipulate others in order to achieve his aims.

Filmed on the rolling Cornish coast, POLDARK knows how to make the best use of its locations, filming its protagonists against the setting sun or having them walk alone among deserted beaches or wading into the sea. There are also plenty of opportunities for Ross to be shown either shirtless or sweat-soaked down the mine, moving in close proximity to his fellow-workers in lurid orange light. We can understand from their expressions how committed they are to their futures, despite George's best efforts to impede them.

In truth the structure of each episode is a tad repetitive, with Ross and his wife (Eleanor Tomlinson) having to overcome a series of struggles both mental as well as professional: negotiating obstacles like Scylla and Charybdis so that they can arrive at a happy end. But the production, directed by a variety of artists, is constructed with such Ã©lan, with plenty of swash, buckle and romance that we are scarcely aware of its schematics. The BBC used to distinguish itself with these kind of dramas of a Sunday night - there was HOWARDS WAY set in the contemporary era that enjoyed a long run. How pleasant to see the new POLDARK perpetuating that tradition.
label: literal

text:
Beautiful in every sense, Moana will soften even the hardest of hearts Moana is a return to the classic Disney formula, the clichÃ©s and characters ripped from a number of other animated films. However, the pure beauty and skill of the production rises the old story into new heights.

Following from the success of Zootropolis, Moana follows a more traditional narrative we know and love; the princess who wishes for something more and is whisked on a supernatural adventure. We know this story so well yet Moana seems fresh and thrilling as if the plot was innovative. Perhaps this is due to the Polynesian setting or the morally ambiguous Maui, played perfectly by Dwayne Johnson, but most likely it is it the simple magic of Disney â€“ the wonder for both children and adults has reached its peak with the perfection of the classic formula. For once, the clichÃ©s make the film more enjoyable. The quality of the animation helps too: it's clear they have reached the pinnacle of blending realistic textures with stylised designs, creating an aesthetic beauty that few other companies can match â€“ Disney have mastered water to the point it looks better animated than in real life! Even the music has been perfected here, the annoying catchiness of Frozen's tunes replaced by memorable but effective songs that fit the culture and setting of our adventure. A childlike warmth was awakened in me and many other adult members of the audience as the film brought the emotional highs of the Disney renaissance without the modern subversion of the classic tropes. While Moana sometimes threatens this with pop culture references, the film thankfully keeps to mostly traditional values and morals; a step above many children's animated films released today.

Moana is good, old fashioned Disney magic; the traditional narrative and morals updated with stellar animation and an awareness that's effective but never overpowering enough to threaten the integrity of the Disney formula.

SWEET

Visit https://sweetorsaltedmoviereviews.com/ for more.

text:
Magic, Misdirection, and a Bold New Illusion Review of Now You See Me 3 Rating: 7/10

Plot Now You See Me 3 follows the Four Horsemen as they reunite for another high-stakes mission filled with deception, global intrigue, and mind-bending magic. This time, they are drawn into a new conspiracy involving rival illusionists and a powerful underground organization. To survive, they must orchestrate their most ambitious and intricate performance yet-one that blurs the line between illusion and reality more than ever before.

Strengths The film delivers stylish set pieces, clever heist mechanics, and energetic pacing. The signature magical flair of the franchise is intact, with creative illusions and slick visual sequences that keep the audience engaged. The returning cast provides strong chemistry, and new characters bring fresh tension and humor. The expanded lore around the Eye adds intrigue and a sense of mystery that fans will appreciate.

Overall Impressions With its polished spectacle, charismatic performances, and thrilling twists, Now You See Me 3 is a fun and satisfying continuation of the series. While not every reveal lands perfectly, the movie offers enough charm and cleverness to entertain, making it a solid entry for fans of magical heist films.

text:
I still don't get why his wife is included in this series. For someone so focused on his goals, the inclusion of an emotionally unstable, one-woman circus undermines the purpose of the show entirely. It feels like her character disrupts the central narrative, adding unnecessary chaos rather than supporting his journey. The portrayal doesn't enhance the storyline but instead makes it harder to take his determination and focus seriously.

Similarly, the roles of both his wife and daughter feel out of place within the series. The wife comes across as emotionally erratic, while the daughter seems to lack intellectual depth, making her contributions to the plot negligible. The daughter's portrayal feels particularly shallow, with her character offering little beyond surface-level engagement, which doesn't add value to the story.

Moreover, having these characters constantly jump around in provocative clothing, seemingly for no purpose other than to attract views, feels out of sync with the tone of the series. Instead of enhancing the plot or character dynamics, this approach comes off as a superficial tactic to draw attention. It's a strange and unneeded addition that detracts from the overall quality of the narrative.

text:
solid international intrigue with great performances Netflix has disappointed me recently with so little worth watching, so it was great to stumble across The Diplomat, which is like a series they would have made years ago.

The biggest attraction is seeing Keri Russell, Rufus Sewell, Allison Janney, Rory Kinnear and Ali Ahn give kickass performances. The cast overall is very strong.

The plotline starts slow in S1, as the setting and characters are built up. By the end of S1, the plot becomes clear and then roars along in S2. It's good to watch the first two seasons back to back like I did. They keep ramping up the stakes, which makes it maybe a little too easy to see where they are going with this, but it's still a lot of fun.

Another noteworthy element that a lot of viewers might skip over: the costuming and use of color in the sets, costumes and interiors. Stuff like, the characters wearing more blue to the Fourth of July event; costumes being coordinated with the set colors; or the comic/ironic contrast of a fancy gown being worn in a decidedly gritty and fraught scene. Somebody is putting a lot of thought into all this.

text:
It's good but still has its issues Yellowstone is a very fine show with its beautiful cinematography and scenes of intense acting. It's 5 seasons long and probably didn't need to go on as long as it does but it gives you hours of entertainment.

It has its issues. Firstly, I don't know who I'm supposed to be supporting. None of the characters are particularly good people especially John Dutton. He's a narcissist and a bully to his own children who refuses to listen to anybody unless it suits his stubborn ways. He's a murderer and a boarder line sex offender and kidnapper. The character of Summer will tell you this. His sons are only thinking for themselves but Kasey who is portrayed as the "good guy" still murdered his brother in law without owning up to it. Beth is the worst character. Horrid alcoholic who has no right to get as far as she does in the show but for some reason Taylor Sheridan absolutely loves her and even gives her the nice send off she doesn't deserve. The actress overacted the part and by the final season, Yellowstone became Bethstone. Partly because Costner did what he does best and whinged about his character not surviving so left the show early. Nothing new with him. But S5 was just Beth Beth and some more Beth. She becomes tedious as she wasn't written to be a main character but that's what we were left with. The Jamie character was done dirty. We know him and Beth don't get along and for some reason, TS wrote him to become a monster with a murderous father( not John, no. A new father ) and it just feels a little forced. He was looking out for himself but after a whole life of being hated and abused, I don't blame him for wanting to hurt the Duttons! His death was predictable but uncalled for as "you know who" got to seal his fate.

Secondly: Away from the Duttons, characters such as Rain Water become obsolete as their original story just ends. Wranglers such as Walker become nothing characters and in his story, Walker just becomes the soundtrack. As wonderful as his songs are. Although Rip is probably the most popular character and he at least stays consistent.

The show has an intriguing storyline. It does have some fine acting, beautiful scenery and a couple of heart stopping moments with some good cliffhangers. But it's a confusing show. It does have an ending at least albeit spoiled by Costner being Costner. 7/10 and worth a watch. Just make your own mind up on the strange characters.

text:
Shame of Thrones The ending of this series is a disservice to the public!

The first seasons are great as they are based on the books source material and, apparently, the writers are good enough at adapting other people ideas. After season four there's a decline, not so manifest at first since the goodness of the source material still lingers around. It's more of a slow deterioration, a spiral into shallow writing that peaks in a last season devoid of content and value. Where at first grand scale developments, societal issues and world-spanning intrigues dominated the narration with characters being the pawns of the true overarching story, later in the seasons characters and stereotypical interactions take the stage and the interesting, long developing issues that made the story captivating get resolved in the most unrewarding ways possible. It's incoherent, detached, uninspired writing. It's everything that is bad in mainstream media.

All of this because the writers decided they had enough with the show and grew bored with it. So they wanted to wrap it up as soon as possible in order to go on and ruin the Star Wars franchise (more than it already is). Thanks for your disservice!

It needs to be mentioned that the overall production, sound design, acting, cinematography, all of these are quite extraordinary and elevate the show quite a bit, even when the writing declines. The quality is amazing. It probably is still worth watching for its entertainment value. It just doesn't pay off. The ending season ruins quite literally everything.

text:
A movie's movie - stunningly beautiful, mystical, haunting I absolutely loved the new 'IT' movie and didn't expect it to be that good. It is a perfectly paced and beautifully shot movie that captures some of the love for 80's horror movies.

But 'IT' is actually much more than just a rehash of a plain-old horror movie: The characters are all interesting and the kids' acting skills are surprisingly convincing and moving. You really do feel for them and you want them to succeed, which is really what makes a horror movie be a hit or a flop. The emotional subplots are not too shallow as wellâ€”the love story does not feel haphazardly attached onto everything else; the interactions between the characters feel meaningful and real.

The new clown is also quite well done with some very creepy acting and a compelling voice. What's more: I didn't even mind the CGI of the horror effects. Usually CGI puts me off, but here, everything was done rather well with some really suspenseful moments.

In the end, what really got me to love the new 'IT' is that this is a movie for people who love movies. The cinematography is just like true movie fans like it: Lots of stunning landscape and wide shots, perfect lighting and atmosphere, and on top of that a great score! What do you want more?

text:
Who is the real criminal? Who should truly be sentenced to prison? Of course, robbing a McDonald's may seem wrong at first glance.

But sometimes, what looks like a crime on the surface reveals something much deeper underneath-a broken system where hard work and talent are not always rewarded.

When a man of skill and dignity can't even earn enough to feed his family, maybe the real question isn't why he broke the law, but why the law failed him first.

He loved Leigh Wainscott with a pure heart, trusting her completely. Yet that trust was used against him. She, together with the police, called it justice. But what kind of justice relies on deception? What kind of righteousness hides behind "I love you"?

I am not saying he was innocent of every act-but isn't it worth asking who the real criminal is in a world where the powerful exploit the powerless without consequence?

As the old Chinese saying goes: "Steal a hook and you're executed; steal a nation and you're crowned a lord." It reminds us that sometimes punishment depends not on what we do, but on who we are.

A hungry man who takes a little to survive is condemned; yet those who take everything from millions through greed and manipulation are admired.

True justice should not serve the powerful alone-it should serve humanity.

Because worse than stealing money is stealing hope. Worse than breaking a law is breaking the belief that being good still matters.

If we lose that, what kind of society do we have left?
label: figurative

text:
Middling Directed by: Derek Cianfrance Written by: Derek Cianfrance, Kirt Gunn

SUMMARY

After breaking out from prison, a convict hides out inside a Toy 'R Us store, surviving undetected for months. However, his secret life begins to unravel as he falls for a divorced mom. Ultimately, despite being given a chance to escape the country, he risks everything to say goodbye - and is caught in the act.

RATING

B

Roofman tells the true story of Jeff Manchester, who escaped prison and hid out inside a Toys 'R Us. The movie captures his ingenuity and resourcefulness with flair, but it falters emotionally, drifting into a middling family drama halfway through. Lacking a true moment of crisis, the story feels predictable and safe. In the end, Roofman is a very good film that never quite dares to be great.

text:
This is the kind of movie that reminds you why theaters matter. Grab your popcorn, kick back, shut your brain off just enough, and enjoy the ride. For me, that's a win. Edgar Wright's The Running Man isn't just a remake, it's a reinvention. Instead of recycling the beats, tone, and camp of the 1987 Schwarzenegger film, Wright delivers a razor-sharp dystopian action thriller that actually feels made for 2025. It's bold, timely, and wildly entertaining.

I heard people were divided on this one. Honestly? I don't get it. This is exactly what a modern adaptation should look like. It's not trying to be the original. It's not mimicking nostalgia. It's a fresh, ambitious take wrapped in the cultural anxieties of today... surveillance, manipulated narratives, viral outrage, and a society that confuses entertainment with punishment. The commentary is there if you want it, but it never hits you over the head. Most of the people it's skewering probably won't even realize it.

If you've caught our live show on YouTube, you already know my stance on Glen Powell. Hollywood's current "It guy"-is usually a big shrug. But credit where it's due, he delivers here. Powell brings a surprising mix of charm, desperation, and physicality. He gets comedic beats, he nails the intensity, and yes... the film gives the ladies a little something too. This is easily one of his best roles to date.

Wright's biggest deviation from the original? Moving the action out of the neon game-show arena and into the streets. Here, runners aren't in a controlled death maze-they're dumped into the real world and hunted in public, turning everyday citizens into potential threats. The media warps every moment, twisting the public's perception in real time. It feels uncomfortably plausible, which makes it all the more gripping.

The supporting cast is stacked and firing on all cylinders.

Josh Brolin brings grizzled gravitas.

Colman Domingo is phenomenal (as always), chewing scenes with quiet menace.

Michael Cera is bizarre, unsettling, and unexpectedly perfect for this world.

Everyone understands the assignment heightened, theatrical, but always grounded in Wright's controlled chaos, and if you are pissed if this is not the usual film from him, then you should have supported Last Night in Soho, a hidden gem masterpiece that flopped.

Most importantly, the movie knows what it is, a fast, fun, adrenaline-pumping popcorn flick. It's here to entertain you for two hours, to make you forget the outside world while it blasts through tightly choreographed action sequences, slick editing, and Wright's signature kinetic style.

And on that level? It nails it.
label: figurative

Perfect then ruined I had read the books years before the series came out and was a bit dubious about how it would translate to the screen. The problem is the series overtook the books and since then it has gone downhill, especially the final series. There is a massive battle which should be incredible but I found it a real let down, and the episodes after this are even worse. These characters that have been so well developed over the years suddenly act in ways that are just bizarre, I'm incredibly disappointed, I doubt George R R Martin had much to do with the scripts/plot and I'm sure he can't be happy with the result. 10/10 for the first few seasons, 3/10 for the last one.

There were also a couple of things in the previous season which were a big letdown, like explaining where the bad guys came from, and some characters were massively underused, or their story arc just seemed to tail off when the had been so promising.

Overall definitely worth watching but prepare yourself for disappointment towards the end.

text: Love season 1, like season 2 The first season of the show gets a nine from me. It's tight, consistent, darkly humorous, and its social commentary is nuanced and central to the show. Season two gets more like a six. It's good enough for me to watch a season three, but overall season two is less interesting because it feels more like a slow moving trainwreck of a tabloid story. The writing is just too obvious and lacks the nuance necessary to make the excesses interesting or meaningful. That doesn't make it bad television, but it does move it to the "maybe" category of recommendations for me - except for Aubrey Plaza's performance. She is excellent and definitely worth showing up for. Overall, the show is engaging and has plenty to say. If they can move past the sophomore slump of overly obvious excess, I'd love to see more seasons.
label: figurative

But getting to know someone and then watching them make the dumb decisions ? It's like reliving a horrible mistake you've made in your life that you regret that you cannot change. That is what this movie is. A giant ball of regrets and awkwardness. Most upsetting was that it called itself an action. The movie was a drama primarily. Secondary it was a dark comedy. There was nothing action about it !

Good old-fashioned violent fun There's something so satisfying when the bad guys in a movie are Nazis. It's almost a bit of a cheat code to ensure that you are firmly on the side of the protagonist. Throw a dog into the mix and it's a no doubter.

This ticks a lot of boxes for my favourite things in movies. A vigilante exacting brutal revenge is just such a satisfying thing to watch on screen. Also the movie has no limits on violence which I love.

The film does require a heavy suspension of disbelief. We would have to believe that this is the most incompetent Nazi troop that ever existed. Completely unable to shoot straight at point blank range. Just how ridiculous it can be in this sense is probably the one let-down of the movie. If this doesn't bother you though you're likely to have a very good time with 'Sisu'. 8/10.

text:
The Running Missed Oppurtunities 001 - Ben Richards, his intestines hanging out as a result of being shot in the guts before the decompression of the plane, is flying the plane directly at the network tower. Killian turns around, looks at the plane, and sees Richards, who is flipping him off. Richards' eyes are black from haemorrhaging, his grin wider than a door.

000 - Ben Richards crashes his plane into the network building. The rising resistance inspired by him is slowly taking over the country. A junkie who is near enough to the explosion to see it clearly but distant enough to survive regards it with wonder and awe. It rains fire over a radius of twenty blocks.

There are other massive missed opportunities in this adaptation, but just as was the case with The Long Walk, someone said hey, I have an ending that is so much coooooooler and decided to put that in instead. The problem being, the ending this film replaces the above with is dorkier than anything in the 1987 film, and I speak as a boy who was nine years old when that film was released when I say that even in 1987, that film was the height of dork. Oh yeah, and another problem. This ending does not merely make no sense. It is physically impossible. Or incoherent. Or just plain editorially slack. Somehow, an ejection capsule brings Richards from underneath the exploding plane all the way to the part of the tower in which the filming of the studio commentary takes place, which previous parts of the film have told us is numerous storeys above street level... I guess this film thinks we are as moronic as the depicted show likes to encourage its audience to be.

It is, of course, inevitable that a film that takes less time to watch than King says he wrote the novel in has to make some changes. Ben's progress through the audition, painfully detailed for good reason in the novel, is truncated because such details as orifice exams and "leave your valuables" are not important to the flow of a film and the cost-benefit in storytelling terms favours cutting them.

But what of such details as Stacey telling Ben Richards on first meeting that elder brother Bradley will, paraphrased, make Ben defecate in his boot and eat it? Sadly, nowhere to be found. This was the funniest moment in the novel simply because Ben, a big but very sickly man, is simply trying to get a little boy to not turn him in and summon the help of an elder brother who can help. That wordplay would have worked wonders in audiovisual form. As it stands, Stacey and Bradley are almost completely without a second dimension. The conversations about the network and the air pollution were amazing pieces of writing. When the real Bradley tells the real Ben, who has just watched a video of himself declaring that he is going to kill "every pig I see", that Bradley is surprised they let Ben get away with as much of the original speech as they did, it still brings ironic chuckles to this Child Of The 1980s. The moment when Bradley explains that the chronic coughing and shortness of breath Ben experiences is not bronchitis, but emphysema, is one of the most horrifying moments in Stephen King's writing. And this is not a horror novel we are talking about.

You see, when you are choosing what details to include, change, or omit, you always have to think about what it will cost versus what it will bring in. Adding a third runner gave us a great chance for a character to explain to the audience that for one, there are three kinds of contestant the network specifically looks for and two, one of those types is an idiot who will get killed quickly. It is all about manipulating the emotional responses of the audience, we learn. But then for reasons best known to Edgar, we are told that the person who "came the closest" to surviving the thirty days was done in on day twenty-nine, and later we learn that this person is McCone, the chief Hunter in this run.

McCone was described in passing as a little man. A frightening little man, but yeah. From the perspective of a six foot two Richards, the average-height man of the early 1980s would look little. That is not the problem here. Physical size comes second to ability to play the part well. The real problem is that we are given no build-up or substantial reason to care about this detail. This is not a Terminator style conflict between a protector and a hunter, it is a man versus world thing. And the real response that Killian gives in response to the world starting to turn in Richards' favour is, although a little overused in today's market, still a nihilistic joy.

No, the Hunters did not go and kill Richards' wife and child. And they were killed for realsies. Killian is not a stupid man. He knows that Richards could go stomping around the streets of the slum district and find out exactly who broke into his home in a matter of hours. It is just an unhappy accident that someone desperate enough or drugged up enough stormed the apartment and stabbed Richards' family to death. Killian even tries to sell the idea of becoming the new chief Hunter by saying it will give Richards the tools to mercilessly hunt down the perps. And McCone's protests? "I think it is time to remember who pays your salary, Mister Chief Hunter." Can you imagine Josh Brolin delivering that line? I can, and it angers me, what they decided to put in this film in its place. The way this plays out in the novel is a little more grown-up (no such thing as truly grown-up in the English-speaking film market anymore). Killian reminds Richards of his stated plan to come to the Network's tower and ride the elevator up, gunning down everyone on every floor. Then Killian asks if it would surprise Richards to learn that one of the people he found on the tower floors was Killian. Richards' response that he had Killian figured for the mouse rigger (goo-goo gaa-gaa, Sundar) gets Killian laughing and describing Richards as a rare, iridescent bird.

These dialogues demonstrate that the reason Richards was picked was because he was too smart to be left to potentially start building a movement on the streets and should be eliminated in the style of the game show. What they did not count on was his game show performance causing a disorganised but even larger resistance movement that at the time of the novel's end is starting to coalesce from riots into organised attacks and hood organisations. Whether this movement achieves its goals after the destruction of the Network building is never elaborated on in the novel. But the novel is replete with truly amazing exchanges of dialogues because for one, Stephen King knows how intelligent people speak and two, he knows how to structure that into an interesting scene. Two things that this film lacks in ample quantities.

The 1987 film had smarter dialogue. I never cared for Killian In Name Only calling Richards In Name Only "cutie-pie". But Richards In Name Only saying I have seen you before, you are the rear opening on TV before Killian In Name Only responding with that is funny, I was going to say the same thing about you, that is far closer to King-level writing than this turgid effort. Oh, and another note about the altered tapes. During the tape Richards sends after learning about the deliberate pollution of the underclass lands, when the audio is edited with the intent of turning him into a psychopath in the eyes of the audience, no effort is even made to match the voices with the lips. I do not remember in enough detail, but it is possible, even likely, that King wrote of the soundalike being slightly off, too. The novel was not just a comment on deliberately induced desperation, it was also about how easily television can be used to alter the perception of the people watching it. You know, like it has been proudly doing for around seventy-five years now?

Another commenter has also stated that the world in the film feels rather two-dimensional. This is why pieces like the defecate in your boot and eat it dialogue were so important. They also mention that Bradley Throckmorton is a big banana in the gang that controls these streets. Stacey's words to this effect come across as the terrified plays of a child that has just been seized by a big man who has climbed out of the sewer covered in shit. But when Bradley appears and his connections are verified as true, it gives a sense that there are other people than those in the narrative, behind the scenes, doing things. Bradley's words about the deliberate pollution are also executed a good deal better. He describes how a lot of his information is only available in libraries, and he explains how he and his gang get around the minimum income restriction that the Network has placed on libraries. He describes having figured out how to make a crude radioactive particle per air volume meter from these books. He describes how the readings on a good day are really bad. All of this makes the world of the novel feel alive. What do we get instead? Oh, apparently Bradley is a YouChoob star.

Did nobody in the writing room ever stop to think about how a world like the one in this novel would have scuttled the internet and censored all mention that it ever existed? How the broadcast signal would be utterly impossible to crack, and how real street gangs would distribute information through ink and paper? Did anyone put half as much thought into this film as I have during this review?

On the plus side, the first four fifths of the film are good, notwithstanding the two-dimensionality and the idiotic alterations in detail where the original material would hit a lot harder if done well. The acting is almost all great. The photography is great when we are not in an action scene. Aside from this, learn from my mistake. Save your money, do not bother. Insulting ends ruin decent adaptations.
label: figurative

text: It's a Family Affair Greetings again from the darkness.  Check out the number of "Howard" surnames listed in the credits.  I counted four, but may have missed some. Dedicating the film to his recently deceased mother, Ron Howard was the perfect choice for directing this Dr. Seuss adaptation.  Mr. Howard has a real feel for family relationships and that plays a key part in the theme of the Grinch vs. Who-ville.  Howard, as usual, cast numerous members of his own family in the film.  This includes, the always good for a laugh, brother Clint.  Jim Carrey again proves that he is a tremendous acting talent.  "The Truman Show" followed by "Man on the Moon" and now this!  We are are blessed to watch such a uniquely talented performer perfect his craft.  If you say the Grinch role required little acting, you are wrong.  Carrey captures the true spirit of the role, and a wide range of emotions, while toting make-up that makes it impossible to recognize him.  My one complaint with the film is the extremely weak version of the Grinch theme song.  Done wonderfully creepy in the original TV special, the song is so light-hearted in the film that it loses the punch it is supposed to pack.  My tidbit on this one is to be sure and catch the Ron Howard parody performed by Jim Carrey as he doffs a ball cap and begins mimmicing the director.  This was most assuredly a Carrey ad lib that made the final cut.  My request of Jim Carrey is: PLEASE get over the butt fetish!
label: literal

McClarnon Zahn McClarnon deserves every accolade and recognition for his role here. He carries the show...I have always admired and appreciated his acting, but, wow, he is simply exceptional in this series...And the acting that every single character delivers nails it.

Joe Leaphorn is an important character (McClarnon) who represents the Native American experience on a granular, day to day level. This takes place in the 1970's, and I learned a lot about what they experienced back then. Not that I'll ever really know it really, of course, but wow, this really expanded my glimpse into how much the disparity was back then and now. It's also a very well-scripted and crafted story arc of venality and the craven assumption of entitled power. This, imo, is one of the Best examples of dramatic social commentary AND writing and acting.

text: The best King adaptation of the year (which isn't saying much) There are different approaches and styles of storytelling but I have always thought that bestselling novelist Stephen King has a good grip over the most effective one of them. He has the image of horror master but his stories offer actually much more than quick thrills. You possibly couldn't churn out up to 1100 page opuses based on just thrills, could you? King's focus is always on careful character and world building because why would one want to just follow a bunch of events if one didn't care about the people in the story and what's happening to them. And he's usually scarily efficient at creating characters that we want to form emotional connections to. I have read most of King's 57 novels by now, and I am often hooked already on the first page, or maybe the second. The careful character and world building doesn't just happen at once, it takes time and room. This is one of the main reasons why most of King's adaptations are not great ones. There is no way to compress hundreds of pages into a screen story lasting about two hours. Take Â„IT", for example. In an original novel, there's more than 1100 pages. As a movie, it runs 135 minutes, including end credits. There was never gonna be a chance to see more than main events on screen, not to mention Hollywood's nasty way of often taking a famed literary work of fiction and throwing out almost everything but the main plot points and character names. I read Â„IT" more than ten years ago, so I don't remember it all that well, but the movie version feels... right. They have taken the best of both worlds: sweet nostalgia-tinged coming of age story as a backbone and the horrors served in short intervals aside. Both aspects work well, neither feels fresh but they are effective. Coming of age story resembles 1986's Â„Stand by Me", one of the most acclaimed King adaptation of all time. Horrors are created the cheap way, that is to say, mostly by editing and sudden creepy music or sound effects. Nothing essentially wrong with that, most horror movies do the same and they still have plenty of fans. I myself have quite tired of this and would have preferred slow and creepy building of suspense â€“ this would have fit more closely with King's original work too â€“ but whatever. The problem me is that there's just too many Â„horror" moments, after one hour it's starting to feel like a carnival show. One has to be a true horror fan to not feel exhaustion before the end, or possibly reaching the middle of the story. Two-plus hours is a long way to watch somebody attacked over and over again by the same two or three evil creatures. I mean, I like Pennywise and his crew as much as anybody but there's only so much times it feels cool to see some monster suddenly jump out from somewhere and say "boo". I was quite curious about how the adaptation would Â„solve" this famous sex scene from the original novel. There's probably no tasteful way to offer it in mainstream movie, so they have opted to not use it all. Wise choice. King should have left it out in the book, too. So. For a horror movie, Â„IT" is good enough if overly ready to use the same couple of tricks over and over again. For a movie inspired by King's work, it's also good enough, giving you the simple but clear taste of what the bestselling master is possibly about. For a King adaptation, it's mediocre as most of them, setting the bar too low to start with. So, you just have to go catch it and see whether you'll float too. There's a possibility of part two although it's hard to tell how concrete this is. Probably depends on the box office success. The movie ends the same way as the novel, which means there The young actors in part 1 are good, by the way.
label: figurative

text:
A powerful adaptation of Mary Shelley's gothic epic Watched at the 2025 Toronto International Film Festival.

Guillermo del Toro's adaptation of Frankenstein is one of the best adaptations of Mary Shelley's epic novel in a very long time. Del Toro continues to prove his talents with how he directs gothic, romantic, fantasy, and emotional stories with such awe striking fierce and power within his talents. Throughout, Del Toro's direction on the writing, atmosphere, and production designs are wonderful. He maintains the balance between the themes, the tone, the style and atmosphere perfectly, which helps blend the gothic, horror, and dramatic elements together very well.

With the gorgeous camerawork, the production, colors, effects, make-up, and sound designs are wonderful. Capturing it's time period and setting in the right spot. Narrative-wise, the writing does justice to the original novel with the themes explored being portrayed throughly and meaningfully. Including some addition new themes Del Toro explored which I thought was creative. The performances from the cast are all fantastic. Oscar Isaac as Dr. Frankenstein was great as he had some much energy and charm to his character, alongside with Christoph Waltz, Mia Goth and the others. Jacob Elordi has Frankenstein the Monster, might just has given his best performance in his career thus far. Being able to capture the emotional and terrifying weight of the character of the monster himself.

Alongside with the beautiful score and some of the thrilling sequences, the movie does suffer a few pacing issues as through it's second act, it does seem to lose a little of it's steam. But overall, Del Toro does justice to a classic novel and remains as one of the best working directors in our current times.
label: literal

text:
Funny and Charming With Heavy Themes Good Fortune is funny, charming, but heavy with its themes.

The writing is great. The characters are all very likeable and no matter how much money one has, they can relate to all of them in one way or another. This script doesn't want to hide its themes. The film is heavily anti-capitalist or at least it heavily criticizes it. Usually I hate when movies preach, but it totally worked here, because this film is a very funny comedy. To be exact, the first half is very slow, but the back half is just utter fun.

As I said the first half is slow and also messy. I wasn't fan of the way the little time jumps occured and the way they were edited. I think some of those scenes could've been cut. They tried to edit them like a slow montage, but on the one hand they slowed the movie down and on the other hand the editing was too fast there and there was no comedic timing. The cinematography is great though. The camera movement is restrained, but the angles and the lighting are awesome. The production design and the acting performances are great too, while the soundtrack is awesome.

Good Fortune is a great comedy with heavy themes that rather elevate the comedy than ruin it.
label: literal

Ultimately the best part was the depiction of old-fashioned values, when times were simpler. The idealists among us will find that refreshing.
