text:
An excellent show from beginning to end It's tough to write 600 characters about a show that pretty much can be summed up with the above headline, but given that to write a review for IMBD, you now have to hit their character count, here are the things that make this show so good: The writing, the direction, but above all, the acting. Everyone is superb, but Gary Oldman gives the kind of bravura performance you rarely see these days; he plays someone you can't stand and yet you also want to see more of him. Hard to pull off. Jack Lowden is able to pull off another trick: the young hero, he's the least interesting character given that young heros are seldom the best, but he has more than enough charisma to pull off the role perfectly. The others are all good, but special kudos to the always underused Saskia Reeves, who is just perfect in her role, and, perhaps most of all, Brian Vernel, who seems like he was born to play villains, and he does it with panache.

Given the snappy direction, fast paced action, and spot-on dialog, and it's a 10 star show.
label: literal

text:
Strong first 20 minutes, then becomes more and more of a trainwreck I am not familiar with Chris Stuckmann as a movie critic, but if this is what he thought was acceptable to put out then it tells me all I need to know about his critiquing abilities.

Shelby Oaks starts off strong, mixing mockumentary and Riley's YouTube channel footage to set the story up. After the first 20 minutes or so, both of these elements go right out the window.

Once the second act starts, the film goes through just about every horror movie trope you can think of, including incredibly clichÃ©d jump scares and Mia making increasingly stupid decisions. I understand suspending your disbelief a bit when it comes to a character's decision making in horror movies, but Mia was so idiotic that it really took me out of the movie at times. Her husband "taking time for himself" was the best decision made in the entire movie.

The third act is where the movie really falls apart and felt like Stuckmann asked ChatGPT to write an amalgamation of every "evil satanic baby" movie. As if the movie wasn't already disappointing enough, the ending was utter garbage. It basically makes the entire rest of the movie feel completely pointless and like a total waste of time.

I feel so bad for the people who funded this movie. Imagine believing so much in someone's project and vision that you give them funds to bring it to life, only for them to create this disappointing mess.
label: figurative

text:
Campy adult fun Hazbin Hotel is a show that is brimming with it's own personality and creativity.

I saw the pilot back in 2019 and was instantly hooked, when I heard it was getting picked up by Prime Video I was very excited.

Characters are very well thought out and the songs are absolutely catchy, I still find myself singing to them, "Loser Baby" and "Stayed Gone" are amazing.

Despite my nine star review, the show is still not perfect. The gripes I have with it will mostly get resolved in future seasons, my main one is I don't think the characters got enough development or screen time, now I know this is mostly due in part to the eight episode limit, but could they at least up the runtime of them? I also felt like the humor could be....a little better? Most of it is just swearing or sexual jokes which I get it, if your show takes place in Hell you'd expect the characters to say raunchy stuff and out of pocket things but at some point it stopped being funny. They are funny sometimes don't get me wrong, but it does start to get a tad dull.

With all that aside, Hazbin Hotel is a very fun musical adventure and I can't wait for season 2!
label: literal

text:
A very good piece of work Good television is still being made. And HBO is still in the business of making good series like "Task".

We all like Mark Ruffalo. A seasoned actor with great credentials- this one shows some of his great range. His portrayal of a grouchy, drinks too much, priest becomes FBI agent, is believable, heartfelt, and engaging.

The casting helps: somehow all of these actors have an amazing regional Pennsylvania/Philadelphia accent.

But beyond that, the producers picked people that figured out the essence of the situation they find themselves in as characters and convince us of it too.

I actually thought I was watching the final in sixth episode only to realize there is one more. I'm very much looking forward to that.

But as your journey through the episodes, you'll find a well put together story that spends a little need of time on our fragility and humanity. Particularly during a time when empathy end joy seems scarce.

I don't know if they can convince Mark Ruffalo to do another distinct season, but I would love to see one. I would think a prequel exploring Tom Brandis's career as an FBI agent would be a good way to handle more programming.
label: figurative

text:
For Anyone Who Loves a Cry, a Hug, and a Pretty Frame Okay, full disclosure: I know full well I'm so biased on this one, but I really enjoyed 'Regretting You'. From the moment the first frame rolled I was drawn in - visually it's gorgeous, the leads are absolutely stunning, and yes, my heartstrings were tugged. Any film that gets a tear out of me instantly gets a higher rating in my book, haha.

I'll admit: I've read the book (by Colleen Hoover) so there was extra nostalgia and expectation baked in. The film adaptation doesn't always dig as deep as one might hope - some character arcs feel glossed over, some of the emotional beats just skim the surface. Critics have flagged uneven storytelling and tonal whiplash. But honestly? For me it didn't matter, because what it does deliver is warm, cute, and full of heart.

If you're after a perfect chick-flick with a lot of heart, this is your match. The daughter-mother dynamics, the romance, the grief, the scenic backdrops - it comes together into something that's far from perfect, but deeply enjoyable. Sure, it could've been deeper, but sometimes you just want to be moved, to smile, to sniffle, to leave the cinema feeling something. And that's exactly what I got.
label: figurative

text:
Adventure After Adventure! "One battle after another!" perfectly describes this film - an action-packed journey that dives deep into the dark side of politics and police brutality. Many people prefer not to believe that corruption and unethical practices can exist within political systems, especially when certain groups hold ideologies different from the mainstream. The movie dares to touch on these uncomfortable truths, showing how authority and narrow-mindedness can lead to cruelty and injustice.

Sean Penn delivers a powerful performance - no surprise there. He captures the essence of the colonel's cold and cruel personality with incredible depth and conviction. His acting elevates the story and keeps the tension alive.

As for Leonardo, his brief scenes with his daughter were some of the most touching moments. I genuinely wanted to see more of that relationship and how he, as a single father, balances love and responsibility amid chaos. Those moments gave his character a human side that contrasted beautifully with the film's intense pace.

The movie itself is funny, thrilling, and filled with nonstop adventure. The soundtrack adds a playful twist to the action scenes, making the battles feel both intense and ironic. Leonardo's portrayal of a paranoid man - once a revolutionary now tangled in his own creation - was fascinating and full of irony.

It's not the movie of the year, but it's definitely worth watching. Entertaining, sharp, and full of energy - I enjoyed every moment.
label: figurative

text:
Doesn't know what it wants to be Sinners was a flick I was excited to see, mostly due to it being recommended by many (both off and online) and due to the high ratings it's been getting. However, I'm sad to say it didn't live up to my expectations.

The film has a terrific bunch of characters, better than 'From Dusk Till Dawn', the only film I can somewhat compare it to. The first half of the movie is mostly a "get the team together" part, much in the vein of "Blues Brothers" or heck, "Ocean's Eleven". Part of the problem is that, while the film has strong character building in this first half, not a lot actually happens. I was preconditioned with the knowledge that it had been called a spin on 'From Dusk Till Dawn', so when it is laid out that Smoke and Stack (both portrayed by Michael B. Jordan, who does a good job) are organizing a 'juke joint' at some barn, it was obvious this would be the 'horror' part of the film. So the main plot point of the first hour or so is just that; there's going to be a party later.

When the party actually starts, it has the most interesting/creative scene of the film; in which 'Preacherboy' (Miles Caton) performs his delta blues song, and the scene is juxtaposed with musicians from others times/regions. I was hoping the film would do more with that theme, but alas, it's just that one scene. Speaking of which, there's a lot of music in the film, and while I like blues music, it sometimes held up the pace of events. There's ways to incorporate music in films which enhances events in the film, but here the musical acts were too front and center in my opinion.

Shortly after that, we get to the "characters making dumb decisions" part, which seems to plague a lot of horror films. The Smokestack brothers seem to figure out that organizing juke joints for poor cotton farmers in the local area isn't very lucrative (who would've guessed?) and thus one of the brothers sends his love interest (Mary, played by Hailee Steinfeld) to get three 'white folk' who had been turned away previously due to being creepy (and white, which one of the brothers point out can be recipe for disaster in 1930's Jim Crowe's America). Why? Are these three people going to turn the night profitable? At that point Mary gets turned into a vampire and pretty soon all hell breaks loose. Stack gets bitten by her, the party stops, everyone leaves, everyone gets turned into vampires and we got our classic Assault on Precinct 13 scenario, in which a small group of hero's battle it out against evil.

A lot of dumb decisions are made during the buildup to the final battle, in which one of the dumb characters decides to invite all the vampires in about 30 minutes before the sun comes up. The battle itself is choreographed decently, but a lot of plot armor is dished around, a lot of clichÃ©'s play out (another love interest who foreshadowed that, if she gets bitten, Stack should finish her off before she turns, which plays out inevitably as planned). Preacherboy tries to escape, gets caught by the main vampire who proceeds to talk to him for 15 minutes with his fangs out, then gets bashed in the head while the suns gets up. Bleh.

Then we get a scene in which Stack (who also survived) shoots up some KKK members, because why not. At least in 'Django', shooting up the Klan felt earned. Here it seemed just another box to tick off.

Now I've only described the film on its surface elements. There's obviously a lot of subtext in terms of the vampires, who seem to share each other's memories and the main vampire who seems focussed on getting Preacherboy (who seems to be a brilliant Blues musician). So I suppose one could argue that Preacherboy is an metaphor for 'black music/culture', and the vampires are perhaps greed/capitalism, who want to suck the lifeblood out of the culture and homogenize it and turn it in an instrument for its own purpose? I'd have to think on that some more. The main vampire seems to be Irish and is hunted earlier in the film by native Americans who get turned away by some KKK members. Probably a lot more subtext that I missed.

But in short; the film tries to bite off more than it can chew, doesn't really know what it wants to do, and thus felt unsatisfying on about every front. It's well produced in terms of cinematography, costumes/production design and has some good characters, but that's about all the praise I can give it. It's also too long, I feel it could've shaved of at least 20 minutes. It wasn't terribly bad, but I wasn't entertained either.

6/10.
label: literal

text: Please, everyone, if you can, go see this in theaters. The production design, though, that stole the show for me, was actually insane. No way in hell it doesn't win that Oscar. That's really all I can say about this for now. text:
Amazing! I love it. Haven't watched such a good show since Supernatural. Tracker is one of the best new shows I've watched in a long time. Justin Hartley brings depth and charisma to the role of Colter Shaw, a unique character who's part detective, part survivalist. Each episode presents a new mystery, but it's the emotional undercurrent-his complex past and moral compass-that really sets the show apart.

The writing is sharp, the pacing is solid, and the visuals give it a more cinematic feel than most procedurals. I also appreciate that the cases are interesting on their own, while still tying into a larger story.

Overall, Tracker feels fresh, well-acted, and surprisingly moving. Highly recommend to anyone who enjoys mystery, action, or character-driven dramas."

text:

Once Anthony DiNozzo left at the end of season 13, they tried replacing him with Quinn and Torres. Unfortunately, they've dulled the show down heavily. If it wasn't for Gibbs, the show would've come to an end after season 13.

My ratings would be: 8/10 for seasons 1-13 5/10 for season 14 (can't continue watching any further, bored of it now) Overall rating 7/10

If I continued watching it, my overall review would probably drop down to 6/10.

text:
A heartwarming-magical voyage of oceanic proportions! I've seen it eight times already! I just can't stop riding in the canoe along lovable Maui and Moana! Looking forward to watching it nth times! Can't help myself. It's like entering my personal holographic suite: a 1.5 hours Paradise-oceanic-adventure with such charismatic characters in an engaging and thoughtful story. Absolutely beautiful and enchanting. 

The Wonderful:

It's gorgeous in all possible ways â€“ character design, environments, storytelling, etc. I giggle, I laugh, I cry, I sob, I feel the ocean spray! I touch the water! So vivid! Sometimes the animation reminds me of Hannah Barbera afternoon cartoons (Jabberjaw, etc.), just love it!

From the beginning, we know that Moana is qualified to undertake such a mission â€“ to save her island and her people. Along the story, we see how she behaves and reacts to situationsâ€”hints that she will be able to overcome future adversities. I loved how toddler Moana gives up a treasure to protect the innocent: so young and already showing how big her heart is. 

I loved the storytelling embedded in Maui's body tattoos. Amazing! Cute. Maui is a rough funny guy, but he is easily lovable, once we learn what's in his heart and mind. Maui seems scary at first, but he shows us how charming he is with his song. Right then I know I'm going to totally love him! I also thought Maui was a perfect blend of Hulk, Hercules, Lou Ferrigno all hybridized into Dwayne Johnson's caricature, voice and performance (I love how Maui's smile/eyes mirror D. Johnson's eyes/smile) Brilliant! 

The emotional content and the empowering message weaved throughout the story is very strong. Moana fulfills her mission and any self-doubt is extricated. She discovers who she really is and realizes her full potential. As for Maui, he re-discovers his human heart! At first I thought the crab scene was too long, but then I realized it was necessary for Maui's hardship (which would later becomes gratitude).

Loved the songsâ€”(I sing along in the late showings if I'm alone in the auditorium!) The lyrics move the story forward and give us insight into the character's hearts and minds. Clever! 

And with all the humor splashing about I giggled lots too. Little children just love the scenes with the pig and the rooster!

The scenes with the fleet of boats and canoes give me goosebumps and chills! It's so magical! I just want to be there myself! So many spectacular sweeping ocean vistas. Wow! Also, the workings of light and shadow, the water kinetics, the night scenes, etc. Absolutely brilliant and genius!

The voice performance is perfectly harmonized: Dwayne Johnson makes a brilliant and authentic Maui. Cravahlo infuses true life into sixteen-year-old Moana, making her full of spirit. Amazing animation! Moana's and Maui's gestures and emotional expressions are sublime, Grandma's are fantastic too!

Moana's story and animation pulses with real life. I read that the Disney-animation team visited the Pacific Islands and did lots of character exploration. (more details in www.variety.com and Moana's interview in www.insidethemagic.net).

The think-about-it: 

At first, Maui is ogre-ish, tossing Moana into the water (was this roughness really necessary?, not my favorite). But when he realizes that Moana is not alone (she has the Ocean protecting her), and that she is a highly determined, kind, and brave teenager; he learns to respect her and admire her. The climatic point of his change of heart is when Moana saves his lifeÂ…you'll see!

Moana's desire to help her people and revive her island makes her strong and resilient, so she learns how to journey along Maui and steers him to become a good human. And precisely this adversity she faces (with a little help of the good forces that accompany her) allows her to discover who she really is/who she is meant to be. So inspiring!

Conclusion?

Never give up your dream, no matter how "ogreish" your adversity is! Please watch it! It's a paradise worth sailing into nth-times! It's entertaining, stunningly beautiful, emotional, and it'll warm your heart with hope and satisfaction.
label: figurative

text:
Not Who, Not What, but Why? With such an iconic 1966 animated 1/2 hour special, it's hard to imagine a reason to reimagine it as a live action movie. If it ain't broke, don't fix it. I'm not particularly angry or hate this. It's just that I couldn't stop asking Why? 

This one gives a backstory to the origin of the Grinch. He gets delivered by mistake to Whoville. The kids bully him because of his looks. In frustration, he runs away to live on the mountain. Now he is a fully grown loner. Cindy Lou Who (Taylor Momsen) is searching for the meaning of Christmas. She tries to see the good in the Grinch, and keeps trying to bring the spirit of Christmas to him. But the Grinch just can't get into the spirit.

I don't have a big problem with the additional backstory or the greater role for Cindy Lou Who. That's to be expected for an expanded Grinch. And Taylor Momsen is a perfectly good child actor. But none of it excites me. The visual design is again expected but without the outlandishness of 'The 5,000 Fingers of Dr. T.' for instance. However it is still great once we get to the last part where the Grinch tries to steal Christmas. All the sentiments are there voiced especially by Cindy Lou Who's father. That part still works. Nothing can change that.
label: literal

text:
Cow punching scenery and psychopathy It's a lot like a western. Since it's all set on the old homestead it's kind of like Bonanza, The Virginian, the Big Valley or The Big Country rather than the John Wayne, James Stewart, Randolph Scott style, man on his own oater. There's a bit of a difference in that the Cartwrights, whoever was running Shiloh ranch at any particular time, Barbara Stanwyck, and even Charlton Heston didn't go around murdering people for no more reason than that they were inconvenient.

In the good old days you had good guys and bad guys. But things are more nuanced now. So you can admire John Dutton's love of the land, his devotion to his family, or, at least, what he sees as his dynasty, his cod wisdom, and more or less give him a pass on being a serial killer.

So. So far so good. Up to the end of series 2. I'm mid way through series 4 right now and it's like a repeat, of the first two series but with a different set of adversaries.

However, there is a problem.

I'm guessing that Costner's obvious devotion to all things cowboy is part of it. But I can't help wondering whether sponsorship might also be a factor in the way that I am now constantly having to watch (actual) rodeo riders displaying their skills in long scenes that have nothing to do with the plot. I like Netflix because, so far, it's ad free, but really , scenes of riders stopping their horses (why is that even a skill) or making them pirouette, make me want to go and get a cup of tea. Jimmy's journey to cowboy land is also looking a bit like a documentary now that he's signed up with a real life Texas ranch. In between that though the story is still engrossing enough to keep me going.
label: figurative

This show is one of those moments. Some of the acting as well in this show is some of the best I have seen in any series.

I also think the concept of what makes a human a true human is very intriguing. I am a christian myself but find this show exploring the nature of humanity and consciousness very telling for how our culture is seeking these existential ideas.

text: Feels Like We Never Left For someone that has nostalgia for the 2000s Freaky Friday, this was everything I wanted it to be. I was worried at first because this was supposed to be a straight to Disney+ movie. So I did not know what to expect. But I'm pleased to say this legacy sequel keeps everything great about that movie while still having its own heart felt moments to it. Lindsay Lohan, and Jamie Lee Curtis are back! And are as great as ever. Even after all these years they are still able to make these characters work. They are both two different characters, and they both absolutely sell it on both of them and make you believe that they are actually two different characters. It's just the right comedic timing and acting. It's so believable. And even the new cast of kids they have in here, same thing goes for them. They do actually feel like the older cast of characters. And thats whats so fun about playing a role like this, you're able to change your personality up and be over the top and make it work. It's crazy that even 20 years later, not only the actors, but the script, the story, all still works and feels like it's only been a few years after the original film. The comedy is still as funny as always, the story is still that classic freaky Friday story, but with more heart. Yes, we still keep that classic formula. But this time since there's four characters being swapped around, and kids trying to change up their parents marriage. It adds for this whole new layer of satisfaction near the end. The character arcs had a meaning and they went through something because you cared for the characters. It had more meaning because of that extra layer you decided to put on. It is not just a mother daughter banter, this time it's the whole family banter and that's why it works better. Now, this is not better than the original film. No one was expecting it to be. But it is still very much on the same par as the original film because it still keeps everything great about the original film, just 20 years later. But of course, the movie is still predictable, we've seen this formula before you seen this type of movie before you know how it's gonna end. But the journey to get there and that heartfelt ending is what makes it worth watching. If you have nostalgia for that original film or just love the freaky Friday movies this is your thing, but if you did not grow up on that, don't know what this is. Don't check this out. It's probably not for you.
label: figurative

text: Wow , well done Netflix and Tim Burton's! I loved this series. Jenna Ortega as Wednesday Addams was truly a match made in heaven. Pairing her alongside the character of Enid was a fantastic choice by the directors considering how their scenes together really stole the show. We got to dive into the backstory of the Addams family a little bit which I LOVED. Morticia and Gomez were amazing and I loved their characterization. Don't even get me started on Pugsley. He was such a sweet boy and an excellent (and refreshing) take on the character. Enid Sinclair surprised me with how much I grew to love her. Jenna and Emma's characters were an absolute blast to watch on screen. I wasn't too interested in the love triangle. It was strenuous and bland and left me feeling bad for Wednesday. However, I can definitely seen potential in Wednesday and Enid becoming something more. Their chemistry had me laughing and crying (especially at the end). Overall, this was an amazing show. It exceeded all of my expectations. My only hope is that for future seasons (please Netflix give me more) for the CGI to be more fleshed out. However, the CGI never once took away from the story or characters. NETFLIX GIVE US A SEASON 2!!!!!!

text: An extravagant B-movie from France with all the right matinee-adventure ingredients. This is a grandiose monster movie from France that delivers the perfect blend of slick style and unsophisticated, gothic melodrama to make it one of the most appealing film fantasies in a long while.  The international success of the film is not hard to understand; it's exhilarating in the same way that the old Hammer horror films were in their heyday.  Everything about this elaborate movie is terrifically tacky, particularly the stunning production design.  It's like seeing those artless, wilderness paintings containing hidden animal images come to life.  The characters come off as if they were lifted right off of some garish paperback romance-novel cover. Best of all, the film has some nifty  flourishes of sex and violence sadly missing from the current spate of half-baked, PG-13 Hollywood product. While some seem to be complaining of one martial-arts fight too many, faulty creature effects or simple-minded plotting; in this case, it's like bitching about KING KONG being over the top.  This is a contemporary B-movie (albeit an expensive, subtitled one) for those who appreciate a good time at the movies.  It delivers the kind of satisfaction audiences used to get seeing the work of Mario Bava or Ray Harryhausen; and that's saying a lot!
label: literal

text:
Great sincere and investing drama Roofman is a highly investing drama that mostly acts as a sincere character piece with a looming sense of doom because you know it's all going to go wrong at some point. The tonal shifts are seriously impressive as the film mostly moves between comedy and earnest emotion with a sharper tonal shift towards the end which feels intentionally jarring. Plus there's real nostalgia in seeing a Toys R Us again.

Channing Tatum gives one of his best performances to date whilst offering a welcome reminder of just how good his leading man talents can be. He's instantly empathetic and sustains the first act on his charisma alone. He only gets better once he starts sharing scenes with Kirsten Dunst who gives an equally heartfelt performance so the relationship that quickly develops between them feels genuine.

Director Derek Cianfrance is handling lighter material when compared to his previous efforts and he does it gracefully, moving through a whole film's worth of plot early on to get to the more interesting story without rushing. Andrij Parekh's cinematography switches between being extremely calm and frenetic when required, complimented by a rich texture in the image thanks to the decision to shoot on film.
label: literal

text:
Great thriller! The Beast in Me," the psychological thriller miniseries from Netflix, stands out primarily due to the caliber of its main cast's performances. Claire Danes and Matthew Rhys deliver remarkable acting, which serves as the backbone of a tense and intricately constructed narrative.

The series masterfully operates within the thriller genre, engaging the viewer on an almost investigative level. The plot is skillfully woven with subtle clues and calculated developments, encouraging the audience to piece together the puzzle of the truth alongside the characters. This narrative device creates an immersive experience, transforming passive consumption into an exercise in deduction and anticipation-a highlight of the production.

Central to the series' tension is the arc of Aggie Wiggs, portrayed by Danes. Her choices, at times questionable and self-destructive, are the raw representation of a psyche shaken by grief and guilt. The character navigates a "deep limbo" emotionally, where the pain of trauma distorts her perception of reality. The character's strength lies in her flawed humanity: despite her obscured perception, she follows her intuition, which makes her complex and undeniably realistic.

The narrative structure is largely solid, with the caveat that some minor insights into the fate of secondary characters could have been explored with a little more detail. However, these are fine-tuning points that do not diminish the strength of the overall work.

In summary, "The Beast in Me" is a robust example of the genre, anchored by masterful performances and a captivating thriller structure. The series achieves a level of excellence that justifies a high evaluation, close to perfection.
label: figurative

text:
Unexpected gem in the world of modern spy dramas /refers to Seasons 1-4/

This Series offers a gritty, darkly humorous, and refreshingly offbeat take on the espionage genre. Centred around Slough House-a dumping ground for disgraced MI5 operatives-the series thrives on its sharp writing, layered characters, and standout performances, particularly from Gary Oldman as the gloriously grotesque Jackson Lamb. Oldman brings the character to life with a perfect blend of abrasive wit and unexpected depth, earning near-universal praise for what many call one of his most iconic roles.

Across its four seasons, the Series steadily builds momentum. Perhaps the first two seasons are a bit slow to start, they're filled with intrigue and character development. Seasons 3 and 4, however, crank up the intensity, weaving intricate plots and thrilling twists without falling into the trap of filler episodes-a rarity in today's streaming world.

Jack Lowden as River Cartwright provides a grounded counterpoint to Oldman's chaos, while the ensemble cast-Aimee-Ffion Edwards, Kristin Scott Thomas, Rosalind Eleazar, and others-adds emotional weight and diversity to the series. Guest stars like Sope Dirisu and Hugo Weaving only elevate the show's quality further.

The Series is able to mix suspense with clever humour, never taking itself too seriously while still delivering emotional and political punch. The dynamics between generations-Boomers and Millennials navigating high-stakes intelligence work-add an unexpected layer of social commentary.

Despite minor quibbles, like underdeveloped new characters or repetitive soundtrack choices, Slow Horses remains consistently entertaining. With tight, six-episode seasons and a rich, ever-evolving plot, it's a perfect binge-and definitely one of the best spy shows in years. Whether you're in it for the conspiracies, the character drama, or just to watch Oldman be delightfully gross, Slow Horses is absolutely worth the watch. Next seasons can't come soon enough.
label: figurative

text:
A Cozy, Flawed NYC Romance I went into Materialists (2025) expecting a forgettable rom-com, but wow, it surprised me, earning a 6.5/10!

Dakota Johnson's Lucy, a New York matchmaker, juggles a hotshot client, Harry (Pedro Pascal), and her ex, John (Chris Evans), in a story that's funny, heartfelt, and a bit predictable. It's all about love versus money, and I felt that tug in my chest. Johnson's warm but could've popped more; Pascal had me swooning with his charm, and Evans made me ache for his quiet guy.

Celine Song's direction and Shabier Kirchner's dreamy 35mm NYC visuals are a treat, though the story drags in spots and wraps up too neatly. I laughed, I teared up a bit, and I didn't expect to care as much as I did. It's perfect for a cozy night with your phone nearby for the slower bits.

Materialists isn't perfect, but it's got heart and beat my low expectations!

text:
Solid 8/10 I binge-watched it yesterday, and honestly, it was wonderful. The cast is excellent-every actor feels perfectly chosen for their role-and the overall aesthetic is stunning. The fight choreography, in particular, is on another level: precise, elegant, and genuinely thrilling to watch.

I don't enjoy action movies or series as much as I used to, unless they offer truly exceptional fight scenes. This one didn't just meet that requirement-it far exceeded my expectations.

There are a few negatives, but none of them have to do with the series itself. The only downside is Netflix's business model.

Now I have to wait over a year for the next season, if-and hopefully-the financial metrics align with what the CEO wants.

That uncertainty is frustrating, especially when a show is this good..

text:
A great film true to it origins! I have been reading and owning the Fantastic Four paper comics since 1973 (when it came to Norway for the first time with norwegian translation) and up to the last one in 1987 (altogether 43 magazines/comics editions). This new film reminded me much of original happenings from these magazines. A very good adaption.

I will not give away much more, so I will reccommend you to go and see the film for yourself!

Some changes could still be seen here as in the original Fantastic Four cartoon from the 1960s in the USA (1970s in Norway), the Silver Surfer was portrayed as male, consistent with his comic book identity as Norrin Radd, the herald of Galactus.

However, in the 2025 reboot film "The Fantastic Four: First Steps", the Silver Surfer is portrayed as female, specifically the character Shalla-Bal, played by Julia Garner. This version is set in an alternate universe and represents a creative departure from the traditional depiction.

Galactus was first introduced to Norwegian readers in the comic series "Et Fantastiske Fire Eventyr" in 1973, specifically in issue #2, titled "Galactus kommer" ("Galactus is coming").

This issue featured the classic Galactus saga originally created by Stan Lee and Jack Kirby, which also introduced the Silver Surfer. It was part of the early wave of Marvel comics translated and published in Norway during the 1970s.

Looking forward for future episodes of F4 (if they come ;-) )

text: More a soap than a historical period drama It started off so promising. Lovely camera work, nice acting, but then .... The writing and directing started falling apart rapidly. Scenes started to look very over the top, the story telling very predictable, sometimes boring and sometimes even hilarious and very inconsistent. Some scenes look as if they were part of a rather bad commercial with actors looking bewildered (or like a deer in the head lights)with agonizing violins playing in the background. It's like watching a soap, but without any sense of humour. The characters are depicted so over the top, that it resembles a Disney production for kids. The bad guy is Scrooge or Cruella all over again, almost laughable. The good guy seems to have come from Homeland and plays a bi-polar role. One scene he is a social, loving and caring husband, the next scene he is a egotistical self indulging hypocrite galloping through the series on his horse. It's not the acting. Actually it is in a weird way kind of fun how the actors play these almost ridiculous and often impossible roles. Quite good in fact. A bit like a soap or a satire. So I feel a bit cheated. I wanted it to be more a historical time piece, more subtle, more realistic, less over the top. Then again, this is probably how modern entertainment is brought to us nowadays.

text:
The good, the bad, the indifferent I've been watching L&O, all seasons over the last several months, and have several opinions about the series:

Lennie Briscoe was, for most of the run of the show, the heart of it. Well, gee, everyone knew that, didn't they? Of course, but even the obvious should be restated from time to time. Jerry Orbach was much more well known for his stage work, especially in musicals (he got his start in The Fantastiks, ca. 1960) than his often overlooked film roles, but once he became Lenny, it changed his entire life. He went from an occasional supporting role to a really fine character lead. It's too bad that his health failed him just as he had the resume and acting chops to become even better known.

Second in line: Jesse Martin. Another stage musician (original cast of Rent) who grew from the "junior" detective to senior investigator, and did a fine job as both.

Of the lawyers, I'm a big fan of Jill Hennessy; it's too bad she only lasted four seasons until she got her own show (Crossing Jordan) but she showed both intensity and humor in her role. Angie Harmon I never really cared for; her character was just TOO intense for my taste. The other ADAs were okay; I preferred De La Gorza to E. Rohm, the rest were pretty equal to each other.

Waterson beat both Moriarty and Roche, that is until he took over the DA role, when McCoy became so intense that the character lost me. The other DAs were okay; my favorite was Diane Wiest, with Senator Thompson better than Steven Hill (odd, since he was not a trained actor.)

Chris Noth, I thought, was better than Bratt, who was better than Farina, who was better than Jeremy Sisto, who was in turn better than Anthony Anderson. Merkerson beat out Dan Florek, that is until her last season; the cancer thing was a distraction.

I must mention several of the "day players," especially Leslie Hendrix, John Cariani, J.K. Simmons, and, my "crush", Megan Byrne. All of them were real bright spots whenever they appeared.

I can't let Fran Liebowitz's Judge Goldberg go by without crediting her (another non-actor) for some fine comedy bits. Not bad, for three or four lines per appearance.

The entire series really took off when "Lenny" joined the cast, and started lessening in quality when Orbach left. The first two seasons were seemingly rehearsals for the main part; the last two were almost throw-a-ways. Overall, it's still my favorite series of all time.

text: Who greenlighted this mess? Nine writers put together a ten-episode parade of actors trying to figure out who their characters are. They're all at odds with each other. If I weren't stressed out, bored, confused or frustrated at all the padding (a whale?), and the cringey dialogue, I might enjoy the show. The snappy preview promised a faster pace and lots of fun situations. Just to fill in the 10-hour time allotment, they lightly touched on random social issues that don't move the plot forward. text:
Tremendous television Let me say one thing: if you had come to me a decade ago and said that Kevin Costner's flagging career would be revived thanks to his role in a modern day western, I would probably have laughed and called you crazy.

Yet it happened. Costner's John Dutton will surely go down in the annals of TV history as one of the best characters ever.

Costner played Dutton perfectly: a doting father, a ruthless ranch owner and a man who is no stranger to violence. Unforgettable.

With "Yellowstone, Taylor Sheridan has done something quite difficult: he made us care immensely about a bunch of characters of dubious moral standing.

For example, Kelly Reilly's Beth Dutton was, for the most part, a horrible person, yet you cared about what happened for her, cheered on her successes and commiserated her failures, even when said successes might have been on the wrong side of what's right.

That's because Reilly is a brilliant actress, and because she was given top-notch material to work with.

Cole Hauser, Luke Grimes, Kelsey Asbille, Wes Bentley...all brilliant.

Sheridan is a genius.

What a show. We won't see it's like again, that's for sure.
label: literal

text:
It kind of let itself down It had all the ingredients and all the elements of a good movie but it didn't quite come together to make an actual good movie. And the ending just felt lazy, like a placeholder that never got rewritten properly.

It seemed like it had a twist and some ambiguity and maybe it's this way but maybe she's doing that, maybe she's lying now maybe she was lying before, But it threw in so many obvious twists in how things were said and presented and from the performances and the edit and direction that the last second twist was obviously going to happen from like half way through so it wasn't even slightly surprising.

Then the closing montage was dumb and lazy after the lazy twist, so it was going for emotional impact but didn't produce any emotional weight whatsoever.

And the flashbacks and black and white scenes with a voiceover like a dream sequence were we supposed to believe the theme? The event? What was said by the people in the scene or what was shown or what was said in voiceover? Some seemed to be trying to show true events but made them not true by making them dumb and wrong and dream logic and they were just inconsistent and just sucked.

TLDR: Nearly good but managed not to be.

text: Phenomenal Show! There isn't too much of one note on this show and that's what makes it so enjoyable to watch (That and the beautiful Montana scenery in every episode). There's drama, suspense, sadness, love, humor, vengeance, violence, and family issues, all under an umbrella of a brilliant, and fresh modern Western.

text: Exploitative Ed Gein's real crimes were already horrific, but this series piles on invented murders (a babysitter, children, a romance) that never happened, turning him into a slasher villain. It ignores the truth: Gein was a deeply disturbed man, shaped by trauma and untreated psychosis, and in many ways a victim of the times himself. Who's to say he ever would have harmed children? By exaggerating and fictionalizing, the show disrespects both the real victims and the complexity of Gein's story.

text:
Good Stuff Just a solid no-frills vampire movie. And by "no frills" I mean it does not feel too especially mired in vampire lore. Some of these movies get way into the weeds on what is true or false about vampires, like you'll have a big scene where a vampire grabs a crucifix and loudly proclaims, "THAT WON'T WORK ON ME." That kind of stuff.

Sinners has none of that. It assumes you know what's going on and kind of leaves it at that. It feels weird to say it, but that's surprisingly refreshing for a change.

Also wild to consider that special effects for an actor playing two versions of himself in the same scene have gotten so seamless and easy to do that I didn't even think about it here. Like, I know Michael B. Jordan doesn't have a twin brother, but it's so effortless and natural that I didn't even register it as anything. A totally invisible special effect (positive).

So it's a good vampire movie, but I especially love the epilogue. It's just a cool note to hang everything on.
label: figurative

text:
An honest review from a 40+ guy who read the book Really liked it, but it's not perfect.

Hard to judge how much of the liking is because of the 80:s (like Stranger Things) nostalgia, but it's far from all of it.

+ Kids act great, especially "Ben Hanscom". Good touch and psychology in the coming of age scenes. Dark and serious social stuff in between the jump scares. Like most Steven King stories, the best parts are in between the horrors. As a member of my own hometown's "loser club", as a kid, I really felt like I was one or all of the protagonists. The film has a good heart. Pennywise is a great mix of a powerful, psychopathic, godlike entity, and a playful kid. Scary and sad at the same time. Music is good too.


* The pacing feels rushed, scenes are stacked on top of each other in a "too fast" tempo, just to stay true to the book. We don't have enough time to really get to know our young heroes. I feel this movie could really have benefited from being 30-45 minutes longer, or even better, a 5-10 hour TV series.


I think this story is hard to do justice in 2 hours of film, but it does a good job, the visuals are also great. Art direction and all.

Overall: Way, way better than the weirdly over appreciated 90:s TV series. I saw that as a teenager, who really looked forward to it as well. It sucked then, and it sucks now. This adaptation is 10 times better. Recommend it, if you like this sort of stuff.

text: Good show with some bad takes on things The show is detailed and shares a lot of relevant facts from the case. text:
Great apart from Season 3! I ate up seasons 1 and 2, they were really well done and with intriguing plots and character studies.

Season 3, however... The first episode showed a lot of promise, and I was actually looking forward to the following episodes. However, as soon as the myriad of sub plots started I quickly lost interest and almost stopped after episode 4, but I pushed through (so you won't have to).

It seems to me like the show wanted to do a general study of infamous serial killers but needed a key character for the hook, and choosing Ed Gein makes sense, seeing as he was prolific and went on to inspire many other serial killers. But the balance is way off. There's too much fluff and non-factual plots and characters in the majority of the season compared to the actual Gein aspects.

There's characters we see a few times or even just once and then never again, some only mentioned in passing, but in a way that makes them seem important, like the son of the woman teaching "Domesticated Husbandry" is mentioned as someone we're supposed to know, but I could not for the life of me remember who he was, if we'd even seen or heard of him previously.

Of course there's a lot of gratuitous scenes as well, whether they be of the sexual/sensual or gory nature, classic Murphy.

The last episode especially was atrocious, as many others have attested, particularly ripping off Mindhunter, even with Happy Anderson reprising his role as Jerry Brudos, and at first I thought they had cast Holt McCallany as well, but it was just a look-a-like.

The season seems to practically celebrate Ed Gein as well as painting him as someone we should feel sorry for. Very little time is spent on the repercussions surrounding the victims and their families, as if they are just an afterthought or even entirely irrelevant.

When it comes to directing and writing, it was just messy, too many too blurred lines between reality and hallucinations to such a degree it was difficult to know how much of Ed's social life was real and how much of it was in his head.

I've had a lot of issues with several of Murphy's productions over the past few years and honestly think he has run out of original creativity and has just gotten used to churning out shows, making money and then moving on to the next. I really miss the earlier days of his stuff, the first four seasons of AHS were amazing for example. I wish the whole Murphy production team would take a break for a few years and come back with, hopefully, renewed creative juices!

I'd probably give seasons 1 and 2 a rating of 7-8 and I can't rate season 3 higher than a 2.
label: literal

text: Lovely, Heartfelt Comedy Anyone in senior living can tell you that the day to day happenings are crazy, much like what you will see in this show! Every resident has a tough first day, isn't welcome to sit at the dining room tables because there is ALWAYS an unspoken seating chart that no one explains. It's couldn't have been easy but Michael Schur was able to convey the complexities of aging, memory issues, death, friendship, and family relationships brilliantly. text:
Are horror films getting worse? I've been catching up on a lot of missed horror films lately, and the disappointment in the ongoing trope-leverage sinks deeper. From Barbarian to Longlegs to The Monkey, all these colossal borefests have lost touch of what horror is supposed to be: scary. Add Shelby Oaks to this list, and quite possibly the biggest offender. Nothing happens in this movie. Nothing. Even the revelation in the finale means nothing. It's another "that's it?" ending that is simply stupid.

One extra star for actress Camille Sullivan who has the arduous task of putting this whole movie on her shoulders and pulls it off. She remained engaging even when the film was reaching critical eye-rolling trope levels.

I don't know anything about Stuckmann, but read the reviews about he's some YouTuber who talks about what's wrong with horror films. Well he just contributed with his cliche, well, everything. I've seen this movie remade a thousand times, only it's a Frankenstein patch up comprised of everything you're used to seeing and the pace could not have been more pointless. It did not induce the fear. This is a YouTube movie that could've been made for $100k and run for 20 mins. Such an ineffectual addition to the genre.

What??? The dialogue is totally unbelievable- f bombs we're rare in Dublin in the 1960's let alone a century earlier.

Also, the paper note on the door ( there's no Goof section yet ) reads " an chÃ©ad uair eile" which is grammatically & linguistically correct for late 20th century Irish; but before then would have been spelled ( spelt?) without the h and the dot over the letter I. Hard to explain but there it is.

Our city was named Dubh Linn in Irish , but the dot over the b rendered it invisible - hence Dublinn, and later Dublin.

Fine English cast.

text:
One Of The Few Medical Shows That Gets It Right. I worked in EMS after training at a large teaching hospital. I rarely watch medical shows because the portrayal of medicine is so dumbed-down and inaccurate. I understand that it's a show and some license will be taken, but at least put in some effort to help me suspend disbelief. The Pitt puts in major effort to get it right (which I expect from creator of 'Southland' John Wells, one of the few cop shows that did it more accurately than most). ER's are places of extreme excitement, sadness and humor (the rat scene alone beat many comedies made today). It's fun to be a couple episodes into a medical show and looking forward to more instead of rolling my eyes and moving on.

Being Hollywood we get the usual moralizing, but most shows lecture while delivering inane dialogue with one dimensional characters. Give me a solid story in a realistic setting with great characters and I can sit through a fair share of finger-wagging. It's great seeing Noah Wylie in a hospital again, especially as a veteran doctor surrounded by fresh-faced medical rookies like he was in ER. The acting has been great from everyone. I recognize so many of these personalities from a career around this environment. The Pitt is a great new show.

One of the worst aspects of the show was the appalling ending, where the main character just gives up the ghost with not one word of summary, but just a middle class nothingness.

text:
Strong Performances, Stylish Atmosphere, but Uneven Storytelling Black Rabbit" (2025) is a dark crime drama that brings together two heavyweight actors - Jude Law and Jason Bateman. Their on-screen chemistry is definitely the strongest part of the series. The performances feel raw and layered, and the visual style creates the perfect moody atmosphere for the story. From the very first episode, the cinematography and production design pull you into a gritty world of crime, betrayal, and family secrets.

That being said, the series often struggles with pacing. Some episodes feel longer than they need to be, with flashbacks and side plots that don't always add much. At times, the writing makes characters act in ways that feel unrealistic or hard to connect with emotionally. While the show sets up suspense well, several twists are predictable, and the narrative occasionally feels overloaded with too many themes at once.

Still, there are moments of genuine tension and intensity that make the journey worth watching. If you enjoy slow-burn thrillers with strong performances and a stylish look, "Black Rabbit" will likely keep you hooked, even if the story doesn't always deliver on its full potential.

Verdict: A solid but flawed series. Worth watching for Jude Law and Jason Bateman, but don't expect a masterpiece.

Rating: 7/10.

text: "That Robin Stone...he's movin' on" The network TV news business as a sleazy cesspool, with John Phillip Law as the titular news-anchor who sleeps his way to the top. Nice idea to have Dionne Warwicke do the song vocals for this movie-adaptation of Jacqueline Susann's bestseller (a la "Valley Of The Dolls")...though it's really too bad this sudser doesn't have Patty Duke's Neely O'Hara to spike the story. "The Love Machine" is unrelievedly dull. Even the final brawl (with an Academy Award as a fight prop!) can't save it. Dyan Cannon seems embalmed in her heavy pancake make-up and cumbersome fall (although her tiny, suntanned figure is a beauty to behold), Law is a handsome block of wood, while David Hemmings is embarrassing in gay-mode as a flamboyant photographer. And where is Robin Stone walking to at the end? Is he trekking out to the waterfront to pick up some sailors? After Cannon has deflated his masculinity, it would be a safe bet. In that case, "Love Machine--The Final Episode" might have been a more interesting flick. Certainly better than this yawn-inducing snooze-opera. *1/2 from ****

text:
Sadly not quite the real deal, though it pretends it is The irritating thing about The Diplomat is that it is an opportunity lost. At a certain level much of our lives is determined by decisions over which we have no control. We might think that because 'we live in a democracy' and 'get to vote every few years' we do have that control. But it is a fiction - we do not.

Once the man or woman we vote into office, whether at a national level or a state/county or municipal level is actually in office, the 'control' we foolishly pride ourselves on having is lost. Those men or women are - almost, but not quite - autonomous.

As far as we are concerned, all they need worry about is that every four or five years (according to the electoral cycle) they need to butter us up, 'get us onside', renew our support for them, make sure we re-elect them, then it is back to making their decisions without giving us a second thought.

Certainly, there are grand claims that they 'only have the interests of the country/nation/state at heart'. But that's only true in theory: in practice they are like you and I: they are human. And the important decisions they make - as in The Diplomat over the deaths of 40 odd servicemen and woman and how to react - are sadly as much governed by the individual human quirks and failings of those in high post as by 'the principles involved'.

This series had a chance to look at and 'explain' the goings on of diplomats and politicians at the highest level and draw us in, to involve us, to help us understand. But it preferred, at the end of the day to be what is, let's be honest, just another glossy soap opera.

That is not to say a more 'realistic' portrayal of dealings at the highest level would have been dry and dull, so we, the viewer needed something 'more human'. In the right hands such a portrayal might very well have avoided being dry and dull. But The Diplomat chose not to take a chance. It went for safe.

Safe means having a dash of this - sex both real and potential, 'relationships', the semblance of 'intrigue' and so on - and hoping that given the trappings of the show - presidents, prime ministers, official residences, helicopters and so on - the viewer will accept that what The Diplomat is 'the real thing' or pretty darn close to 'the real thing'.

But it isn't: at the end of the day The Diplomat is just another - very glossy - TV show. There's nowt wrong with that, of course, except The Diplomat does pretend to be more. But it isn't. As I say from where I sit it is an opportunity missed.
label: literal

text:
Has it where it counts As cynical as I am about Disney movies, I freely admit that I liked "Moana" quite a bit. It wasn't exactly a challenge with Dwayne Johnson's involvement, but the elements that are usually a turn-off . . . weren't. The songs are good, the animation's beautiful, and the formulaic heroine with sidekicks really seem to work here.

Cynically speaking, Moana is just another princess for the Mouse's stable. Having said that, you could do with a lot worse. She's got the spunk and strong personality to be a winning character, and she really makes this an enjoyable story.

I could easily watch this again.

7/10

text:
Best Ending The ending of Black Rabbit was, in my opinion, one of the best and most balanced conclusions a series could have. It wrapped up the story in a way that felt both fair and emotionally satisfying, staying true to the characters and the journey they went through.

What stood out to me most was how the show didn't force a dramatic twist just for shock value. Instead, it gave each character the resolution they earned, and the choices they made throughout the story truly mattered in the end. The finale managed to deliver closure without losing the emotional depth that made the series special.

In an age where so many shows stumble at the finish line, Black Rabbit ended with honesty, justice, and heart. It was the kind of ending that makes you sit quietly for a few moments after the screen fades to black - not because you're confused, but because you're satisfied.
label: figurative

text:
Nothing else but all Love for this film! It was absolutely worth the year-long wait. After the goosebumps I got from Wicked Part 1, I already had high expectations and watching this one in IMAX made the experience even more magical. I knew it was going to be great, and it truly delivered.

The music in this film is phenomenal. Every song fits perfectly, but for me, nothing will ever top "Defying Gravity" and "The Wizard and I." Those two songs remain unmatched-they're the heart-stopping, mind-blowing moments of the entire franchise.

What I loved most about this movie is how much it centers on Elphaba and Glinda and their friendship, their connection, and how their choices shape their world. Even when Dorothy enters the picture, the story never strays from the two of them. It's their journey, their bond, and their heartbreak that hold the film together.

The ending still hit hard, even though I already knew what was coming from part one. Watching Glinda break down over what happened to Elphaba was sad, but it also felt right for both of them. It was painful, but it made sense-for their good, and for the story.

Overall, Wicked: For Good is truly one of the best films of the year. The wait was worth every second, and I really hope it finally gets the recognition it deserves. This movie is pure magic.
label: figurative

text:
It's a special show I, like most people, enjoy shows the most when they have a combination of certain elements; quality acting, a topic of interest to me, a fitting soundtrack, proper character development, etc. Above all of those qualities though, sits the most important aspect of a television series or movie - the ability to draw emotional involvement from the viewer. A select few have had the capacity to foster the bittersweet happiness that comes from finishing something you've been so invested in. It's an odd thing when something can evoke sadness - and yet a sadness you don't wish to push away, but to wallow in, if at least for a little while. Stranger Things has met that mark.

A particularly interesting part of this series is the journey of maturation the child actors are partaking in. It goes without saying that Millie Bobby Brown is a shooting star in the acting world and is far from her zenith. The rest of the party performs laudably, and seeing them get their big break is a fun thing to behold.

David Harbour complements Millie's performance with a terrific effort as Chief Jim Hopper. Both excel in portraying the qualities which define what it is to be human; the idiosyncrasies, the varied nature of our individual capabilities, and the ways in which we cope with these strengths and weaknesses.

The plot of the show, while not bad, fails to live up to the far-reaching standards of the other aspects. Especially in Season Three, it seems a struggle to find ways to continue the plot; sometimes resulting in contrived and lackluster turns. Despite these shortcomings, this show remains a phenomenon which I'm happy to have experienced.
label: figurative

text:
A brilliant series (ruined by its final season) Gilmore Girls is a heartwarming, coming-of-age dramedy with top "rewatchability" factor. It's got charm, fast-paced banter and a slew of well-rounded female characters.

That said, beware the final season where it loses most of the things that made it loveable.

While it was also ahead of its time, it was still (in some ways) a show of its time - so expect a rare handful of jokes that haven't dated too well.

Overall, would recommend it for most of everyone as a well-loved and feel-good classic.
label: literal

text: Suspend Reality Jane Wyman is stiff and motionless both before and after becoming blind. She reacts to bad news as though someone has just told her the morning paper has been mislaid. She seems so much older than Rock Hudson that the love interest between them is unbelievable and seems silly. I thought she seems old enough to be his mother. Why do blind people in movies not recognize the voice of someone known prior to blindness? This also makes the story unbelievable. There is much music, mostly Chopin, in the background (coming to the foreground frequently). Rock Hudson's car is one of the most interesting items in this movie. A blind person would surely recognize the sound, smell, feel of a car like this! Based on this car and Hudson's valiant work to carry this movie, I give this a 5 star rating.

text:
A Charming Criminal I dare to say that this is Channing Tatum's best performance in his career.

Jeffrey Manchester is an American convicted spree-robber, former US Army soldier and professional thief who became famous for breaking into his target locations by drilling through the roofs. All this happened in real life and was featured in the news. I personally remember hearing about the story.

It's a peculiar, unique, charming story of a real life criminal who ended up living in a Toy store after escaping jail.

Channing Tatum's performance will have you rooting for him, its a fun drama with funny moments, suspense and nostalagia. Kirsten Dunst does a good job with her character and Peter Dinklage is great as well.

I highly recommend it, its on my top 5 of 2025.

Some nice photography. Acted well. But like the burger, 2 1/2 hrs later, unsatisfying.

text: It is not black or white, it is not grey, it's colourless The war of perspectives, the war of manipulation, the war of words. The war which is fought before the war starts, in the minds. Beautifully directed, written and exceptionally presented. The character building, from hate to admiration to worship, was elegantly crafted. This is not a movie, this is a window to peak into our own past. This movie is not for mere entertainment, but for understanding. "I am a prisoner because you won and we lost, not because you are morally superior". The realization of gravity of this statement is the essence of the movie. A treat for WW2 enthusiasts, and spine chilling experience for others. A Must Must watch in theaters.

text:
This is a painful addition to the action genre XXx (2002) is a movie I recently rewatched for the first time in a long time on Tubi. The storyline follows an extreme sports vigilante of sorts who is hired by the government to infiltrate an international crime ring, discover their ambitions and help stop them.

This movie is directed by Rob Cohen (Dragonheart) and stars Vin Diesel (Pitch Black), Samuel L. Jackson (Pulp Fiction), Marton Csokas (The Equalizer), Asia Argento (Land of the Dead) and Danny Trejo (Machete).

This concept was awful and many of the action scenes are too over the top and ridiculous. There are some great special effects and action scenes. The soundtrack is awesome too. The Danny Trejo scene was hilarious and his use of "Mr. Funny Guy" always cracks me up.

"Bitches come" is also a legendary quote from this movie. Argento's character's evolution didn't make sense based on her background and the one-liners were really bad. The ending also isn't good.

This is a painful addition to the action genre where if felt like the studios were just trying to take advantage of X Games premises at the time and the success of The Fast and Furious. I would score this a 3/10 and recommend skipping this.
label: literal

text:
Traded One Prison for Another A down-on-his-luck veteran turns to a life of crime to support his family, adopting a method that earns him the nickname "Roofman." After his luck runs out and he spends some time in prison, he decides to escape and seek freedom. While on the run, he falls for a single mother and adopts her family as his own, risking it all for a sense of belonging.

This true crime comedy is a great way to share the story of Roofman. The story seems impossible, but Jeffrey Manchester managed to do it. There is a lot of comedy and fun throughout, with some drama mixed in to drive home the gravity of his actions. The two-hour and six-minute runtime is excessive, where parts of the movie feel stretched with no added benefit. The true story is entertaining and captivating enough for a stream when available.
label: literal

text:
if Steve Martin and Martin Short collaborate, then you're in for something good And boy are you with "Only Murders in the Building"! This clever miniseries is a parody of/homage to true crime podcasts, with Martin's and Short's characters (along with a young woman played by Selena Gomez) investigating a murder in their New York apartment building. Plenty of surprises are in store, and there's great chemistry among the cast members (including some guest stars).

You're sure to love every part of it.

text: Amazing Series I really didn't think I'd like this series as I'm not particularly a fan of any western cowboy and Indian type programmes or films. But after a million recommendations, I'm so glad I tried it. I quickly became a huge fan of the family, the land and how much it meant to them. The work they put into keeping the ranch going was incredible. I must say that Beth was ultimately my favourite character all throughout with her savageness. Watching and hearing what she'd been through and then watching her settle down was lovely. I won't name anything as I don't want to spoil for anyone deciding if they want to watch. The only thing I was deeply upset about was John Duttons exit as it seemed very abrupt but now that I know what happened behind the scenes it makes sense why things went the way that they did and it was a brilliant story line. If John Dutton had survived I would of rated a 10 lol.

text:

The scenery is so idyllic. And there's a little romance too!

The Police Chief is a divorcee from a big city, who moved to this quaint sea town. The love interest is the town librarian who is hesitant to get involved with him, but of course, they get together.

Love the characters and the actors.

I still can't get over the police chief being Donald Sutherland's son.

I hope it is given a second season and time to develop further.

text:
Every technical and style detail is wrong. They obviously did not use any sort of technical experts or cultural advisors. Not about law enforcement, aviation, wilderness search and rescue, not even hospital operations. It's clear they never spoke to anyone from Alaska or that knew anything about Fairbanks.

I get the need for creative story telling choices. But every single thing they got wrong and not just a little wrong, there was no creativity or artistic choices. The prop and production staff were clearly using by-the-book out of date style guides not intended for location driven stories. It would have worked fine for a generic police procedural set in a nondescript mainland/lower 48 urban landscape where prop and location details don't matter. But they got everything wrong.

One example; the theft of the aircraft black box, they showed the "ambush" taking place on a small bridge on narrow road. In reality the road from where they put their location and "on the way to Anchorage" would have been the Park's Highway, very wide, very flat, with the vegetation further cut back from the pavement.

It wouldn't have impressed production to use technical advisors and at the very least local knowledge. The last season of True Detective took place in Alaska while being filmed in Iceland. It was visually very different from Alaska they still managed to capture some of the feeling of a large Alaskan village.
label: literal

text:
Not About Death, Rather How We Live The movie hits like a gut punch. Brutal, unrelenting, and strangely beautiful-I came away numb, but in awe.

It's superbly written and brilliantly acted, all the more impressive given that almost the entire film takes place on the road. The premise is simple and clear from the start, but the real hook is the characters. You find yourself attached almost instantly-some you like straight away, others not at all-until they reveal their true selves, and suddenly you can't help but care for them.

At first, I saw it as a terrifying mirror of where the world could be headed. A dystopia where survival is reduced to endurance, where the system can't sustain everyone, and where lives are stripped down to a brutal contest of who can keep going the longest. It's a chilling thought, and one that feels uncomfortably close at times.

But somewhere along the way, the film became less about how scary the world might become, and more about how to get through it. What really struck me is that those who seem most at peace near the end of their journey aren't the strongest, the fastest, or the fiercest competitors. They're the ones who care for others, who seek genuine friendship, who invest in the people around them. That's what makes the walk bearable. That's what makes it meaningful.

And here's the kicker: whether or not you would choose to play the game in The Long Walk, you're already playing a version of it. We're all walking, step by step, burning energy to stay in the race. We push forward, hoping to outlast, to achieve, to matter-knowing full well that the finish line is the same for everyone.

The only real question is: how do you choose to walk your walk?
label: figurative

text: Strong, Emotional, Deep, Meaningful With its emotional and meaningful story about strong bonds of brotherhood, it resembles life rather than a TV series. It is the most amazing production I have ever watched and it has a big place in my life. We have a lot of similarities with the character Sam. It was an unforgettable series with the harmonious chemistry of Sam and his older brother Dean and interesting characters. My first favorite is season 7. Although each season was enjoyable in its own way, I liked some of them more. Sam is deeply devoted to his brother and is always ready to make sacrifices for him. There's nothing Dean wouldn't do for Sam. They are always there for each other. Sam, who is rebellious, emotional and has a hard-to-control anger, and his aggressive, sweet-loving hero older brother Dean, who protects him, become the nightmare of the villains. Thank you Supernatural for 15 seasons.
