text:
Disappointing Ending - Season 5 Finale of Poldark The final season of Poldark was a huge letdown for many fans, including myself. Several key aspects of the story felt rushed, underdeveloped, and unsatisfying. Here are some of the main issues I had with the finale: 1. Unnecessary Storylines: The plot involving Officer Ned felt irrelevant to the season. There was a missed opportunity to focus more on Ross and his family's journey to restore their wealth and legacy.

2. Morrwenna's Inconsistent Behavior: Morrwenna's sudden change of heart regarding her son was jarring. I was expecting a more substantial reunion or a clearer decision, but instead, it was a confusing back-and-forth.

3. George Warleggan's Fate: Given his many crimes throughout the series, I was disappointed that George wasn't jailed in the final season. A more fitting consequence for his actions seemed warranted.

4. The Children's Inexplicable Stagnation: It felt like time stood still for Ross and Demelza's children. Despite the passing of time, they remained unchanged, while other characters' children grew noticeably.

5. The Closure of Trenwith: After George's imprisonment, it would have made sense for Ross to inherit Trenwith and raise Jeffrey Charles there. Instead, the whole storyline was left hanging.

6. Jeffrey Charles and the Girl: Jeffrey Charles' relationship felt rushed and shallow. His interaction with the girl he loves, where she brushes off their connection as a mere infatuation, was a disappointing way to end their story.

7. Missed Potential with Key Characters: Several key characters, were written off without proper closure. The show often introduced characters and plotlines, only to abandon them with no real explanation.

Overall, the final season felt like a missed opportunity. The storylines that were built up over the years deserved more respect and attention. The ending felt forced and left me with a sense of dissatisfaction.
label: figurative

text:
A Riveting Ride into the Alaskan Wilds - A Must-Watch Thriller From the very first moments, The Last Frontier grips you with tension, danger, and emotional depth. Jason Clarke delivers a powerhouse performance as U. S. Marshal Frank Remnick - equal parts steely lawman and deeply wounded family man. He carries the series with a magnetic presence, giving the show much more than just procedural muscle.

Dominic Cooper is a standout in his role, injecting nuance and charm even as his character operates in morally gray territory. His scenes crackle with energy, and every moment he shares onscreen with Clarke or Bennett feels electric.

Haley Bennett as the lead actress (CIA operative Sidney Scofield) rounds out the central trio beautifully. She balances toughness and vulnerability in a way that makes her character feel both unpredictable and empathetic. She never feels like a "sidekick" - in her own right, she's an emotional anchor for the story, giving voice to the series' stakes beyond just action and survival.

What truly elevates The Last Frontier is how it marries natural suspense with human drama. The vast, icy wilderness becomes a third character - relentless, unforgiving, and hauntingly beautiful. Yet even in the cold, there are warm moments: familial tension, grief, betrayal, and alliances testing under strain.

Yes, the plot leans on familiar tropes (escaped inmates, backcountry chases, conspiracies), but the cast imbues every scene with a spark that keeps you leaning forward. The pacing is strong; the action sequences are visceral; and the quieter interludes, where characters face their fears or regrets, are the ones that really stick.

If you're looking for a thriller that delivers both spectacle and soul, The Last Frontier - anchored by Clarke, Cooper, and Bennett - should be at the top of your watchlist.
label: figurative

text: Heart Wrenching I was totally mesmerized by this movie, I believe this will be the movie of the 2025 year, and rack up award nominations. text:
It's starting out very well. I'm a long time fan of Steve Martin and Martin Short so I had to check out this series. Their past collaborations are electric. Im not aware of Selena Gomez's work but I know WHO she is.

After reading other reviews, it's fairly obvious there are many Selena fans who wanted to voice their overwhelming approval of her performance to pad the rating. Those "reviews" stand out because they are not really reviews, just kudos because they are ardent fans. Tell us WHY you liked it!!!! I'm sure many who stated such and also stating their admiration for the other leads' past work was a token. I can't imagine the fandom realistically includes legendary septuagenarian comedic movie and stage actors and a Disney popstar. If I had a dollar for everytime I read the word "amazing", I could produce the show.

I digress - this show, after 3 episodes is fabulous!! I hate most TV shows created in recent years. Comedies are formulaic, recycled crap. Drama is redundant and stale. I give some with an interesting premise a chance - 99.9% fail. The ONLY network shows I like now are NCIS, the original, and Young Sheldon. Streaming: Stranger Things and Alien TV. Yes, I'm odd that way. Castle Rock was cancelled, so.... I love quirky original concepts like 3rd Rock from the Sun, Big Bang Theory, the aforementioned Stranger Things and Alien TV ,etc. This show has it all. It's hilarious, dramatic, thrilling, mysterious, eclectic, thatrical and insane all at the same time. It's a definite rollercoaster ride of emotions. If you didn't bust a rib with the cats "arrival" on scene then you are dead inside.

Steve Martin is his usual sardonic self and teaming him with Martin Short's over-the-top theatrics - their sarcastic banter is always entertaining, add to that Selena Gomez's deadpan snarky often dismissive repartee with them is priceless!! They have fantastic chemistry for their 3 very distinct personality types. I'm quite impressed at her ability to hold her own with these two and it was so refreshing to hear a young woman have a lower register voice for once and NOT hearing "super" this and that constantly. C'mon people, there are other synonyms for that word. It makes you sound silly and unintelligent.

The storyline kept my attention and I love how they cut to each characters unique perspective in interpreting the clues they have; Short "auditioning" the tenants and Selena's visions/delusions. They throw in backstories with flashbacks and ambiguous habits to build the character profiles.

Finally, the supporting cast - masterful casting in my opinion. The tenants are the kookiest group of people you could ever imagine and they all live in the same building!!! Nathan Lane AND Sting as well!! Great!!

I was sad when episode 3 ended, I now have to wait until next week but it's worth it. You never know what will happen scene to scene or for that matter, what may come out of their mouth.

So yes, millennials and Gen Z...Selena was AMAZING!!!! So are the rest.
label: figurative

text:
Average but cult SF action flick Arnold Schwarzenegger, Maria Conchita Alonso, Jesse Ventura and Sven-Ole Thorsen. No, I didn't watch Predator again. :D

Futuristic action movie based on Steven King's story, published under pseudonym Richard Bachman, tells a story about modern gladiator games in which convicts get a chance to win their freedom if they survive the arena. Movie about totalitarian regime, media monopoly and a world at the edge of ecological and economical disaster. And about always current 'panem et circenses' tactics. It was made in 1987. and story is placed in 2017. Once described future comes to pass, futuristic movies usually become unconvincing, but not this one. Although actual 2017. and 2017. in this movie seemingly have no touch points, difference is only in appearance, while essentially they are much more alike than we are comfortable to admit.

"Schwarzenegger rising, with his criminal one-liners, which had already developed their own personality and received a fee on separate bank account." - Aleksandar UroÂševiÄ‡

If you are searching for top cinematography better pass this flick, but within the genre it's pretty good and, if you are looking just for good entertainment with decent plot, I warmly recommend it.

6/10

text:
Enjoyable In two previous films we've seen how the Four Horsemen group of stage magicians/performance artists use stage magic/illusions to carry out large-scale hoaxes, heists, capers, performances in order to exact justice upon unethical power players and wealth hoarders. Well, they're back. Or, to be more precise, a group of young wannabes pretending to be the Horsemen is back. And the target this time turns out to be South African diamond magnate, money launderer, blood diamond facilitator, and all-round nasty b*tch Veronika Vandenberg.

To be honest, much of the plot is a bit far-fetched, and many questions remain unanswered. But it's a good enough excuse to see all our old friends back in action, together with some new ones. The set design is great (particularly Chateau Roussillon), the set-pieces are fun, Rosamund Pike chews the scenery nicely, and the aggressive interplay between Bosco and Atlas works well.

I classify this as undemandingly enjoyable, particularly if you enjoyed the first two.

text: Cournerstone of all modern TV series It took me around two years to complete the series, but I think it was for the better. I was kind of not used to this TV-show structure where the episodes are more like a series of discrete, independent from one another, complete mini-stories with barely palpable main plot thread happening somewhere in the background sewing all the episodes into one fabric of a cohesive world. That being said, I feel like I lost nothing by not binge-watching the whole series in a matter of weeks. Since there wasn't any intricated and convoluted story many details of which I would had to remember in order to enjoy it, I gave myself time to savour each episode independently from one another. Initially, you may not grasp the greatness of "The Sopranos", but as the seasons pass, the multifaceted and deep characters start to grow on you, levaing you no choice but to appreciate the genius of the scriptwriting as well as the perfomance of the actors it was written for. Take, for example James Gandolfini, who seems to have been born for the role of Tony Soprano. I don't think it would be an exaggeration to say that his performance in the show is the most prominent in all of the history of television. As a result, "The Sopranos" transformed the industry and set a new standard for TV series to strive for.
label: figurative

text:
Bad Premise. Bad ending. Bad Bad. 'Nuremberg' does not work. Here's why.

1. The premise. If the USA Prosecutor (played by Michael Shannon) cannot 'win' in the trial of The Nazi High Command (primarily Hermann Goering (played by Russell Crowe)), then .... then ... then what? Does a 'loss' mean that the former Nazis will all walk free? Do you want the viewer to believe that they would not be executed in any case? Ridiculous. But there's more.

2. Premise #2. In order to guarantee victory in the courtroom, the US asks an Army psychiatrist (Ramy Melek) to work with Goering; a way to learn more about him as a man, and so obtain information to be used against him in court. Again, ridiculous. But wait, wait for this.

3. What the psychiatrist learns from Goering does indeed help to 'convict' him. But the real incriminating information does not come from the psychiatrist's findings, rather it comes from a statement read aloud by the Prosecuting Attorney representing the United Kingdom. And so the premise of the U. S. shrink infiltrating the Nazi's mind, and this being the most important event in the trial, this goes for naught. Goering does himself in. But his fellow Nazis were going to be put to death, because of the U. K.'s revelations. And - this is not a spoiler, it's public record - they were.

A waste of talent, a waste of time.
label: literal

For one, the supporting cast were uneven in their performances. Some were good; others were not very memorable, and in a few cases even painful to watch.

Which means that Danson and Beatriz really had to carry the show. They don't quite succeed. I think that's because the script wasn't as exemplary as it needed to be.

And so, unfortunately, the dynamics between Danson and Beatriz's characters weren't really there. The two actors didn't even have many scenes together.

text:
Yellowstone - The best of Bonanza, Dallas, and Dynasty The Dutton family (the father, three sons, and a daughter) has philosophical, positional, and financial differences. The father (Kevin Costner as John Dutton) is a resolute leader, and his children share his determination and loyalty, but differ on the means to solutions. One son (Luke Grimes as Cory Dutton) finds himself outside the clan; but when his family loyalty is tested, he proves himself but at great expense.

Taylor Sheridan (Wind River, Hell or High Water, and Sicario) has done it again (creating a very interesting story with great action). His characters seem so real; and the dilemmas they face are so complex, but understandable. You actually feel Cory's pain when he is torn between his wife (and her Native American relatives) and his family. S1 E1 has a very emotional scene (Cory and his wife) that no one will dismiss; it's so real and well-acted.

Finally, no one does a better job presenting a gun fight than Taylor Sheridan. Taylor knows guns and he knows what happens when guns are fired. The gunfight in Wind River was exceptional, and Mr. Sheridan presents the same authenticity in Yellowstone.
label: literal

text:
The connections to original NCIS So far so great! I actually had the privilege of vising the set on a recent trip to Paramount Studios and it was mind blowing to see the actual office sets.

A few of the details in NCIS Origins have been changed from NCIS, but so far not enough to alter history, Vis-Ã -vis, Star Trek (2009) vs. The original series.

The series does a good job of filling in some of Gibbs's back story from the original, but Austin Stowell has not yet transitioned Gibbs the cold, no nonsense, loner that Mark Harmon portrays. Can you picture the Gibbs we know going out with the team socially, attending veteran support meetings, and going by his first name Leroy? It will be interesting to see the transition as the series hopefully progresses.

The best character crossover so far is Kyle Schmid to Muse Watson's Mike Franks. The attitude and physical appearance make for good continuity. Though we only see Muse Watson in one episode as a NIS agent, the connection is there. Some details like his dress code seem altered in Origins but, again, not universe altering.

It will be very interesting to see the introduction of more of the characters we know and love from the original series.
label: figurative

text:
Hard to care about the characters I finished this series, it was good enough for that, and I'm a huge fan of Jason Bateman and Jude Law, but I didn't binge the series and it had very slow moments. I don't mind slow, but because these characters were unlikeable, I didn't really care about sifting through the slow, relationship-building moments.

These characters have huge flaws and the only redeeming quality is their loyalty to each other. They were annoying often, made a lot of dumb decisions, and constantly went back and forth between being terrified/stressed to laughing and joking like nothing happened.

Didn't care for the ending either, maybe because I didn't care about the characters. I felt like Jude Law's ending was too simple and kind of empty.

If you're looking for something to watch, it's definitely entertaining enough for that, but it's not as gripping as it wants to be and you may find yourself sighing with frustration a lot. But although I didn't care for the ending, the last 2-3 episodes were gripping in the way I wanted the whole series to be. So if you can stick it out, it gets a lot more fun to watch then.

love the kung fu action In 1764, the beast arrives in France. In one year, the fear has spread far sending the region of GÃ©vaudan into darkness. text:
Top TV Shows of All Time I am not one to beat around the bush so here it goes:

This show is epic in its entirety. The writing, characters, plot, cinematography, the pacing and the incredible transformation just pushes this show into a league of it's own. It takes you into a world we haven't quite ever seen before, a world where the sad and unaccomplished Walter White turns into a genius mad-man. You can see the character evolve into a selfish, power-hungry villain who you just love to hate. Vince Gilligan did an amazing job not following the lead of most tv shows out there right now. He knew how to build a story without making you feel like you are underwhelmed and when he knew it was time for this show to end (although I felt a hole in my heart for days after the finale), he didn't care about the money or the fans or the critics, he just ended it the exact moment it was supposed to end.

Bryan Cranston is a power house and completely embodies first Walter White, and later Heisenberg to such amazing heights, you really cannot see anyone else acting this part. That is what, I believe, sets his character apart from most characters we see on TV. He dominates every episode and that is not the say that the rest of the cast don't put in their best efforts (they are all amazing in their own way), but he just has this energy that is undeniable and you cannot help but root for him and the crazy plans he comes up with.

Epic is the only one word you can use to describe a show like this. The only show I feel sometimes touches the bar of this pure excellence, is Vikings and it still does not come close to how well thought out Breaking Bad as a whole series truly is.
label: literal

text:
Wings of Disinterest Wim Wender's "Wings of Desire" has spoiled angel movies for me. It was so beautiful and so thought provoking that all other angel movies have been a "meh" for me. "Good Fortune" is the same.

I'd describe it as "watchable." - It's got a wonderful cast and they are funny. Keaneu Reeves quirky acting style gives his angel character uniqueness. Keke Palmer was the highlight and the only character I cared much about. Aziz Ansari's limited acting range holds back the movie a little. I think Seth Rogan was supposed to be an unlikable antagonist to Aziz Ansari but I didn't find myself hating or liking either one. I adore Sandra Oh but the script didn't give her much to work with.

The movie is a commentary on late-stage capitalism which is a solid concept but I didn't get any insights or feel any compelling emotions beyond "the system stinks."

I know "Good Fortune" is getting decent reviews but maybe those people never saw Wim Wender's masterpiece.
label: figurative

text:
A different approach to horror genre Sinners is a historical horror directed by Ryan Coogler (Black Panther, Creed) which smartly combines the supernatural with the political.

The cinematography is stunning, which accurately captures the 1930s western vibes. While the movie starts pretty slow and takes time for the build up, it picks up in the second half by delivering a haunting experience. The movie often feels very lively due to it's musical numbers.

The film's fascinating array of genres and tropes and ideas swirls together, whether be it oppression of race, or preaching of good and evil. Jordan gives a great performance, while the rest of the cast were terrific too.

Although the horror element was less than my expectations, however the political satire and the tense atmosphere makes Sinners a great movie.

The Geek Reviewer gives 4 stars for 'Sinners'.

text:
What a fun movie... Having gone through the little league stage with my son and his friends, I thought this was really a touching and wonderful movie about what boys love to do in the summer, organized or not.  We could relate to it since we have the quiet athletic one in the family and the other characters we've all known in one fashion or another.  The goofy loud one, the pint-sized one with the stand-out ears, and the serious one without much of a father around.  Loved it - and loved the James Earl Jones part.  What a joyful laugh he has!

If you love kids, love baseball, love summer, and love a nice warm film, see it.  It has ended up in our library of films we watch again and again. Makes me smile thinking of it!

text:
Firefighters and their daily lives Five seasons of this were refreshing and original making for entrancing, exciting and entertaining television. At launch it was a novel concept and a little ground breaking with a genuine presentation of female firefighters alongside their male counterparts. A strong blend of fire station procedural elements with the daily trials and tribulations of a decent ensemble cast.

Some great characters, particularly the fabulous portrayal of Gabriela Dawson by Monica Raymund who anchored the show for me.

Season six lost its sparkle and I only watched four episodes of seven before giving up; still not sure if the show got worse, got repetitive or 'it's not you it's me' took over - likely a blend of all three.

text:
This show likes itself way too much Um...I guess it's just us, but my husband and I stopped after the 3rd episode. I loved it at first but quickly realized it was just too too much. I get the realness of the chaos and stress, but it seemed like they jammed in every possible story line ever imagined. Big corporate takeover - check! Underage abortion - check! Bizarre accident - check, check, check!

And the characters -- so one dimensional. We have the stoic, tragic doctor. The straight-laced, humorless intern. The naive, farm-boy intern. The sassy, tough intern. The working-class white male racist. The no-nonsense head nurse. Single-minded hospital administrator. Hot young doctor. Hot older doctor. Hot maverick doctor.

I also found the acting over the top. The episode with the brother and sister debating whether to take their father off life support was enough for me. The actor playing the sister was too unbelievable, the sibling relationship was unconvincing, and the soliloquies to the dying father were straight out of a Hallmark Channel movie. Ugh.

Every character is so bloody earnest; makes it so unbelievable and inauthentic.

I get that the lack of subtlety or nuance is a big part of the appeal, but it turned us off.
label: literal

text:
Couldn't wait for it to end. I really couldn't wait for this to end, I felt it just dragged on & on forever, I felt I had been watching it for 20 years by the time it finally finished.

It started of OK, a black comedy but then it just got more and more serious and more and more nastier with more and more annoying accents and characters with each episode, music became less and less as episode one started with some good tunes. Constantly hearing Jesse scream yo, bitch, was making my head feel like it wanted to explode.

Really I found it all a bit daft, going round and round in circles and about 2 episodes too long. Maybe it's a cultural thing but it really didn't do a great deal for me though it was good in places, Walt played his part well turning from a nice man into a total back stabbing pos by the end.

Both my Mrs and I were relieved when it came to end, it was OK, but not as great as the hype suggest. The main message, crime doesn't pay unless your a politician.

text:
Another Expensive Reboot with Nothing to Say Yet another costly reinterpretation of a story we've already seen and re-seen hundreds of times. Frankenstein 2025 fits the current trend where every director feels compelled to "sign" a classic, reshaping it in their own image - not out of necessity, but out of vanity. The result is a film that feels purely commercial, with millions spent on visuals and production, but nothing new to express.

The ending is artificial and incoherent, pushing the central idea - an inhuman being who is somehow human - to such extremes that it collapses under its own weight. There's no emotional core, no narrative tension, just a virtual spectacle.

This film reflects a time when cinema no longer renews itself but recycles myths into hollow simulations. It's not storytelling - it's aesthetic posturing. In this context, cinema feels stillborn.
label: literal

text:
Wow! Great series of 1880 politics and the Forgotten President James Garfield Outstanding. I recommend reading a synopsis of James Garfield first, as that helps provide more context and insight on the times and the names of historical figures.

Absolutely brilliant series. The actors, writers, director and crew brought together great production values! From what they put together I think this series, along with Lincoln with Daniel Day Lewis should be shown as a teaching medium to school students. The politics of now is no different to 145 years ago- polarized, divided, and ineffective. Can we not get along, and make our great country stronger? A question then, as now, and this series shows the actors and writers elegantly working through that question.

Well done in every aspect- I am not political at all, and this series was an excellent example of entertainment and teaching all in one!

text:
A welcome sequel that captures the fun and quality of the original, but doesn't bring much new to the table to make it truly stand out. Nobody was an unexpected delight, elevated by the legendary Bob Odenkirk as the iconic and likable protagonist. The continuation takes the traditional sequel route of being bigger, louder, and doubling down on everything that worked the first time. That doesn't necessarily make it better, but it's still a lot of fun-just not as refreshing.

The film repeats many of the same story beats as the original, which works both for and against it. On one hand, it maintains the charm of the first; on the other, it feels a little too familiar.

The cast is once again the highlight, with secondary characters getting more to do, and Sharon Stone stepping in as a memorable new villain.

The ending, however, feels a bit too rushed considering the buildup.

Overall, it's a welcome sequel that captures the fun and quality of the original, but doesn't bring much new to the table to make it truly stand out.
label: literal

text:
Dark escapism with a shattering message at its core Two working class cousins, one of them a highly motivated activist and the younger one being mentally challenged, live in squalor together in Atlanta. The activist cousin, embracing intergalactic conspiracy theories, devises a highly quixotic kidnapping scheme in which the CEO of a prominent biochemical company is the target. He and his cousin undertake this puzzling endeavor. A genteel and majestic soundtrack belies the film's most seedy surroundings.

Jesse Plemons is raggedly creepy and pitiable as the kidnapping mastermind. Emma Stone is fierce as the brilliant CEO who doesn't roll over for her captors. Aidan Delbis is exceptional as the simple-minded cousin who becomes a mere mercenary. Stavros Halkias is effective as a good-natured but diligent local cop. An intertwining theme of class warfare and emotional bullying is starkly evident in the scenes between Plemons and Stone.

Yorgos Lanthimos can surprise his audience no matter what his approach is or the scale of his ambition. Here, just when you think you know where Lanthimos is going, his film becomes genre-bending and takes on new significance and an angle that we didn't see coming. To be sure, Lanthimos ultimately reinforces his clinical perspective, but in a way that subverts our expectations. Notwithstanding this mountain of misery and excess, the film does take moments to express wonder. After this, I might never look at honeybees the same way again. Highly recommended to viewers with thick skin and an open mind.
label: literal

text:
Please stay on the air.... Absolutely one of the most ground breaking bad ass shows on the screen, (pardon the pun). Definitely not for everyone but finally something that feels real.

I personally like the fact they pull no punches. I find myself pausing at the fact that I am so intrigued by this hard core street wise program, more than any of the other big name series. This one really hits home and gives a true behind the scenes look at what most would consider the bad guys. I'm not condoning the contents of the story, and I don't think the show is either, there is no glamor in what these boys are doing, but it's giving an insight to the darker side of many streets. 

How the denial and desperation that can occur to the common working stand up citizen, the pillar of society that suddenly changes his moral standing in a society driven by the almighty dollar. This is pretty dam close to Fallen (Michel Douglas) but with up to date street smarts nd a lot more punch. 

The characters don't over exaggerate their roles and the story line isn't filled with cleaver dialog or near to impossible feats of bravery or beating impossible odds. Just true to life screwed up events that could take place in the real world. I think they did their research on this one. Good work everyone. 

I hope we get more than a second and third season out of this great crew (every one of them). From the writing and production sets to the acting, costumes, lighting, filming and originality. I've seen a few good series lost to the wrong decision makers, hope this one doesn't end up short (long live FireFly)

Chuckbytes
label: literal

text:
Quite enjoyable, would have worked better as a series It is good, but as the film progressed I started noticing how things didn't add up.

First of all, as usual per Netflix, they release a film with a story that clearly would have been better if it was released as a series.

That is because, despite Zoey and Mira being protagonists of this film, we do not see that much character development for them, still better than the other members from the Saja Boys that are early on hinted to have personalities - like the dude with the abs -, only for them to barely speak again later on.

So we are left with the both "main characters" Rumi and Jinu, so why is Rumi's character development so broken? As in, why does it feel like elements to properly develop and conclude her character are missing? Jinu on the other hand, despite having a simple premise, is properly delivered.

By the way, talking about Rumi, why does Celine (her foster mother and mentor) only showed up in the last third of the film? And we have Rumi say a cliche line such as "why didn't you love me?", are you for real? You are working as a Demon Hunter despite being a demon, isn't this the best approach for this situation?

Something else that slipped my mind, but I had to edit and mention is, so they are stealing their fans' souls and the news say "thrice the amount of people are missing", so how does these numbers add up? People are missing, are the Korean police so incompetent to connect those people missing are literally connected by the Saja Boys? Also, how do they fill a stadium if they keep on stealing souls and don't do it in one go?

As for the voice acting, it is so weird because I considered watching this in Korean, because I heard a comparison video between English, Korean and Japanese and, for immersion, I thought Korean would be the better choice, but I ended up watching in English, but I do reckon each language had their better approaches. What I disliked about the English dub was how the voice singing, except for Jinu, don't match their acting voice (not talking about the other Saja Boys, as I said, they barely speak).

The art is very nice, but the animation felt like was missing frames? Kinda like it was a bit choppy?

In the end, my pet peeve was that this should have been a series, properly develop the other two girls and the Saja Boys. Throw the conscription male idols go through and the Saja Boys, being demons, are that much better than actual soldiers so they are released; have both groups interact with those variety programs old geezers are there and they do stuff only they find it funny and people awkwardly laugh, there was so much they could do, SPECIALLY this being a western animation, you would never see a Korean animation mocking those things because their society is too rigid, they would take that jab as something offensive and not something to just laugh it off.
label: literal

text: Sandlot of Dreams Passionate about baseball, a middle aged man fondly recalls the summer when he first learned how to play, the friends he made and the mischief they got up to in this popular comedy. While there are some funny moments to be had and the kids interact with one another credibly, the first half of 'The Sandlot' is difficult to get through at times with lots of excessively sentimental voice over narration and several silly shenanigans. The second half of the film is a blast though as a lost ball over a fence brings out the kids' creative sides. The inventions they come up with to retrieve the ball (without disturbing the dog in the yard) are delightfully wacky and inventive, especially a souped-up vacuum cleaner. The second half also features a chase sequence done with unexpected originality (if still the odd heavily telegraphed gag). Suffice it to say, footage from 'The Wolf Man' has rarely been appropriated so well. It has been said that 'The Sandlot' is the type of film that will only appeal to baseball lovers and those who like reminiscing about their youth. It is true that those from these demographics will likely get more from the film, but the project is still probably worth a look for others. The annoying voice-over does disappear for certain stretches and uneven as the first 45 minutes may well be, everything picks up once the kids get to show off their ingenuity.
label: literal

text:
Visually appealing, but unnecessary sluggish This movie, about Elphaba and Galinda who become friends at Shiz University in the Land of Oz, is an okay fairy tale movie.

It is one of the most hyped and popular movies of recent years, and I had somewhat high expectations. The movie is visually appealing in terms of production design, costumes, and makeup, delivering musical and artistic performances and touches, and it proves itself how much work that has been put into it.

However, although I found the first act to be promising, the rest of the movie increasingly falters in telling its story in an appealing way, I think. Ariana Grande fills her character as the protagonist Elphaba's friend Galinda surprisingly enough, but I do not think Cynthia Erivo (as Elphaba) deserves an Oscar nomination. Erivo did alright, but nothing outstanding. The movie has a runtime of 162 minutes, and together with the first act, which I enjoyed, the movie feels like a grand-scaled one, reminding me a bit of The Harry Potter Octalogy (2001-2011), Barbie (2023), and The School for Good and Evil (2022), but after this act, the movie is surprisingly slow, barely developing the story at some points. It makes much room for the musical parts, which are not bad, but to me they could have been shorter or fewer. The movie did not appeal to me as much as I expected, unfortunately.

In conclusion, this movie shines visually but falters in storytelling. Despite strong production design and performances, the narrative loses momentum after a promising start. Ariana Grande impresses as Galinda, while Erivo's Elphaba feels unremarkable. At 162 minutes, the movie prioritizes musical numbers over plot, making it feel sluggish. Ultimately, it does not live up to its hype.
label: figurative

text:
Infiltration and Intrigue A Man on the Inside" is a comedy mystery series on Netflix, crafted by Michael Schur. Inspired by the Chilean documentary "The Mole Agent," Michael Schur adapted its intriguing premise into this series. Ted Danson stars as a retired professor seeking new excitement in his life when he answers an advertisement from a private investigator. Lilac Richcreek portrays the investigator who tasks Ted with infiltrating a nursing home in San Francisco to uncover the mystery of a missing necklace, a cherished possession of one of the residents. Stephanie Beatriz takes on the role of Didi, the nursing home's manager, while Mary Elizabeth Ellis plays Ted's daughter, residing in Sacramento with her family of three boys.

The ensemble of elderly characters includes Sally Struthers, John Getz, Lori Tan Chinn as the board president, Clyde Kusatsu, Margaret Avery, Veronica Cartwright, and Susan Ruttan. Nelson Franklin is featured as the owner of the nursing home, and Marc Evan Jackson as the son who enlists Lilac's services. The series presents a delightful and engaging story with endearing characters that resonate with viewers. There's a hopeful anticipation for a second season to continue this charming narrative.
label: literal

text:
Schwarzenegger's Hunger Games In the dystopian future of 2017, all media is controlled by the state. Their most popular TV show is "Running Man", a game show where convicts fight against American Gladiator style warriors known as "Stalkers". If the contestants are able to escape with their lives, then they are granted their freedom. After being framed for a crime he didn't commit, Schwarzenegger's Ben Richards is entered into this competition.

Of course, not all the "futuristic" technology holds up, but the commentary they make on media is still surprisingly relevant to this day.

The movie is vintage Arnold. It came out the same year as "Predator" and has him doing the action and spouting all the one-liners as only Arnold can. There is a definite cheesy charm to it. With all his quips, the title of the film could have been "The Punning Man".

text:
Pretty Good Movie Rating - 7.4: Overall, a valiant effort for a directorial debut as Chris Stuckmann shows his potential as a filmmaker with captivating storytelling and ominous world-building, but the movie suffers from issues you would expect from a new indie filmmaker with its amateurish cinematography, cheap visual effects, and an inability to stick the landing because the final 5 minutes ruin this movie's chance of being something special; I hope Stuckmann can parlay this into making bigger budget movies as he shows potential as a filmmaker, but hopefully he uses his budget wisely because it is obvious Neon wasted the increased budget on cheap CGI and unnecessary reshoots.

Direction - Pretty Good to Good: The direction on a macroscale is built well, as they create this ominous mystery in a demented world; I really enjoyed how they weaved the documentary and found footage into the movie; I felt the filmmaking style in the dramatic moments felt a little amateurish with how it looked, which makes sense because this is a directorial debut; The direction on a microscale is pretty good, as you can really empathize with their struggle to find her sister; The storytelling is good for the majority of the movie, as they create a mystery that slowly unravels, but keeps you engaged, as you want to see how things play out; I was not a fan of how the storytelling was in the last five minutes; Tension is built well, as you are emotionally invested in these characters, so you feel on edge when something bad happens to them

Story - Pretty Good to Good: The concept is good, as it's a missing girl mystery that weaves in found footage elements to give it a Blair Witch feel, and the conflict is presented in a way that it doesn't give away too much, but at least gives you a why for why things are happening; The plot structure is good for the most part, as the movie feels like a good mystery that slowly unravels the more you try to solve the disappearance, though the resolution wasn't that great, as it felt forced; Character writing is good, as you get a sense of the protagonist's struggle trying to find her sister and the world they live in affecting them; The character writing is critical in helping connect with the protagonist's struggle, as you feel invested in her trying to find closure

Screenplay - Pretty Good to Good: The dialogue is sharp for the most part, nothing super outstanding; the symbolism is very strong, as the movie touches on issues of loss and grief as well as pagan and found footage supernatural tropes; the foreshadowing is strong in the movie, as it helps the protagonist try to solve the mystery

Acting - Pretty Good: Camille Sullivan - Pretty Good to Good (The star of the show, she shows a wide range of emotions and is the emotional core for this movie; we experience this mystery through her eyes as she is motivated to find her lost sister after 12 years), Brendan Sexton III - Pretty Bad (Honestly, it feels very stiff and doesn't have chemistry with Sullivan), Robin Bartlett - Decent to Pretty Good (Plays a real sinister character, but doesn't have much time to work with), Sarah Dunn - Pretty Good (Really shows a wide range of emotions as she really embodies the character and feels like what the lead of Blair Witch Project should have been), Keith David - Pretty Good (Feels like he was a part of the reshoots, but he does a pretty good job and has chemistry in the one scene he is in), Rest of the cast - Decent (A pretty small cast, but what you would expect from a low-budget horror movie)

Score - Decent: Helps with building tension

Cinematography - Decent: Cinematography in the documentary and found footage moments was really good and weaved well into the movie; when they switched to a traditional camera, it felt pretty amateurish and not that appealing, which makes sense because it is a low budget directorial debut

Editing - Decent: Editing for the found footage and documentary clips was pretty cool, as it made the movie feel like a mockumentary, but the rest of the movie just felt kind of bland in terms of editing

Sound - Pretty Good: Feels amplified to help heighten tension and make you feel scared of what is going on

Visual Effects - Bad: It felt very cheap, and it was obvious it was added when the budget was increased

Production Design - Pretty Good: Help create this pagan, ominous world of the abandoned Shelby Oaks

Makeup - Decent to Pretty Good: Helps show the impact of the hauntings

Pacing - Pacing is fine for the most part as the movie goes at the right pace

Climax - The climax is good and well executed, and the ending was a big let down as it basically felt like they threw away everything they built up to

Tone - Tone was a mystery and a found footage film combined; I would have really liked to see them continue the documentary style throughout the movie

Final Notes - Saw press screening at Fantastic Fest; Met Chris Stuckmann after the movie.
label: literal

text: An outrage to King's vision, but enjoyable nonetheless I've read the Stephen King story about 5 times, and this movie does not follow the fable, even vaguely. But that does not make it a bad movie. In King's version, Schwarzenegger's character is a skinny, intense and relentless character, a person with integrity that surpasses all expectations and vigor, in a Dystopian world. In King's version, the protagonist is "every man," just an average Joe who is lucky enough to be elected for the "Running Man" game show. He runs and runs and runs and kicks some serious a--. Unfortunately in the movie, it's all about Arnold getting revenge. But this doesn't make it a bad movie, just one that is a betrayal to the passion and the voice of the original story. In this regard, the movie is a fraud, and yet, it is enjoyable in the heyday of Arnold's magnificence.

text:
'Weapons' Lacks Substance and Big Flaws I'll give the pros and cons.

Pros: 'Weapons' maintains suspense in the first half pretty well. The acting is good (as it usually would be for such a high-budget film), and it has some unique shots. Sorry, that's all I got.

Cons: I really don't like bashing films (any film) because I know it takes a long time and a lot of hard work to make even a bad movie, let alone a good or great one. However, this film had several flaws.

Ensemble Cast: Having an ensemble cast can be a significant advantage or a major drawback. In this case, it was a considerable drawback because the plot was convoluted due to the presence of too many subplots competing for attention. We don't really get to know any of the characters or their motivations well; we're only given snippets about them. Justine is a drunk who cares too much about kids, Paul is a cop who commits adultery and has contamination OCD (maybe?), Archer wants his kid back (yup, that's all), and Gladys is an evil witch who traps Alex under her thumb. I don't feel that characters have to be 'likable,' necessarily, but they have to be interesting.

Setups & Payoffs: Having 17 kids run away from their homes at the same moment in the middle of the night is a BIG setup. However, if you have a big setup, you need a big payoff, and this film definitely did not deliver one. What is behind this great big mystery?... An old, dying witch. Done. Wouldn't it have been much more interesting if there was something bigger that Gladys had planned? If the stakes were raised? What if she were part of a larger coven that was planning to take over the entire town? Maybe more? Nope, she's just an old evil witch we know nothing about.

Lack of Authorities: Although they did show some cops and special agents interviewing Alex and other people during a montage and a few quick scenes, the number of local police/FBI/DOJ/DOS/HSI, etc. Would be overwhelming in this case; they wouldn't simply let it go as the unseen narrator tells us. A good story should be kept as private as possible to the world that the writer creates. However, limiting the world to only a handful of characters hurts the credibility of this particular story; the small, fictional town of Maybrook, Pennsylvania, should have been more deeply involved in the plot. The authorities would have searched every inch of that town (and beyond) and found at least one clue that would have led to at least one (if not more) of those seventeen children. After however many months, it took Archer, acting alone, to finally review someone else's doorbell camera footage and obtain a map, until he finally discovered that Alex's house was where the problem had been all along. The authorities would have known this very early on and figured out where the kids were. Lazy writing!

The Rules of the Story World: Not only does the writer not have to explain everything to the audience, but they shouldn't. However, when a writer creates rules within a unique world (especially in this genre), they must define them to a certain extent. Gladys's way of bewitching people was clear enough. She needs water, a bowl, her blood, a tree twig, and something her victim possesses? Hair too? Both? Kind of confusing. In the end, Alex casts his own spell on Gladys and has the kids literally rip her apart. But how did he do that? Can anyone just grab the necessary items and go to work? It would have been much better if there had been a chant or something more specific that Gladys did, which Alex perhaps witnessed by accident, allowing him to cast the final spell. Also, how was Gladys 'feeding' off these kids? They were just standing around when the crackhead found them. Why didn't Glady's put Alex under the spell once she had all those children? Where were Gladys and Alex going right before Archer and Justine found the house near the end? Too many open questions.

Finally, some of the shots and coloring appear slightly off. I know that is very technical, but I noticed it. Also, the pacing was slow and muddled at times, especially in the second half.
label: figurative

text: John Hughes scraping bottom... Comic book junk concerns two teenage boys who invent a busty, sexy brunette with their home-computer, resulting in hormone-crazed chaos. It is far worse than the usual sex-related teen shenanigans, which not even Anthony Michael Hall's affable charm can rescue. Kelly LeBrock, with her pouty lips and deep, guttural laugh, is definitely game, but she's used as a sight-gag, a prop, and Hughes can't even work up a genuine character for her to play. Overall, The spectacle of the show is what kept me involved, It made me smile because, even as a magician, the film feels like magic, it loves how it presents magic and thats what magic is about, presentation.

text:
When key characters are replaced, you are playing with fire (Spoilers) I was watching some episodes of Season 12 when I noticed the absence of Thomas Gibson. The story line that he is not coming back sounded a little strange. Then I read here all sorts of pros and cons on the firing of Thomas. Surprisingly enough, and coming from "pros" is that CBS/ABC Studios seem to have only taken a look at a little corner instead of the entire picture.

I have watched each and every episode of the entire series since Season 1 and one of the strengths of CM is the great chemistry that existed between the cast members. Sure, some agents came and went but that was OK because the main characters were always there. The resignation of Mandy Patinkin was a hard kick in the main structure of the show but, thankfully, Rossi's arrival "fixed" it.

Then, Shemar Moore left and you could tell there was some kind of gap somewhere. Now, Thomas Gibson was fired and swiftly replaced by Paget Brewster. What is a very weak link here is the fact that Emily Prentiss has been working for Interpol for awhile and she was over in pursuit of a criminal. Realistically, agencies like the FBI don't simply grab an agent from another agency PLUS puts him/her in charge of a division. There is something called courtesy between agencies of allied countries. It would have made a lot more sense, since Rossi did not want the position, to give it to JJ, a regular field agent with seniority from the beginning.

A structure can only take some many kicks to its heart before it crumbles. Ratings are unfortunately weakening, fans are boycotting it and Season 13 is a huge question mark. The stupid CBS/ABC Studios and their executives should have thought of that instead of their idiotic macho pride. Sometimes "pros" do not stand up to their title.
label: figurative

Interesting depiction of little-known period in American history Until I watched this miniseries I only knew that James Garfield was one of the four assassinated presidents. I knew nothing of the assassin or that Garfield was an "accidental" nominee in 1880.

I generally enjoy historical dramas and this one is pretty solid- until the viewer is suddenly jolted out of the 19th century by dialogue that almost certainly wouldn't have been used back then.

Examples: At the Republican nominating convention someone on the stage angrily yells "motherf*cker" to the crowd. Later, Garfield's wife tells her husband that people are "on the lawn" outside their Ohio farmhouse.

Much of the script uses very formal language even in casual settings, which may be unrealistic but is more easily forgiven.

text:
It just doesn't work Much to my surprise Kenneth Branagh's adaptation is better, for the sake of a quick comparison. There are aspects of this that are fine. It looks good, at times, but is lacking a significant amount of emotional heft. Certain characters missing, Justine for example, and the trajedy surrounding her, and a more global justification for the monster's motivations, in terms of it having been universally condemned, rather than by only Victor and a random encounter with a particular group.

Some of the visuals are good, but there's something a little too clean and plastic about it all. Would suggest avoiding 4k actually.

I also have concerns about the creature's design, rather more like the Engineer, as revealed in Prometheus, with a few big scars, rather more than Frankenstein's monster.

It's a shame, but there we go. In fact, among many less than sucessful adaptations.

text:
One of the Better National Lampoon Films The Griswold family's plans for a big family Christmas predictably turn into a big disaster.

How do you beat this? Frank Capra III helping to direct, John Hughes writing and Angelo Badalamenti on the score? There is no way these three folks could make a bad movie. Then throw in Chevy Chase, Brian Murray, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Bill Hickey and Randy Quaid... you have an instant classic.

I could maybe have done without Juliette Lewis. I mean, she has her moments, but how did she get to be in this film? Being the daughter of Geoffrey Lewis? It certainly was not her work being Wayne's girlfriend on "The Wonder Years". Oh well. At least she went on to do better things.

Today, the film is considered a modern Christmas classic, and I would have to agree. It also is a strong third entry in the franchise, second only to the original. Ebert wrote, "The movie is curious in how close it comes to delivering on its material: Sequence after sequence seems to contain all the necessary material, to be well on the way toward a payoff, and then it somehow doesn't work." I have to say, I think he was wrong.
label: literal

text:
Fun for kids, entertaining for adults, excellent for baseball enthusiasts. "The Sandlot" is a charming kids film that over the last 15 years has gained somewhat of a cult following, making this a nostalgic joy for 25 year old's who remember seeing this at age 10 and laughing their heads off. To me, this is not a perfect family film, but unlike many movies that claim to be family films, this actually is a "FAMILY FILM". Kids like it for the relate able situations and amusing dialogue between the kids, adults will find it's very easy to get wrapped up in this, even though it is just a silly kiddie movie and anyone in between will probably enjoy this too.

Scotty has just moved to a new neighborhood, and isn't accepted by the other children. Eventually, he begins playing baseball with them at the local sandlot, and several adventures come from this. The main story is Scotty losing his step dad's (Dennis Leary) signed Babe Ruth baseball in the backyard with an evil dog the kids refer to as "The Beast".

This movie has some genuinely amusing scenes, and some scenes so campy, they're hilarious. One scene involves a young boys plan to make out with the attractive older girl lifeguard at the public pool, and this scene is kind of a classic, which may be seen in movies after or even before this, but it was just done so great here. Any scene involving "The Beast" is hilarious. Depending on the scene, this dog changes shape and size, and can be anything from a large dog to some kind of mutated super monster. This dog puts the shark in Jaws to shame. It's good the kids each have their own distinct personalities, and aren't entirely run on stereotypes. One small problem is the lack of any emotional conflict, which may or may not be a problem depending on your point of view. I would have liked something to tug at the audiences' heart strings, but nothing does. It's still a good movie however.

Overall, this is a fun movie for all...not great, but good enough to be enjoyed by the whole family.

My rating: *** out of ****. 100 mins. PG for language, tobacco use.
label: figurative

text:
Superb adaptation a homage to Old Hollywood My Review -

Guillermo del Toro's Frankenstein In Cinemas now My Rating. 10/10

I recently lamented about the quality and attention to detail and originality that some obviously not all contemporary movie directors and screenwriters display today.

Oscar winning director Mexican director Guillermo Del Toro's work has always been a showcase for creativity, originality and attention to detail.

His admiration and inspiration is obvious for his favourite directors that include Alfred Hitchcock Sergio Leone, Akira Kurosawa, Stanley Kubrick ,Martin Scorsese and James Whale who inspired his love of the horror genre.

James Whale in 1931 directed Boris Karloff as the monster in Frankenstein and now 94 years later it's Guillermo Del Toro's turn.

Guillermo del Toro decided to follow up his version of Pinocchio (2022), with the "Frankenstein" story that he has always viewed as two sides of the same conceptual coin.

I agree the concepts are identical whether a wooden puppet turns into a real boy or an ego crazed doctor creates a monster by experimenting with the power of life force.

Both Pinocchio and The Monster discover the cruelty and abuse of humanity .

We all know or have seen different adaptations of British author Mary Shelley's gothic 1818 novel Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus .

Guillermo Del Torro who successfully achieves the movie Trifecta of Producer, Director and Screenwriter has remained largely faithful to Mary Shelley's novel in a similar way to Danny Boyle's superb 2011 stage production for The National Theatre that starred Benedict Cumberbatch and Jonny Lee Miller who alternated the roles of Victor Frankenstein and The Monster.

Australian actor Jacob Elordi gives a sensational performance as the monster and brings such emotion and gentleness to a role that transcends horror and violence.

I read that he was not the first choice to play The Monster ,Andrew Garfield was originally cast as the Monster, but had to drop out due to scheduling conflicts.

I think it was a brilliant choice to have one of the most handsome male actors today play the cruelly deformed monster.

In the most demanding role of his career Jacob Elordi says he loved playing the role and spent up to ten hours in the makeup chair for extensive makeup application .

Some days he arrived at the makeup trailer at 10 P. M. and stayed up all night.

To quote Guillermo del Toro "he came to believe Elordi was "superhuman". "Never once did he come to me and complain. "Never once did he come to me and say, 'I'm tired. I'm hungry. Can I go?' And he put in 20-hour days." From the first frames of this movie I felt it was a nostalgic affectionate homage to the Golden age of Hollywood movies the director insisted on elaborate studio built sets rather relying on CGI and this adds to the homage to old movie making.

The superb music score by French composer Alexandre Desplat reminded me of the richness of the past great screen composers Max Steiner and Erich Korngold .

The amazing gothic sets by Shane Vieau who designed Dune 2 and The Shape of Water and costumes by Kate Hawley who also designed Guillermo Del Toro's Crimson Peak add to what I consider perfection in a movie .

Guillermo del Toro's only choice to play Dr Victor Frankenstein was Oscar Isaac and he brings an almost sympathetic quality to what is often portrayed as a crazed villainous character.

The great supporting cast includes Christoph Waltz, Charles Dance and an actress I've never seen appropriately named Mia Goth who is splendid as Elizabeth who in Mary Shelley's novel is the fiancÃ© of Victor Frankenstein but in this version is the fiancÃ© of his younger brother William played by Felix Kammerer.

I loved this adaptation of Frankenstein please see it on a cinema screen don't wait till it streams in Netflix.

I predict many Oscar nominations next year for this superb movie and I hope Jacob Elordi is nominated as best actor.
label: figurative

text: So much more than the sum of its parts I'd put off watching The Morning Show because I thought it would be a Sorkin-lite style Newsroom series set in a breakfast show and that felt like a tired format with nothing new to say. How utterly wrong I was. Yes it's got the big names. Yes it has clearly had a vast amount of money thrown at it, but that doesn't mean it isn't one of the most gripping tv series I've watched in years. The series builds and builds, the tension cranking up with each episode, literally at points, leaving me breathless. What I found particularly remarkable is that the #metoo movement is seen through so many different perspectives but cleverly the writers allow each perspective to live its own truth, whether or not that is a reliable truth or not, morally right or not, and in doing so it weaves this uncomfortable narrative that exactly reflects the rich and strange tapestry that is the real world. I thought that aspect of it was audacious. To not bring judgement and spoon feed an audience is a brave and risky thing to do. The performances are stellar, it's an ensemble cast with everyone bringing their A game. I devoured this first series in a couple of days and cannot wait for series 2. Can they replicate the clever and nuanced storytelling of this first series, I hope so.
label: literal

text: One of my favourite shows of all time! I love series like this, and Criminal Minds is just so interesting and absorbing. It is very dark and somewhat grim often, but I like that side, it does make the show compelling. I will admit it was a show that started off good, but then got better and better. I love how it is filmed as well, the camera work is innovative, and the locations are always lovely and evocative to watch. The music is very fitting, the main theme is chilling to an extent and the music choices in each episode are appropriate and effective a vast majority of the time. The writing is always intelligent, witty and thought-provoking and the episode ideas are brilliant with moments that are chilling and moving. And of course the characters are wonderful, especially stone-faced Jason Gideon, Spencer and Hotch(as well as Rossi and Prentiss), and they are brought to life brilliantly by a sterling cast, both lead and supporting. Overall, I just love this show, it is true that some episodes are better than others(then again it is like that with most shows), whenever it is on I always watch it. 10/10 Bethany Cox
label: literal

text: Masterpiece Oh man. This show is absolutely amazing. I didn't originally want to watch it, and the only reason I did is because my friend kept telling me and telling me to and I don't regret it at all. I'm watching better call Saul and I've seen El Camino but this show started it all. While season 1 is a bit lacklustre, the rest of the show is a masterpiece, and it never disappointed. I once heard that the first episode tries everything to get you on Walt's side, and the rest of the show sees how long you're willing to stay with him, and I fully agree with that sentiment. At the beginning, you agree with Walt and think that he's reasonable in his actions, I mean he had to kill krazy-8 or he would kill Walt's family. But throughout the show, even if you don't notice, you don't continue to agree with him, but you still like him. I believe this is because of that first episode. Everytime Walter White does something bad you think back to the first episode and think "Look how far he's come." But Eventually, He isn't Walter White anymore, but fully Heisenberg. This is when you truly see him as a villain. The Question is, Did the Cancer change Walt into becoming this monster, or Did it just reveal who he always wanted, nay, who he was all along?

text: Disturbing but good This is definitely the best portrayal of Jeffery Dahmer I've seen. Evan Peter's was great in this. Eat your heart out Jeremey Renner. No pun intended. The 2002 Jeremy Renner film was terrible and the 2017 film My Friend Dahmer didn't do the story much justice. This show gets into much more detail. I had no idea his mother was on tons of psychological medication while she was pregnant. Or that she was a suicidal UFO nut. I never knew he spent time in Germany as a US Army combat medic. A lot of the events that took place were news to me. I'm glad I decided to check this show out. It's definitely worth a watch. 8 stars.

text:
I was there during this time period I really loved the 2 seasons of this show. Suspenseful, griping storyline and great acting.

I lived on the Navajo Reservation in Shiprock during this time period when I was 8 years old. The look and feel really brought a lot back. The beauty of the desert is hard to capture just how stunningly gorgeous it is, but the film crew does a very good job.

My dad was an OBGYN and we lived there in 1972.

We went to Jim Charley's church and his son Wilton drew an amazing picture for us that I have hanging up today! (He was loved by the people and of course did not sterilize the women) I have lot of Native American art from this time period which I love and treasure.

Apart from that I will say this is a fabulous show and I highly recommend it!

text:
A Must Watch for Fans of House MD (and Beyond!) I can't believe I only heard about Doc through a random TikTok! As a longtime House MD fan, I clicked out of curiosity but within minutes, I was hooked. I ended up watching all 15 available episodes in less than 24 hours. This show has the formula down sharp writing, emotional depth, medical realism, and characters that feel genuinely human. Dr. Amy Larsen's story hits hard: the mix of memory loss, identity, and redemption is beautifully balanced with intense hospital cases and heartfelt moments. Molly Parker completely commands every scene, and the supporting cast adds layers that make the story believable and addicting. It's rare to find a medical drama that feels both intelligent and emotionally grounded, but Doc nails it.

If you loved House, The Good Doctor, or New Amsterdam, you'll find Doc even more compelling. I just hope they keep the momentum going - because I'm absolutely ready for the next episode!

text:
How Atrocities Happen After reading some of these reviews, it's a mistake to compare this film with Kubrick's excellent film because this film isn't focused on the Nuremberg trials as courtroom drama. The main focus is on GÃ¶ring & the "relationship" he develops with Dr. Kelley, & how Kelley comes to realize the depths of evil GÃ¶ring's capable of committing behind his often charming, intelligent, narcissistic--and sometimes disarming--facade, & that this evil isn't a trait of a "Nazi mind." A secondary focus relates to the difficult task of establishing trials when no precedent existed for such trials; the allies weren't even sure what crimes to charge the Nazi leaders with, but it was absolutely necessary that once charged & tried, the Nazi leaders had to be convicted because the world was watching. That sounds simple. Who could imagine them not being convicted? But it wasn't as simple as it seems decades later; GÃ¶ring made escaping justice not outside the realm of possibility.

Crowe is simply amazing as GÃ¶ring: alternately haughty, defiant, warm, funny, & even vulnerable--but always there's an underlying menacing aspect to him. He has great affection for his family, for his country, for his leader, but he can casually sign off on the death of millions of people & feel no remorse nor regret. And he is always in control of himself.

Malik is also good, but sometimes his reactions are, imo, exaggerated. He gets reeled in by GÃ¶ring, & it's not until he physically sees the results of GÃ¶ring's actions that he truly sees the real GÃ¶ring.

The entire supporting cast was top notch, most notably Michael Shannon as Justice Jackson, a man of principle, who was the driving force behind the tribunal, & Leo Woodall as Sgt. Triest. (There's been some criticism of John Slatterly, but he captures Colonel Andrus.) It's easy to see how GÃ¶ring, & those like him, manipulated & captured an entire nation's people given the devastation to Germany after WW I. It's also easy to see that this type of manipulation didn't end with the Third Reich.
label: literal

Right from the opening scene, and especially for people who are aware that this show is about a key chracter from Breaking Bad, this starts at such a faraway place in terms of story that you just do not know what to make of it!

And that is exactly what is fascinating about this show. The story and character development. This show is not a spin-off. It's a parallel prequel, and a brilliant one at that. Slow- burning, outrageous, funny, smart. And it gets you a HUGE shot of Breaking Bad Nostalgia because of the key characters that it brings back. I will name only the biggest one : Gus Fring!!! text:
Black Phone 2 proves that the sequel curse is breakable Black Phone 2 nails what so many horror sequels fail at: honoring the original with clever callbacks while carving out a fresh, eerie story of its own. The jump scares are sharp, inventive, and land perfectly-no lazy repeats here.

The film weaves together nods to classic horror-from Freddy Krueger and Nightmare on Elm Street vibes to echoes of M. Night Shyamalan's Glass universe of clairvoyants-creating an atmosphere that feels both nostalgic and chillingly new.

At its core, Black Phone 2 is Gwen and Finny's story-two kids caught in a relentless fight against pure evil. Their bond, courage, and raw defiance give the movie its beating heart, turning the terror into something strangely hopeful. It's a horror sequel that doesn't just scare you-it makes you care.

text:
A Brutal Vacation Timo Tjahjanto's Nobody 2 is a relentless, bone-crunching sequel that doubles down on the first film's blend of suburban angst and bloody mayhem. This time, Bob Odenkirk's Hutch Mansell is on vacation, which of course becomes a backdrop for an insane series of creatively staged, over-the-top fight sequences. Tjahjanto, known for his work on action films like The Night Comes for Us, brings a distinct, stylized flair to the violence, turning the tranquil setting of a small town and an amusement park into a series of deadly playgrounds. The plot is thin and largely exists to string together these incredible set pieces, but that's not a criticism-the movie knows exactly what it is. It's a joyful, unpretentious action romp. The action is more outlandish and even more graphic than the original, with a dark, cartoonish sense of humor that differentiates it from the more grounded, noirish tone of the first film.

Some critics have noted that the sequel loses some of the original's gritty charm in favor of a more comedic, outlandish style, but praise the film for being an entertaining and satisfying follow-up.

Is it worth watching? If you're a fan of the first film and are looking for a fun, fast-paced action movie that doesn't take itself too seriously, then absolutely.
label: literal

text:
An average Netflix Christmas movie Look, this is your typical streaming Christmas movie. Is it anything special? Naw. But does it work as a Christmas movie? Totally.

The story follows a separated couple trying to celebrate Christmas together before finalizing their divorce. You've got the new girlfriend, the hot guy who conveniently takes his shirt off, and a Harry Potter-obsessed Nigel (I actually loved that dude). It's super predictable, but honestly, that doesn't hurt it at all.

The cast works well enough, and there are a few fun familiar faces. The small-town Christmas setting is always a win, and that's exactly what we get here-cozy, simple, and right on theme.

At the end of the day, it's an average Netflix Christmas movie... and it works. If you're into these kinds of holiday comfort watches, it'll absolutely entertain.

text:
Depends on your mood. 'Playdate' is the kind of movie you're either going to really enjoy, or really hate. It sort of falls in the vein of 'Nobody' and 'Novocaine', but without the emotional punch. This is action for the sake of action and comedy for the sake of comedy, and there isn't really an in-between. The humour also mostly edges towards slapstick.

Regardless, I still had a good time with 'Playdate'. I guess the moment makes the big difference. If you're in the mood for this kind of movie, then you will be satisfied. If you're in the mood for an action comedy with a bit more substance and emotional depth to it, then you will be disappointed. Since I was in the mood for light entertainment with enough action to keep me interested, I was satisfied.

Ok, so Kevin James stars as Brian, who has just lost his job. His wife Emily (Sarah Chalke) suggests he stays at home with her son (his stepson) Lucas while she works extra shifts. (I must also add, there was absolutely no chemistry between Kevin and Emily and they did not come across as a married couple.)

While trying to bond with Lucas, they meet Jeff and his son CJ playing ball. Jeff and CJ instantly connects with Brian and Lucas and invites them to their home, which starts a very unconventional friendship. Things quickly spiral out of control when CJ tells Brian that Jeff isn't his Dad, and that he was taken. And soon they find themselves on the run and being shot it, and it becomes clear Jeff and CJ are not who they appear to be.

Some moments definitely were more silly than funny, but in general it was mostly entertaining, and there's plenty of action and excitement. Its not exactly the kind of movie I'd watch again and again, but it was cool for a once off. I really enjoyed hunky Alan Ritchson as Jeff, who - despite being a hugely built action junkie - liked to cuddle and hold hands. He was so sweet, actually! In fact, I think he made the movie more enjoyable.
label: literal

text: Crazy like a fox-... i mean wolf Oh man, there's a lot going on here. A detective story about a monster rampaging the French countryside, a mash of competing genres (romance, horror, martial arts, political) . . . And Monica Bellucci thrown in for good measure. Makes you wonder how they sold this project to investors (how much cocaine it took to grease those wheels?). And yet, it all comes together somehow. Despite his lack of dialogue , Mark Dacascos was the enigmatic allure for me, and I'll admit I was disappointed when his part of the story came to an end. The fight scenes are engaging, the locations really help this setting come to life, and the story is just crazy enough to work. Bottom line, it's a trip, and well worth the time.

text: ER on steroids As many others have noted, The Pitt is very realistic in terms of the emergency medicine. Additionally, without the limits of network television, it has fewer guardrails. However, throwing F-bombs, pissing and pooping on people, and occasionally showing genitalia does not, by itself, make The Pitt better. What ER did have was engaging storytelling and characters with lives outside the ER, which so far The Pitt does not even try to do. I have yet to see anything in Pittsburgh other than stock shots of the city. Moreover, for a show set in Pittsburgh, it would be nice to at least have some of the minor characters speak with a Pittsburgh accent (i.e., yinzers). True, the doctors would likely come from elsewhere, but the patients and nurses should speak with the local accent, and not sound like they're all from Southern California.

text:
Horrible Messages About Modern-Day Dating Let me preface by saying that my wife was a matchmaker for over 2 years in L. A. She lived the life of walking around asking people "hey are you single?" So naturally, she and I were excited to see this movie. While there were a few nods to the common (and hilariously ridiculous) issues that matchmakers deal with and some all-too-relatable moments for my wife, we were ultimately very disappointed.

1) I'll avoid spoilers, but essentially the messages sent by this movie to all the single people out there are depressing and incredibly shallow.

2) For a movie called "Materialists" that makes references to money consistently throughout, there was a shocking lack of eye candy in the film. Dinner scenes showed no food. Fancy homes were decorated by a beige monster. Not even travel porn.

3) I'm a fan of Dakota in general, but wow this is a stale performance. She's monotone and lacks any chemistry with the main characters. They interact as if she has a restraining order against them in real life but already signed up to do the movie together.

4) Everything. Is. So. Slow. The character's speak at a snail's pace. They also don't have conversations. Instead, they take turns reciting long monologues to each other. Scenes are drawn out in order to create drama and the soundtrack must just be a Pandora station called "Melodramatic Elevator Music." For a movie that centers around human connection, the main characters interacted like they were written by AI.

The marketing/pr for the film made it seem like this was going to be light, airy, and more of a rom-com. Sadly, that was not the case.

Verdict: Don't Watch.
label: literal

text:
Do Not Resusitate Don't get me wrong, the premise for Nurse Jackie is great. Edie Falco plays Jackie Peyton, a Vicodin addicted nurse whose whole world (and this series, it turns out) are held together by the hope that nobody will discover her dirty little secret. During the day, she's the Champion ER Nurse of All Time, showing both compassion and brains while bucking the system that promotes and protects profit-hungry hospitals and rock star egomaniac doctors at the expense of the everyday working man and woman. Bravo Jackie.

Not so much so to the show's creator's Liz Brixius and Linda Wallum, who, it seems, had every good intention when they dreamed up this little show, which has, since season one, devolved into a horribly solipsistic mishmash of retreads from all the most forgettable network TV hospital dramas and bad nighttime soaps.

See, NJ has one card to play --- the one stated above --- and after that ace is revealed, the rest of the show goes on life support. Season two ended promisingly enough (after 85% of it was recycled St. Elsewhere hubris) with some much needed suspense revolving around that ace.

I've only watched a few episodes of season three but it is mind numbingly horrific.

One of the big problems is the roster of bland, two-dimensional supporting characters (not the actors, with the exception of teeth-grindingly cutesy Merritt Wever). They run the gamut from Thor (not fleshed out enough...really just a gay cardboard cut-out) to Ackolidas (Anna Devere Smith utterly wasted in the 'bad boss with a heart of gold shtick' --- did I actually see her talking to a monkey in one episode or did I dream that?) to unbelievably dense (Falco's husband on the series....just a weak-willed cypher who's decades too young to play opposite Falco, at least in appearance).

The first season had some interesting subplots, including the one about the OCD daughter. The newer episodes have as subplots: 1) Will Wever get together with her hunky slob of an EMT boyfriend? 2) Will Peter Facinelli (another great actor in a wastoid role) make up with the male nurse who punched him after he screwed his girlfriend? Add in the Xanax-induced doze of all the hacky "zany" ER episode-length plots that try so earnestly to win our hearts and funny bones. They get neither.

It's too bad Showtime didn't see the broken railroad tracks at the end of this speeding freight train when they green-lighted it. I'm sure they thought Falco alone could save it. Sorry....pull the plug and DNR it if you value your time and sanity.
label: literal

The show understands that true tension isn't always found in frantic action, but in the quiet, charged spaces between people, in the unspoken histories and simmering resentments.

A dystopian futuristic drama in the vein of Blade Runner, Dune, and other sci-fi magnum opuses, RBW draws you in from the first episode with this forboding feeling that something unexpected is going to happen.
