text:
Honest review Watched all episodes in a day that being said,really had higher expectations for this.

Unfortunately it was boring & simply dragged out,most exciting parts was in the very beginning/cliffhanger ending.

How the husband was a political figure & let alone her,is frankly beyond me.

Although there's plenty to complain over with the husband,will focus on her unrefined character.. From how she walks,talks,dresses & hygiene.

Will just say.. Felt he was undermining/shady/jealous of his wife,but she made things confusing on his role too.. She would get upset at his actions,but also when advice was needed & he restrained back.

Their marriage woes aside,which got annoying at points in the series.. Again,the storyline was boring yet unrealistic.

What irked me.. If a man abused his wife,would it be let go? There's a time & place for personal matters,but regardless abuse is never it. Absurd behavior & nobody stopped it,including security!

Don't get why her dirty mouthed behavior,was allowed such leeway even if she was (basically) new to it all.

She was being considered as VP? Yikes! Although refreshing than a typical stuffy suit,she seemed overly unpolished to even be a PTA president if she was a mom.. Also she acted like she was above all of it,didn't want it & made it hard believing in her.

She didn't like dressing up,fine! But how about fitted attire to flatter her & that was ironed plus more feminine looking shoes.. Also needed to stop carrying her purse/bag that way or have something nicer,the way she wore it looked like she was headed to a casual meeting. Granted females don't need to look always polished but in certain situations,you should conduct yourself a bit more accordingly.

If you want a series of people doing nothing significant,walking into rooms,going in cars,meetings,marriage issues.. You'll enjoy it! However want an intelligent series with drama,action,storyline of substance about a woman in power.. Forget it!

As mentioned above watched it all,because was hoping it improved as the series went on. It was cast decent and acting wasn't overly horrible,but maybe with better direction or script it could of been a more compelling series. The scenery and homes was beautiful,as was the cinematography.

Even if there's a continuation to this where a second season happens,unless certain aspects improve it will be a waste of time.

Is this worth watching? If you're bored or like the actors,otherwise skip it!

Need a great political series? Designated Survivor.

text:
Really? This is What's Considered the Comeback for Adult Animation? I heard a lot of good things about this show: Funny jokes, good characters, good animation, and now I'm wondering if we watched the same show because this has none of that. I think the premise of the show is solid: A group of odd friends have to help people smile and each episode displays the hijinks to get to that point. But in execution . . . Meh.

Now, I haven't watched season 2 and don't plan to because season 1 gave me no reason to continue. I don't hate any of the characters in Smiling Friends (well except Mr. Frog and the boss gets on my nerves), but I didn't get attached or find any of them that memorable. Pim was alright. The voice acting was also fine, no stand outs good or bad.

As for the animation, I'm mixed. The good things are the main characters have good silhouettes and I like how many mediums they use (such as puppetry, claymation, live action, and rotoscope). For the negatives, the background characters for one thing. As I said before, a lot of the jokes rely on you finding the ugly art funny. There are multiple of these shrimp-esc characters that all look like recolors of each others and are animate the same. The human characters are also very unappealing and I can't tell whenever it's intentional or not. The backgrounds are fine.

The humor is the worst part of the show in my opinion. If you don't find screaming and loud noises funny, you won't like this show because that's nearly 50% of the jokes. The others 50% is made up of laughing at the grotesque art. I didn't laugh until episode 7. There are also multiple scenes of characters talking in that "ha ha awkward" way and I can't tell if those are jokes or not. They happen multiple times an episode and eventually all blend together, so the whole season is a blur. I would be much more forgiving if this was an indie web series, in that case it would be decent at best. But since it's critically acclaimed and produced by a major studio, I'm harsher.

Would not recommend this one. It wasn't offensive or overly awful, and good job trying something different, but different doesn't mean better.

Sorry but this doesn't deserve all the 10/10s Granted it's good, and I like most of PTA's films, but it's not like this is anywhere near as brilliant as something like There Will Be Blood or The Master.

The plot is very simple, and while that's not a bad thing, I found it difficult finding anything substantial to grab onto. The performances are certainly good but again it feels like all the actors with the exception of probably Chase Infiniti and maybe Sean Penn aren't given a whole lot to do.

In my opinion this was far less interestingly photographed than something like Phantom Thread, and with less compelling characters than something like The Master, and lacked the spectacle and gravitas of something like There Will Be Blood.

Still better than most films releasing these days, but if you're looking at all the rave reviews like I was and expecting a masterpiece, from my perspective I'd be lowering my expectations.

It gets a 7/10 for being well performed and pretty well written, but I can't go beyond that because it lacked the depth I'd normally be seeking from filmmakers of PTA's caliber.

text:
From Masterpiece to mess - Ed Gein's story deserved better I absolutely devoured Dahmer, dark, haunting, and brilliantly executed. The Menendez season? Also great. So when they announced Ed Gein, I was hyped... and then totally let down.

The first episode had promise, creepy tone, great setup but it quickly fell apart. Random subplots everywhere, characters who show up once and vanish, and scenes that drag on forever. Ed Gein's real story is fascinating enough, they didn't need to twist it with hallucinations, filler, and fake drama.

What made Monster great was the grounded storytelling and focus on victims. This season forgot all that and instead focussing heavily on trying to make us sympathize with Gein. By the finale, it was a confusing, over-stylized mess - even borrowing from Mindhunter (and not in a good way).

Overall: Dahmer 9/10 Menendez 8/10 Ed Gein 2/10 Ryan Murphy's early work had real spark, but this one felt like creative autopilot. Here's hoping Season 4's Lizzie Borden gets the care and storytelling this one deserved.
label: figurative

text:
Brilliant , subtle, risky, and devastatingly human. This series is a straight standout. From the first episode, you feel the family as real people, not tabloid caricatures. The acting, writing, and direction show their humanity, love, loyalty, and flaws. That human touch deftly handles the series until the last couple of episodes when everything slips through the cracks. The pacing and flow let you live in their world, understand their choices and pressures, and give the story a depth that no documentary or media coverage has ever approached. The series navigates bias in a way that feels remarkably controlled. While Serial leaned toward Adnan and The Staircase often glamorized Michael Peterson, this series starts with subtle bias but incrementally drops it, unapologetically showing what actually happened.

There's also an ironic, sad truth about the iconic American Dream. We all strive to reach the 1 percent, yet we hate and tear down the 1 percent that we are striving for and, in many cases, selling our souls to become. This makes it an American nightmare. This series captures that tension perfectly, showing both the allure and the peril of power, wealth, and status without ever turning it into caricature.

The performances are incredible. The actor playing Alec, who I believe is Scottish, kills it, capturing his charm, manipulation, and selfishness. Patricia Arquette is brilliant, breaking away from her usual offbeat brilliance to play a grounded, straight character in a way I haven't seen before. The sons are excellent, showing the mix of influences from both parents, and the series captures these family dynamics with nuance and precision.

My biggest takeaway is that Alec is a foul, manipulative, and ruthless human being, but the rest of the family is not. True crime coverage has flattened this story into "the Murdaughs are a corrupt 1 percent dynasty," but the series resists that. That is a risky production choice, going against what audiences expect and presenting a nuanced, humanized view of a family that people already want to vilify. That courage makes the storytelling even more compelling.

For me personally, what explains Alec's actions is not premeditation and not Snapped. In my opinion, these opioids completely fogged his brain and caused him to impulsively kill the mother and the son, then try to cover it up in a way that made total sense to someone under the influence of the true toxicity of opioids. A new American nightmare: the opioid crisis and its devastating effects on the brain over time. That perspective is what makes the story hit so hard for me.

Ultimately, this series is not about exploiting tabloid intrigue. It is about human complexity, a family with real depth, and a single man whose choices destroy everything he touches. The subtlety, nuance, human feel, and willingness to go against expected narratives make it unlike anything else I have seen in true crime.
label: figurative

text:
Superman: Legacy of Disappointment If boredom had a cape and could fly, it would be this movie. Superman: Legacy manages to do the impossible: make the Man of Steel feel like a soggy paper towel.

Let's start with the plot-if we can even call it that. It's less of a storyline and more of a loosely taped collage of clichÃ©s, half-baked ideas, and scenes clearly written during a lunch break. We're introduced to a Superman who has all the charisma of a DMV employee and the emotional range of a brick.

The villain? An AI-generated placeholder with all the menace of a wet sock. The stakes? About as high as deciding between decaf or regular. And don't even get me started on the forced "emotional" moments, which had all the subtlety of a freight train and none of the impact.

The dialogue is painfully robotic, as if the characters are reading fortune cookies to each other while pretending it's Shakespeare. Clark Kent spends half the movie brooding like a sad influencer who lost his Wi-Fi, and the other half giving awkward pep talks that somehow manage to be both boring and unintentionally hilarious.

Visually, the CGI would've looked impressive back in 2006. But in 2025? Watching Superman fly looked more like someone struggling with a green screen TikTok filter.

And finally, the pacing: glacial. Entire civilizations have risen and fallen in the time it takes this movie to move from one dull scene to the next.

In summary, Superman: Legacy is less a cinematic experience and more a two-hour exercise in wondering what went wrong. If you're a fan of Superman, avoid this one to preserve your sanity-and your childhood.
label: literal

text: Well done series "Peaky Blinders" comparisons are tiresome and should be shelved. Do you really want the same creators to be one-track ponies? This tells a very fictional family story which touches on enough history of its era to keep things believable and engaging. Fantastic production values in every respect, including setting and costuming. Great performances from key cast, too.

text: Sirk and Metty's best Sirk couldn't even get through the book and just worked from the previous screenplay. The story is ludicrous but the film is gorgeous. The segment just before Hudson returns maybe one of the most visually stunning ever put on film. Sirk's use of music is outstanding. Even the mise en scene is highly stylized. Hudson looks gorgeous but over plays it sometimes as does Rush. They both do much more right than wrong. Wyman is brilliant. In the midst of this true melodrama is this very minimalist performance. It's a very similar to the one she gives in "Heaven" but here there is the contrast with the films overwrought narrative. The narrative is pure cheese but the filmmaking is as compelling today as it would have been in 54. Beyond having Hudson function as the ingenue in some respects there isn't any strong social commentary so it isn't as embraced as "Heaven" or "Imitation" but it is just as beautiful and visually inventive as those films. If you like melodramas, women's films or bravura filmmaking see it.
label: literal

text:
Merrry Christmas from Chevy Chase! I don't know how anyone could ever go in life without seeing Christmas Vacation, it's one of the necessary movies you have to watch during the holidays. The reason being is that everyone can relate to this movie in one way or another. Who hasn't had their crazy family over during the holiday season? Well, that's Christmas Vacation, one of the funniest movies you will ever see. You think that Vacation topped it off with the laughs, believe me when I say that you've seen nothing yet. With an all star cast that clicked so well, you couldn't go wrong going on a great Christmas Vacation with the Griswolds.

Clark Griswold has really got the Christmas spirit this year, and his wife Ellen, son Rusty, and daughter Audrey have noticed that. Clark has invited Ellen's parents Art and Francis Smith, his own parents Clark and Nora Griswold, and his Aunt Bethany and Uncle Lewis to spend the holidays at the Griswold house in Chicago. But in spite of all the good intentions and careful planning, Christmas plans start to go awry: crazy squirrels, SWAT teams, burning Christmas trees, an over cooked turkey and of course a visit from the world's favorite white trash with a heart of gold Cousin Eddie! A Christmas ride not to be missed with the Griswold family.

One of the things I just adore about this movie is the little touches they put in the film: the grandparents falling asleep to an old Christmas movie playing on TV, the anxiety you feel as the doorbell rings knowing who's going to be behind it, and the little awkwardness during dinner when you hear everyone chewing their food. Chevy Chase is still such a pervert of course going for the hot sales lady instead of Cristy Brinkley this time, but you can't help but love and laugh at his fantasy in the back yard while the whole family is swimming in his most wanted work bonus: a family sized pool. He maybe a crazy pervert at times, but you feel the love he has for his family and how badly he wants Christmas to be perfect.

There are some great laughs in this movie: a squirrel gets caught in the Christmas tree that Clark brings in and it attacks the family and neighbors! Clark gets upset that there is no Christmas bonus so his cousin Eddie kidnaps Clark's boss, wraps him in a bow and gives him to Clark so he could kick him in the butt! A cat chews on the Christmas lights and gets electrocuted under the chair. But if you also get past all the slap stick humor, you still feel the Christmas message at the end, that despite all the craziness that comes around Christmas, don't forget what it's really about: peace and love. A wonderful ending and a perfect movie for Christmas that I watch every year, Christmas Vacation is definitely in Santa's movie collection somewhere.

10/10
label: figurative

text:
A Reminder Why Jackie Chan Is a Legend Watching The Shadow's Edge (2025) was both nostalgic and thrilling. Seeing Jackie Chan-my childhood superhero-still in action ignites a mix of admiration and emotion. Though time has passed, the fire in him hasn't faded. Jackie shows once again that he remains unmatched when it comes to blending raw action with heartfelt storytelling.

The movie itself is an absolute ride: packed with intense sequences, compelling drama, and that classic Jackie Chan blend of emotional depth and physical brilliance. Yes, the police approach in catching the mastermind is a little unrealistic at times, but come on-this is cinema, and it does exactly what it's meant to do: entertain with style and energy. We've accepted far crazier things in franchises like Mission Impossible, so no complaints at all.

The storyline is engaging and layered, with real emotional stakes that Jackie anchors brilliantly. His presence is magnetic-as always-and every action scene is a reminder of why he's a legend. If you're a fan of Jackie Chan, action films, or just good cinema, this movie delivers on every front. It's a thrilling, heartfelt, and satisfying experience from start to finish. Jackie Chan continues to fascinate me. Wow...just wow.
label: literal

text:
Intense fantasy/musical epic full of emotions This is really worth your time. An epic musical version of the story of the fantasy theme oz which combines both the fantasy and musical genre in to an epic result.

Music in this film occupy most of the film like two thirds of the whole film if i'm not mistaken and although not all the songs were great as there were some average or forgettable songs still there were quite a few excellent themes which brought a smile to the faces.

One of the few negatives was the film was too long and it more seemed like an extended dvd edition rather than a theatrical version but still it was so enjoyable that u could not really tell how time passed.

One of the strongest positives was the film was full of intense emotions and full of energy everywhere.

The three main characters were presented in a great way and the white witch was adorable too and i always love jeff goldbum.

If u really like a good fantasy musical film then this is for you.

The film is not perfect by far but it's a very solid effort which keeps u in your seat until the end.

A part 2 is confirmed for a future release so to conclude the story of the evil witch so stay tuned.

Get the dvd and the cd soundtrack in to your collection.

text:
Am I an accomplice now....? 7.0/10 (Recommend)

I have been looking forward to this one since I've seen the trailer, and honestly I was not disappointed. While the pacing is a little slow, and in the second half things seem to drag slightly, it's still an enjoyable story. Despite the slightly slow pacing it doesn't feel like you're watching a movie. The way scenes are captured it feels like you're part of the action, or at the very least a fly on the wall.

Channing Tatum is a lot of fun in the role of Jeffery Manchester, and the chemistry him and Kirsten Dunst have is satisfying. Sure he's a criminal and she's just an oblivious single mother, but they feel natural together and you can't help but cheer for a positive outcome.

The film isn't overly funny, but it has some funny bits where you can at least chuckle. The vibe is that this is a slightly more serious, "emotional" film than it is a comedy. And it may look like a family movie, but be mindful that there are a few n-words thrown around, a sex scene or two, and a brief nip slip. Oh no, not a nip slip, you say. Well, some may be concerned with the content they take in or what their kids or teens watch so I mention it.

Overall, this is definitely a film to see in theatres even. The true story and the Hollywood story may be overdramatized, but this story will definitely entertain. While the pacing is a little slow, the story pulls you in and makes you feel like you're part of the adventure. Channing is fun, Kirsten is loveable, and you just want to see the bad guy succeed because he lures you in perfectly.

That's it for now. Thanks for taking time to read my review. Happy watching and enjoy the show!
label: literal

text: Spoiler, sure, but is it though? This movie checks all the Christmas/holiday movie requirements: mixed-race supporting couple, LGBTQ+ couple, someone working in real estate or real estate-adjacent career, small town with a Christmassy name, environmentally conscious character/subplot ... to name a few -- in addition to the "will they or won't they" narrative that always ends in "they will." I guess that's a spoiler, but is it really? I watch these movies and think, they must pay well. Otherwise, why would good actors like Silverstone and Hudson do them, not to mention Jamil (was thrilled to see her)? And they're probably quick and easy to shoot. Plus, I always get the vibe that the cast and crew have fun shooting them. Still. Can't we set higher standards? I agree that the main characters lacked chemistry and the plot was predictable. Movie makers: You've got a formula for these holiday movies. Find one aspect of the formula and twist it for us, just to make it work the 90 minutes, yeah?
label: literal

text:
A real movie after a long time! Coming in a time when there's an overkill of superhero and fantasy flicks, when all we find except, are mediocre rom-coms and unremarkable horror films, is an old fashioned cat and mouse thriller with comedy at the right places, all in a newly imagined never seen before setting of a rebellious group on the run.

At the heart, is a beautiful dad and daughter relationship which is an absolute revelation in the movie.

The action sequences are just amazing and reminiscent of the good old movies of the 2000s Hollywood.

Not one with a build up and a grand showdown for a climax, just a very good journey though.

text:
Politically Correct, Predictable, and Painfully Generic The best that can be said about Tracker is that it ticks every box on the politically correct checklist. We've got a white "superhero" protagonist, his handlers-a stereotypical middle-aged lesbian couple with one resembling an Ellen DeGeneres lookalike-an Asian lawyer secretly crushing on him despite her overly bossy demeanor, and a black computer nerd who magically conjures plot-advancing information out of thin air.

Beyond this carefully curated ensemble, there's little to hold onto. The show is predictable to a fault-you'll know exactly how it ends within the first five minutes of each episode. The lone-wolf, woods-educated protagonist is neither believable nor compelling, and the lines he's given feel more suited to a Hallmark movie than a gritty action drama.

Tracker lacks originality, depth, and emotional engagement. The characters are flat, the plotlines are cookie-cutter, and the attempts at tension or excitement fall utterly flat. If you're looking for a series to challenge you or keep you on the edge of your seat, keep tracking past this one.
label: literal

text:
Imagine an Ice Cream Shop So imagine you go into an ice cream shop and you order a sundae. They've got all kinds of nice stuff going on, beautiful delicious soft serve vanilla bean ice cream, some hot fudge, freshly cracked up peanuts, woah what is that?? A brownie? Some delicious house made whipped cream... Man this sundae is gonna be spectacular. Wow what more could you ask for? Cherry on top? Bring it on!!

And then all of a sudden they put an anchovy on top, and then another, and then a couple more, and then squirt some Dijon mustard on for good measure.

You don't even want the sundae anymore, in fact, you can't even look back on how nice that sundae used to be without thinking about all the stupid s*** they did at the very end just when it was going so well.

That's essentially Game of Thrones. I tried to rewatch it, but as I got through the first season I began looking at where all the pieces land at the end it's literally impossible to go back to. There are just so many ruined character arcs, so much pointlessness, and every time I come back here I drop it one more star it seems like. Game of Thrones is a beautiful anchovy sundae.
label: literal

As a woman, this feels more degrading than empowering. It would have been more impactful if intelligence had been more balanced, as it is in the real world. If you're a true crime lover, this show probably isn't for you. You'll get hung up on the problematic details and the breaks in protocol that would ruin any chance of getting a guilty trial verdict. text:
This isn't Frankenstein Weird science has got to be the most illogical picture John Huges ever scripted, but I can't say is that it doesn't have appeal.

Two teenage boys Wyatt and Gary take inspiration from Frankenstein to create the perfect woman who will bend to their every will. 

What they didn't expect is for Lisa to have a mind of her own and a few powers thrown in for effect.

I never heard of a computer hologram that can become a living breathing person not does it go into what Lisa really is. A genie? A mystical goddess from another time and place?

What makes this movie work is that the comedy aspect work very well rather the boys are finding frozen grandparents in the closet, Lisa mentioning private moments in the bathroom to parents or when a house party erupts into an outrages smorgasbord carnival funhouse.

In the end, Gary and Chet really do overcome insecurities to become brave young men who don't need a model to make them into cool guys. It was already inside them screaming to come out.

Weird Science is full of heart and witty humor that will have you coming back to revisit again and again.

text:
I just saw Sisu in the cinema - it's brilliant. SISU I just saw Sisu in the cinema - it's brilliant.

Without a doubt, the best film I have seen in the cinema this year, and that includes all the boring BAFTA-winning rubbish I had to endure.

It's a brilliantly entertaining action war film with minimal but essential dialogue. Brilliant performances, fantastic direction, awesome Cinematography and some of the best blocking I have seen in years.

There are 4 shots that will stay with me until my brain is destroyed for medical research.

This is a proper cinematic film that begs to be seen in the cinema and just goes to remind you that directing is an ART, and very few people are actually any good at it.

You do not need famous actors to tell a great story and you do not need a famous Cinematographer to make things look good.

This should win all the awards everywhere for everything. I don't care what anyone else thinks - this was a brilliant afternoon's viewing.

The acting, writing, direction and production values are generally on par with most high profile cable shows with 2 exceptions: 1 - Shawn Hatosy just smashes it as "Pope". His portrayal as a disturbed anti-social with significant prison time under his belt proves him to be one of the most underrated Character Actors working today. 2 - Ellen Barkins portrayal as "Smurf", the Cody crime families matriarch is quite possibly the worst acting by a name actor in a long time role on television that I have ever seen. text:
Return of Claire's quivering lower lip It appears almost immediately in under a minute, yet I was able to get through the entire series with lots of fast forwarding.

Overall the story is just not that good, despite the two leads driving it. 8 episodes is quite a bit for a simple story with a few twists, not that complicated and easily predictable from the outset.

The reveals aren't interesting either, and it's not nearly as good as Homeland or The Americans, which I both loved.

I don't think there's a fix for this. You can't trim it and make it better, although that would help. The writer can't add any more plot twists as there just isn't enough meat in the story to do so.

So it's a 4/10, barely watchable, lots of boring exposition and flashbacks. Perhaps it's a Dateline 90 min story stretched to 8x50mins. Ignore the plot holes and everyone is a supercop/super villian and you'll get through it without thinking. And quickly forget this series.

text:
I couldn't be MORE changed For Good! Wicked: For Good defies gravity and exceeds expectations set by Part One. The character arcs are expanded and deepened, the cinematography and directing builds a "calm before the storm" energy that will leave you glued to the screen, and the set design and costuming/makeup truly brings the whole story together for good!

Performances by the entire cast left me with goosebumps, especially those of Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo. The Oscar campaign for these actresses is going to be wild and BOTH deserve to walk away with their WELL-EARNED awards in their respective categories. The buildup of their stories coincide in a beautiful and painful way that left me turning away with tears that refused to stop.

And I, of course, HAVE to mention the INSANE tension between Marissa Bode's and Ethan Slater's on-screen chemistry. The deep layers of Nessarose and Boq were visible in ways unexplainable by words, but more so through the feeling I had running up my spine.

When it comes to the vocal performances of the soundtrack, Thank Goodness and NO GOOD DEED truly stood out to me. Cynthia is an absolute powerhouse and had the entire audience erupting in cheers and applause.

When it came to the second half of the film, it was definitely faster paced while still allowing key moments to have their centerstage spotlight. And of course, we have the crossover with The Wizard of Oz that fortunately does not steal away from the core of the film. Jon M. Chu, you are a GENIUS. I truly enjoyed how many off-stage moments were expanded in this film and allowed for many narratives to be dived deeper into.

And then there's For Good...holy shiz. I was crying for half the song and then immediately after all the way until the end of the film. There's also ONE scene that was not rushed and gutted my heart out in ways I can't even explain.

All in all, it's an astounding conclusion to a beloved franchise. I am truly changed for good.

Congratulotions!
label: literal

text:
The Gilmore Girls - A Life Without Consequences Warning: spoilers follow. Please only read if watched all seasons and only looking for another perspective on the show.

The Gilmore Girls is a good old fashioned family drama centred around the different generations of the Gilmore family. The Mother Daughter relationship forms the emotional core and how they interact with family members and the local community around them. The supporting characters, like Kirk, will grow on you as the series develops whilst others, like Michel, you will find irritating for the entire seven series.

Compared to much of the other dross you find on TV there is a lot of quality in this show with solid acting, funny and sad moments and good storylines. Sadly if you binge watch via Netflix, you will find yourself start to feel more and more irritated by the lead characters as the series unfolds.

The greatest source of irritation is the obsessive way the series creators/driving force The Palladinos protect the main characters Lorelai and Rory from any consequences for their actions.

The examples of this are many; both are able to eat copious amounts of junk food with no impact to their stick like figures. The Palladinos are essentially saying that if you are attractive, intelligent and sassy that you are immune from obesity. It is inverted snobbery of the highest order. Interestingly Sookie the non-threatening simple larger friend is never filmed eating loads but clearly in Palladinos eyes doesn't possess the intellectual capacity to be spared weight gain.

Other examples: Lorelai leaves fiance Max just before the wedding and goes on a road trip instead. Once back, she is spared the expected showdown with Max and instead moves to the next guy. Its only about Lorelai with no consequences for her selfishness. She then ultimately bounces between Luke and Chris, dropping one for the other depending on who meets her demands best.

Rory is no different; she breaks up an ex-boyfriend's marriage and then is rewarded with a new millionaire Yale boyfriend. She leaves her mother's home with no warning and is rewarded with a place at her millionaire grandparents place. She leaves the grandparents with no warning and is rewarded with an emotional homecoming to mother with no requirement for a clear the air discussion most of us would have. The one concession to consequences which is a clear the air dinner at the grandparents which provides the type of depth and accountability which the series often lacks.

All the way through the show we are continually told what a golden child Rory is because of her supposed intelligence. Her every whim is indulged by Stars Hollow. However, her friend Lane has twice the amount of emotional intelligence and overcomes a stifled childhood and a strict mother but this is never appreciated by the town in the same way.

At the centre of the family dynamic are the grand parents Richard and Emily who are both brilliantly written and the characters casting is perfect. The Friday night family dinners provide the best dialogue moments of the whole series as rifts are exposed and worked through. The interplay between the four leads is impeccably written and performed.

Another interesting aspect is that whilst Lorelai mocks her parents and their lifestyle, when it comes to being part of their dinners, parties and get togethers, she fits in effortlessly; she dresses the part, acts the part and generally feels completely at ease. Lorelai may have escaped a life of privilege but she is essentially still a product of that privileged world.

Talking of the grandparents, how Kelly Bishop who plays Emily did not win an Emmy over the seven series is a total mystery. She steals every scene and her portrayal of a life of privilege is an acting masterclass in itself.

The reunion series A Year in The Life clearly was conceived with good intentions but very badly executed. The four extended epsoodes contain weak storylines, scenes that drag on forever and have awful self-indulgent moments like the Stars Hollow musical. Old cast members return but with storylines of no substance. They almost look embarrassed to be returning to their old characters looking so much older. Rory's behaviour throughout the follow up is dreadful on both job and relationship fronts but of course the Palladinos ensure there are no consequences for her as ever. The one storyline of any depth is the therapy sessions between Lorelai and Emily which are abruptly halted and never followed up. The final moment is ill conceived and turns the series into soap opera cliffhanger mode.

Overall, the Gilmore Girls is well worth watching and maybe if I had watched one episode per week over seven years then the series irritations would not have been so noticeable. In short, I blame Netflix !
label: literal

text:
Fantastic!!! I must say it's such a pleasure to watch St. Denis Medical - much more of an authentic TV drama than most of the medical shows. This series manages to show the busy, emotional and the funny aspect of the healthcare system.

Probably its strongest feature is its realism in the depiction of the everyday struggles of doctors and other medical staff. The people are real, the problems are real, and the comedy is just the right kind of comedy most people know how to deal with stress in tough situations.

It depicts the dedication, teamwork and struggles of healthcare workers without neglecting the root causes of the problems in the healthcare system. For any healthcare worker or any curiosity seeker, St. Denis Medical gives an amazing balance of realism and comedy.

text:
needs a few changes Jim Hanson (Liam Neeson) has a shrinking property on the American Mexican border. The bank is foreclosing on what's left of his property including the hill where he spread his late wife's ashes. Her medical treatments had drained their life savings. He often finds illegals crossing his property. One day, he comes across Rosa and her son Miguel. They're on the run from the Mexican cartel. Jim gets into a gun battle and kills one of the cartel gunmen. Rosa is killed. Eventually, Jim is on the run with Miguel. Jim's stepdaughter Sarah Pennington (Katheryn Winnick) is a border agent.

This needs a few script changes including several situations during the final confrontation. There are some bad old fashion holdouts with the ending. Jim would never lay down his gun. As soon as that happens, both him and the kid would be killed. The biggest change I would make is to get rid of the money. It muddies Jim's motivation in helping Miguel. It would also heighten the danger by taking away a resource. In addition, Jim should have used the money to buy a car. The bad guys know the car and he knows the bad guys know it after the corrupt cop. It's also shot up to heck and on its last legs. Another change is Miguel's declaration that he wants to go home. Here's the deal. The kid is written as a real smart character. He wouldn't be dumb enough to want to go home where he can expect certain death. Overall, I like this lone marine who wants to do the right thing and Liam Neeson playing it. The script for this simplistic story has a few flaws that needs cleaning up.
label: literal

text:
A sad account, in every sense of the word, particularly however, with the liberties it takes. While Evan Peters certainly deserves accolades for his particularly engrossing and gripping personification of the monster that was Dahmer, the series - the first half of which was excellent - leaves much to be desired.

Note: A special mention should also be made of actor Shaun Brown who delivered a stellar performance in his portrayal of Tracy Edwards, Dahmer's last would-be victim.

Like a good book that you just do not want to put down and which leaves you wanting to know what the next page will bring, the first episode of "Dahmer, Monster" is compelling enough that if you have the time, you will not even think about turning off episode two.

The issues, for me, began around episode 5. This is when the story began to move away from Dahmer and his actions somewhat, and began to concentrate on other aspects of the case and the people who surrounded him. This disconnect just grew and grew into the ensuing episodes, with Dahmer being present, less and less. While some viewers may not have minded this, and perhaps viewed it as being 'thorough', to me, it was fluff and fill. There's is no convincing me that this series would not have benefitted from being two episodes shorter. THE LONG (OMG) review: The Beginning of this series took me off guard completely. The way Mabel was found in a very compromising scene, it surprised me. That was a great start! Like oh alright, you want my attention, CHECK. Curiosity, CHECK! Questionable, CHECK CHECK CHECK. Lol!

Why was she full of blood, and who AND why was there someone body there!?

And then.... It takes you back in time. And more questions come up. The mystery begins!

She actually knows him, and knows what he had done?

Why is he so curious for that ring?

Where was all that Jewelry from?

He is supposed to be already out of jail, where is he?

Was it a revenge?

Was it really someone from the building?

Was it an outsider?

Was it one of them?

Why was that note on the door?

Was the dog poisoned? If do, ill he make it?

There was only 4 listeners, and threats were being already made!

The more I think about it, the more questions that arise! I'm loving it! Lol!

To conclude; I don't typically watch TV, but this show keeps me wanting more (I binge watched all 3 episodes). I want every episode to be released already, BUT at the same time I don't want it to come to an end. (Can anyone else relate?) I have never ever done a review, EVER, on ANYTHING! But I had too for this. I wish I could say more to make this helpful to other's interest but that would be giving too much away for those who will start watching it after these reviews!

You must watch it! GO! You won't regret it!

If you read this far, omg you are awesome!

Like some of the unison and harmonies didn't have the timbre of non-autotuned recordings which bugged me (mainly cause I have watched a performance of it live) but regardless I believe I could have been blended together.

2. Elphaba. I will say that Cynthia did a commendable job and I'm glad that she's getting recognition for her amazing voice. All I wish to say is that she changed elphaba's character. Some of my friends who I watched it with (who haven't seen any form of the musical before) found her even annoying to an extent. I was mainly how she reacted to the people around her skin colour. 3. Pacing. I am a very patient person when it comes to long movies. However, I do agree with many comments when they say that it didn't need to be that long. The original musical was about the same length as the movie (aka the first act). They probably could of kept it more concise.

text:
Best comedy since Friends A young couple, Sam (Rose McIver) and Jay (Utkarsh Ambudkar), inherit a haunted mansion and, unaware of their invisible housemates, plan to turn it into a B&B. Their lives become much more complicated after a fall causes Sam to see the ghosts.

I have been bereft of quality comedy since Friends ended in 2004. But Ghosts came along and filled that void. Ever since I watched the pilot I was hooked, and I can honestly say that at the end of season 4 I have not disliked a single episode.

One of the rare things to happen in comedy is when you get an ensemble cast with not one single weak character. Every single character of the extended cast is well defined, and excellently portrayed by the actors. So much so you can't even see them as NOT their character in other works.

The only actor I knew before watching this series was Rose McIver, but I love every single one of them now. I laughed and was aghast and was saddened at the storylines, even though it's a comedy it has a broad impact still.

I was overjoyed when I heard seasons 5 and 6 had been greenlighted, I honestly can't wait. A solid and rare 8 for this show from me.

text: Severance: A Haunting and Thought-Provoking Thriller Severance on Apple TV+ is a masterclass in psychological thriller and dystopian storytelling. The series, created by Dan Erickson and directed by Ben Stiller and Aoife McArdle, follows employees at Lumon Industries, who undergo a controversial procedure that separates their work and personal memories. With a chilling atmosphere, gripping mystery, and stellar performances-especially from Adam Scott-*Severance* explores themes of corporate control, identity, and free will. The unsettling cinematography and haunting score amplify the eerie tone, making it a slow-burn thriller that lingers in the mind. A must-watch for fans of thought-provoking, suspenseful storytelling. Season 2 can't come soon enough!

text:
Magic without the Spark This sequel sadly fails to captivate with either its story or its plot. The characters feel strangely lifeless, each reduced to a single defining trait that they cling to from start to finish, and their conversations are delivered through dialogue that is as flat as it is forgettable. The chemistry between several of the main characters never quite clicks, either. A romance carried over from previous installments illustrates this perfectly: it's mentioned early on, and from that moment you can see every beat coming. What unfolds is explained through uninspired lines rather than conveyed through genuine performance.

The film is further weighed down by a handful of logical inconsistencies and plot holes, culminating in a twist that simply doesn't land. The magical "tricks," while central to the franchise's appeal, often feel exaggerated to the point of being implausible, which slightly dulls the atmosphere. I also found myself wishing for deeper character development-something the crowded roster of Horsemen makes understandably difficult.

And yet, in spite of all its shortcomings, I still enjoyed my time in the cinema. The movie lives on the playful fusion of magic and heist, and when it leans into its elaborate illusions, it delivers exactly the kind of spectacle you hope for. Watching the tricks unfold and later learning how they were pulled off remains delightfully entertaining. If you're willing to overlook the film's rougher edges and meet it with a sense of childlike wonder, there is still plenty of fun to be had. Even the humor occasionally hits just right, bringing a smile or a brief laugh.

In the final act, the film manages one last flourish-a trick paired with enough action to momentarily sweep you along. Ultimately, it's a watchable experience for fans of the first two entries; for newcomers, the trip to the theater may feel less rewarding. The tease of a fourth installment, and the way it is woven into the finale, unfortunately suggests that the franchise may now be more interested in financial returns than in maintaining its original quality. And that is genuinely disappointing.
label: literal

text: House without the humor or the rudeness. I am very disappointed in this show. Given that the creator also gave us Elementary, which I loved, I expected an awful lot more than we are getting. Perhaps if they had tried to be a mystery, or a medical, or an updated Sherlock Holmes, they could have successfully pulled off something unique. But they have failed on all fronts.

text:
Why does Disney drag itself through the gutter like this? It is really sad. Despite consistently being criticised Disney doesn't seem to want improve. This show is blander than a coleslaw without dressing and more predictable than Elons rocket launches.

Why is the compulsory Disney gay character always full of spite? He is the team mascot and trips his own team's quarterback on purpose!! No one bats and eye lid!! He should have been fired in episode three. Also he treats people so poorly it's awkward and wrecks the believability of story line. Literally he does not say one kind thing or show any evidence of self awareness.

Also classic Disney, every family is dysfunctional and all the characters act like this is normal and acceptable. The main character's dad literally tells his son he wishes he was dead. Seriously? That's not deep or emotional - it's just dark and awkward and again is unbelievable.

And the swearing... there's so much of it, for no reason at all. The dialogue will put you to sleep - it's gritty, distasteful and reminds me of coffee with the grounds added into it. The only fun part of the show was listening to Glenn Powells southern accent and idioms.

Overall, Chad Powers is classic Disney - in my opinion nothing but forced drama, unoriginal and unnecessary writing, and unrealistic characters you can't root for. It's the way Disney is going and I think it's a mistake.

text:
Liberties Taken of History, but an Enthralling Adventure. "A man is not a savage when he shares in your misfortune."

There's a lot to like here, and a few things to critique fairly. The fighting, the beast, and the main villain invoke a live-action animÃ© feel, while the tragic history of the African transplant along with the romance between GrÃ©goire and Marianne gave the essence of a fairy tale. The debaucherous elitists with their secret society, and their attempt to undermine the providences faith in the King's ability to protect them, is an interesting angle, along with a cultic priest who wants to pervert God's will to make his savage acts be seen as righteous judgment. I would critique though, that generally accepted history shows that the king's lieutenant of the hunt wasn't anything like this fraud of a hunter in this film, and he did, for the most part, destroy multiple beasts that terrorized the countryside. The believed final beast kill of a local hunter of devout faith wasn't even mentioned here, nor the valiant defense of a Mari-Jeane, who her and her friend wounded a beast in an attack against them. The King and the Church had a heavier hand in protecting the people and stopping the threat than what this film reimagines. The angle of an incestuous brother was disarming, and naming the villian after a local hunter and his son who helped as best they could is not cool, but my biggest critique would be the trope of the noble savage versus the mentality that the "white men can't see or hear" the natural world and spirits around him. There are many cultures of paler skinned tribes that are either pagan or simply more in tune with nature and spiritualism than the more modern civilized communities. As for the Americas, where Mani came from, the blended communities of native and foreign culture simply makes such writing pale to the nuance of the real world. Still, Mani and GrÃ©goire's potential for punishing groups of bad men (and women) with Conan-like brutality and Dare Devil type combat would be something I'd want to see more of.

text:
Great show, (mostly) great acting, quirky, believable... 6 seasons in and the show has lived up to its early promise. 

Admittedly there have been a few ups and downs, and in my opinion unfair comparisons with the more dramatic hospital shows however this show continues to stand firm as a solid counter to those overly 'OMG! drama of the week' types with its lighter form of dark humour very effectively countering the inherent saddening, and sometimes negative moments that cannot, and should not be avoided by the makers of such shows.

Eddie Falco as the titular Nurse Jackie is the headline name but I give my honours to Merritt Weaver (Zoey Barkow) and Anna Deveare Smith (Gloria Akilitus). Without these two who match our heroine on every level, and sometimes fly above her, the show would come to nought.

Along the way other characters have come and gone, grown and developed, or been the ever present stalwart. A couple have been grating or wearisome at times but overall thankfully there no one who has been truly cringeworthy.

The question now is where does the show go next? What will season 7 bring?

Imo a little tighter writing schedule could have utilised the existing story lines to wind the show up at a grand season 6 finale. I'm concerned that by continuing the show may rely on pushing the TV vs reality boundaries too far following Jackie's inevitable fall from grace as the 'Angelic' nursing figure she so often conveys in public but fails to live up to in her personal life.

I'll keep my fingers crossed and in the meantime recommend this show to all who are fed up with the usual doom and bloom and unrealistic portrait of hospital life. Take a chance with a less hyped half hour viewing...you may well enjoy it more than you thought, I know I did!
label: literal

text:
The Town of Derry Gets Darker, Deeper, and Deadlier This prequel series to It by Stephen King manages to revive the horror franchise in bold fashion. Exploring the origins of the evil in Derry and the twisted history of Pennywise. It delivers on atmosphere, vision and lore-expansion, though it doesn't always stick the landing in pacing or character depth.

ðŸ“º What It's About

Set in 1962 in Derry, Maine, the series follows the Hanlon family (Leroy & Charlotte plus young son Will) as they arrive in town only to discover children are going missing again. At the same time, a Cold-War era military operation is investigating strange phenomena, drawing the town's darkness into conspiracy and myth.

âœ… What Worked

1. The performances especially of Jovan Adepo (Leroy Hanlon) and Taylour Paige (Charlotte). Bring emotional weight and genuine fear to the proceedings.

2. The production design, set in the early '60s, gives Derry a sinister, period feel: the town hides its evil beneath a faÃ§ade of normalcy.

3. It expands the mythos of Pennywise and Derry in interesting ways. The connection to military operations and a larger supernatural scale give the show new narrative ambition.

4. For horror fans, the series contains some legitimately chilling sequences (especially early on) and a mood that lingers.

âŒ What Didn't Work

1. Some critics find the pacing inconsistent. The dual storylines (kids + military) don't always merge smoothly.

2. The horror moments, while strong, may not reach the same level of dread or originality as the best entries in the franchise.

3. Character development for younger characters is viewed as thin by some reviewers. The show sometimes leans on spectacle over connection.

4. For viewers unfamiliar with the previous It films or King's universe, some of the myth-building might feel dense or referential rather than fresh.

ðŸ’¬ Favorite Moments / Highlights

The opening sequence: a child hitchhiker in Derry vanishing in an eerily strange way. Sets the tone immediately.

The military subplot featuring a young version of Dick Hallorann (played by Chris Chalk): a fascinating tie-in to other King-verse stories.

Pennywise's appearances remain haunting, and the show doesn't shy away from gruesome or surreal horror elements.

The atmosphere of Derry as almost another character: the town's history, racism, and hidden evils all intertwine with the supernatural.

ðŸ’­ Final Thoughts

It: Welcome to Derry might not redefine horror TV, but it is a bold and worthy expansion of the It universe. It draws on rich source material, brings new ideas to the myth, and gives us a chilling journey into the heart of Derry's darkness.

If you're a fan of Pennywise, haunted towns, and horror with substance, this is a must-watch. Just know it takes time to build, and some payoff is still ahead.

Final Verdict: 6.5/10 ðŸŽˆ Scary, ambitious, and layered with myth while uneven at points, the journey into Derry's past is definitely worth the trip.

ðŸŽ¥ If You Liked This, You Might Also Enjoy

1. The Haunting of Hill House: haunted house, family trauma & horror with soul.

2. Chambers: body/horror + supernatural suspense.

3. It: the feature film this is prequel to; same town, same evil.

4. The Shining: explores overlapping themes and even character ties.

5. True Detective (Season 1): mood-driven horror, small town darkness, myth & menace.
label: figurative

text:
Worth waiting for. I made the decision to wait for the second part's release to watch it, and I watched the first one, and went straight to the cinema for this, for me it's one long film.

Where do you start? It's a messed up book, with some real dark, crazy horror. Some of it translated here, some of it didn't. The famous scene where Pennywise is first seen I loved, it was terrifying, and from that first moment, I loved Bill SkarsgÃ¥rd, and have nothing but praise for him.

People criticising the run time, clearly haven't read the book, it's a long, but rewarding book. As I now can compare the two films, I preferred this first installment. It's very well made, well acted, definitely enjoyable.

Sometimes it felt more adventure then horror, it never really felt full on horror, there were some very good scenes, but they could have ramped it up a bit. Many people are terrified of clowns, they could have pushed that vibe a bit more. Lots of humour, too much though? Not sure, I didn't detect much humour in the book.

I'm so glad Stephen King is on the big screen still, how about a reworking of The Tommyknockers?

7.5/10

text:
A by-the-numbers epic where nothing happens. Fantastic songs. I have seen Moana five times. Each time I am captivated by the first half hour. Around the time they get to the giant crab hoarder Tamatoa, the movie runs out of steam and I remember the every last bit of the story. This is easy because there are no details left at that point before the film whimpers through its underrated finale.

There are great themes here, suitable for all ages. This "princess" movie should especially be seen by young girls. Disney seems especially good these days at developing female leads that are full of defiance and motivation. The older men are stodgy and fail to make the best decisions on their own. It is nice to see a female take command and not be defined by her relationship with a love interest.

In fact, I say nothing really happens in Moana, and I mean it. Albeit, sort of in a good way. I There is no love story of any kind. Not too long ago, the story of Moana would have ended with her falling in love with yhr only other male character who isnt her dad And "ick" at that thought. I am not sure Moana would pass the Bechdel test, as the only female characters are Moana and her grandmother and they only have Moana's father as a talking point, but in this case I would let it slide. The film is well intentioned. I especially love the archetype of the bull-headed prototypcal man being portrayed as an over-artogant fool. The song "You're Welcome" flips the script on songs that that are lists of things worth thanking, and Maui takes unwarranted credit for everything. It might as well be called "The Mansplaining Anthem."

The music is filled with a lot of the best melodies ever. It's a shame that all of the memorable songs are front-loaded into the first half. Besides "You're Welcome", there is the Oscar nominated, "How Far I'll Go" and my personal favorite, "Who You Are." When I hear that l, it is literally impossible not to hum along with Moana's countermelodic responses.

"We share everything we make.

We joke and we weave our baskets.

The fishermen come back from the sea." "I wanna see - "

Give this team an Oscar.

For something that seems like something Lin-Manuel Miranda did for Disney as a short-sighted favor, the music here is is way better than it has any right to be. This would make a great Broadway musical, albeit one with only two characters and five real songs.

The animation is serviceable, but nothing beyond what we expected in 2016. The water and lava effects are astounding, but I am always surprised by how goodwater and fire effects look in pretty much every CGI animated movie. The struggle between Moana and the volcano goddess is a visual treat and is worth the price of admission.

As of me writing this The sequel was released to tepid reviews. This doesn't surprise me. There are no hooks left in the thread bare story that I wished were further explored. Next on the schedule isn't Moana sequel but a live action Remake. Mayve this one will be Disney's least necessary yet.

Moana is a movie best suited as a 25 minute Disney attraction. Kids should see it, and the songs are keepers.

7.5/10.

text:
A True Human Film Many of the reasons people are reviewing this poorly are the reason I feel it is a good film: It paints very negative views of modern dating. This is a strength. The film takes a strong point of view in a time when many are afraid to do so.

It's slow. This is a human story, told in real scale, through the beautiful haze of 35mm and realist acting. It is not meant to jump you out of your seat. It is painting with gorgeously long, unusually daring, and meticulously designed shots. Just admire the painting.

Lack of character arcs. I would argue this, but even if we were to rephrase as no drastic arcs, again this is realism. It's deeply human. In normal life, we as humans change very slowly most often, and to see this on screen was beautifully accessible.

Overall, this movie is a beautifully made piece that evokes feelings of classics with its medium and acting, but with modern flair that makes it feel entirely unique and new. A true human film.

text:
This series never should have been done All of the actors in this series did a great job, specifically Peters who portrayed Dahmer. But that's the only reason to why I give this a 3/10 instead of a 1/10.

I've watched lots of true crime, but this series was something else. Netflix has taken a real life event - peoples real trauma (let me remind you that this did not happen thaaat long ago either) - and made it into a tv-show mixed with fictional events. What makes this different from lots of other true crime that I've seen is that they have real actors (who dresses the same as the real victims and of course are named the same thing as them) who they've used to recreate the scenes of the murderers. If you don't find any issues with this ethically yet, please have in mind that lots of the murderers that are shown in this series have made up stuff thrown in to the scenes which never has never happened just to make it more interesting for the viewer. For example the episode that focused on the very sweet deaf guy that unfortunately met paths with Dahmer, that was not at all how his last day looked like. What make this even more ethically wrong, is that Netflix did not even ask or inform the families of the victims first.

It's awful how hard Netflix are trying to capitalize on so many completely innocent young mens deaths. This series never should have been made. I feel genuinely sorry for the victims families about having to relive this again, I never would have watched it through if I knew everything I've learned from googling the case now after I've seen it.
label: literal

text:
Only four episodes in and loving it! I know we are only four episodes in to this series, but I am really enjoying it so far. It is dark, funny, topical and has a little bit of mystery. I am not a huge New York-o-phile, but I appreciate the appeal and the willingness of this series to poke fun at itself. This reminds me of how much I enjoy and have always enjoyed Steve Martin.

I am seatbelted in and can't wait to see where this story takes us.

The series is about a murder in an expensive piece of residential real estate in New York called The Arconia...or at least our three strangers turned podcasters think it's a murder, the police think it is a straightforward suicide. The three strangers, played by Steve Martin, Martin Short and Selena Gomez, all live in the building and are brought together during a fire alarm because of their love of a true crime podcast (the podcast is done by a character played by Tina Fey), everything is not ok in Oklahoma. When the three of them discover there has been a death in the building, they decide to come together to solve it...and naturally do a podcast about it.

Amazing cameos and wonderful melancholy storylines...everyone seems to be hiding something, which is a great set up for a who-done-it.

text:
Nice build up, poor pay off First one hour and half seem inspired by Magnolia. But the highly ambitious build up maybe was not a good idea, given the rather generic outcome.

The director gives us an interesting premise and some well written characters but unfortunately he is unable to give us a conclusion of equally high standards.

From a very early stage in the film he gives us a hint about why everything is happening (car graffiti). The very simple and silly explanation betrayed to inability of the director to come up with something better than b movie shocks and a cheesy villain that reminded me of the TV shows I used to watch as a kid.

I think it was a serious error to bring supernatural elements in this type of film. The director seems to have forgotten that the sophisticated audience he wants to target, don't believe in witchcraft.

Apart from introducing the villain and her magical spells, there is not much to help the viewer understand why everything happened. The title does not make much sense. We know who the "weapons" are but we don't know why they're weapons.

Weapons is a film that thinks its smarter than what it actually is. I suppose it's smarter than some of the viewers, which could explain the overhype.

text:
Superman Review! First watch review:

ðŸ†95%

I went into this movie with pretty high expectations. James Gunn might be my favorite comic book movie director, and his previous movie Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 is hands down my favorite MCU movie. Even though this wasn't my most anticipated movie of the year, it'll likely end up being my number one favorite movie of the year. I'll try my best to make this review without spoilers. I thought David Corenswet was great as Superman, and Krypto was absolutely adorable. I also really liked Mr. Terrific; he was easily my favorite character in the Justice Gang, and Rachel Brosnahan was decent as Lois Lane. Nicholas Hoult was amazing as Lex Luthor; he's easily in my opinion the most hateable Lex Luther we've ever seen on the big screen yet; he's pretty much pure evil. The movie didn't really go into deep detail about his character, so I do think that the movie could've done more with him, but what we got with him was still very good. The plot twist towards the end of the movie was decent; it wasn't anything crazy, but still, I didn't see it coming. The comedy in the movie is kind of what you'd expect from a James Gunn movie. I didn't think it was anywhere near as funny as the Guardians of the Galaxy movies, but still, there were some funny moments. This movie feels just like a comic book, which is definitely one of the best parts about the movie. I also really liked the message of the movie, and to be honest, I liked the changes they did to Superman's real parents; I actually enjoyed seeing a slight change to it; after a while, getting the same story with them over and over again gets a little old. Overall, this is easily my favorite Superman movie, and this is definitely an amazing start to the DCU!

---------------------------

Second watch review:

ðŸ†96%

Somehow I enjoyed this even more on rewatch, which is crazy since this movie was already my favorite of the year to begin with. This is definitely a top 2-3 DC movie ever. The Dark Knight is still the best, but I'm not sure which is better between this and The Batman; it's definitely very close though. I absolutely love the message of the film. Even though many are different, everyone is still human. Lex Luthor hates Superman because he's an alien, but deep down Superman is even more human than Lex himself. What makes you human is your choices, not what others view you as. It's definitely one of my favorite messages I've seen from any comic book film. Also, the scenes in the pocket dimension are easily the best part of the movie for me. The scene with them falling into the black hole looks absolutely stunning. Overall, Superman is easily my favorite movie of the year, and I can't wait to see Supergirl and Man of Tomorrow!
label: literal

text:
The best of Sirk. I have always had mixed feelings about some of the Sirk melodramas. "Imitation of life" is "cool" in the wrong sense of the word, with a bad cast (Lana Turner, Sandra Dee, etc.), poor sets and a general look of fifties sitcom. "All that heaven allows" also has its flaws: a "politically correct" tone, a postcard look (that awful final shot of the deer) and a horrible and unveliable Rock Hudson.

On the contrary, I think "Magnificent Obsession" is the most poignant or Sirk's films. It has a restrained, "less is more", mood very different, for instance, from the frenzied and mad bursts of "Written on the wind". Take, among others, the sublime scenes of the "insomnia night" and its dark tones, the reading of comic strips by the lake or the sweet and serene ending. Here, Hudson and Wyman show a real insight with their characters and are really moving. The paced mood and the soft, pastel colors contrast with the hard driven and violent tones of "Written ..." (the red car and dresses, the aggressive performances of Malone and Stack, the "lubricious" dance,etc.). These two very different films are, in my view, the best of Sirk: "Obsession" tender and moving, "Written" violent and crazy.
label: literal

text: Simply the Finest Christmas Comedy Ever Filmed There is barely room for discussion regarding the fact this is a Christmas comedy that's perfect in virtually every respect. Withing its running time there are some of the funniest moments ever captured on film, holiday movie or otherwise. The script is one of the most hilarious, sharp, and intelligent in cinema history. The direction is inspired and technically it is without a doubt excellent. There is something about it that so stunningly captures the spirit of Christmas and the atmosphere of a family gathering. The cast is nothing less than remarkable, with an astonishing display of incredible talent. Everyone does a superb job and their comic timing is unbeatable. As an ensemble, it is truly a fantastic group effort. This is a director's dream cast and Jeremiah Chechik puts them through their paces as if he had a magic wand. Chevy Chase has never been better and Beverly D'Angelo is utterly amazing. Randy Quaid gives a knockout performance as Cousin Eddie and the motion picture wouldn't be complete without his visit. A yearly favorite at our house and one my late wife looked forward to very much. It is a happy memory of the holidays and always managed to make us laugh even though we've seen it every season since it was first shown on HBO. A funny, lovely gift to everyone for Christmas.

text:
Good historical drama, but too long Nuremberg (2025) is a psychological thriller historical drama movie written and directed by James Vanderbilt and is based on the 2013 book The Nazi and the Psychiatrist by Jack El-Hai and it follows a psychiatrist who is challenged with determining if a man is fit to stand trial at the Nuremberg trials. This is a movie that caught my eye only because of James Vanderbilt as it is very different from what he is usually know for. Well, I just got done watching the movie and it was good.

Positives for Nuremberg (2025): The story in this movie is really interesting as it explores a story in time that I am not familiar with. The movie is shot and directed very well by Vanderbilt as you can tell he wanted to do this story justice. The cast does a great job with their performances here and you have a lot of people including Russell Crowe, Rami Malek, Leo Woodall, John Slattery, Mark O'Brien, Colin Hanks, Wrenn Schmidt, Lydia Peckham, Richard E. Grant and Michael Shannon. I also have to say that the production on this movie look really good and it feels like you're being transported into a different lime in life with these people from that era. Vanderbilt did a good job at exploring the themes with the characters and how it effects their journey in the movie. And finally, the dialogue in this movie is really good and it was nice to listen to what these people were talking about.

Negatives for Nuremberg (2025): The movie is way too long for its runtime which I get for the story, but it felt padded out. The pacing is also really bad as it drags the story in such a slog that it gets boring at times. I also felt that the movie wasn't able to balance the themes with the emotional moments that well as they tend to cancel each other out. And finally, the ending of the movie goes on forever and it was annoying.

Overall, Nuremberg (2025) is a very well made historical drama movie with a great story and a great cast, but is let down by the runtime and pacing. Honestly, this is one of those movies that you should wait for it to be available on streaming.
label: figurative

text:
The Glossy Facade Gives Way To A Studio Classic Looking back on the abbreviated career of Douglas Sirk, "Magnificent Obsession" rises above being just another "woman's film" or "weepie". It actually serves as a notable turning point as it is the first in a string of Technicolor melodramas Sirk helmed at Universal-International, as well as one of his most popular. It also kick-started the malnourished career of Rock Hudson and sent his fame into another realm. Despite the film's lame-brained premise and endless implausibilities, Sirk takes the material and dishes out a sweet, moving drama that is a thinly disguised tale of Christianity.

Hudson stars as Bob Merrick, a millionaire playboy with no cares in the world. His lavish and self-serving lifestyle inadvertently leads to the death of a prominent local doctor, Wayne Phillips. Dr.Phillip's widow, Helen(Jane Wyman)tries to pick up the pieces of her shattered life, while at the same time resisting the advances of Bob Merrick. His persistence results in an accident in which Helen goes blind. In a convoluted and corny twist, Bob tries to redeem himself by giving selflessly to others and devoting his life to medicine to find a way to restore Helen's eyesight.

Every stereotype of every soap opera convention is used in overwhelming doses to tell the story of "Magnificent Obsession". The "alternative lifestyle" of Christianity that Bob learns is a mish-mash of psychobabble that even the most detail-oriented viewer would find boring and confusing. And the seriousness in which the actors take the material is eye-rollingly unbelievable. But this film is saved by the always-savvy direction of Douglas Sirk(who himself hated the plot)and an elegant, understated Jane Wyman who brought her own brand of sophistication to every role she played - and was Oscar-nominated for this role. Even Hudson is able to overcome his nerves in his first leading, A-list role to give a performance that is convincing. Sirk's use of reflective surfaces and a dominating color palette give this movie a look that is undeniably sheen. And Frank Skinner's classical score takes the ordinary material to an emotional level; although the choral "oohs and aahs" on the soundtrack are a bit pungent for such a quiet film. This is not Sirk's best work, but it is definitely solid enough to engage first time viewers and a must for fans of the German-bred director's work.
label: figurative
